label: lvl1>Chapter
line: I

label: fl>First Line
line: The Nellie, a cruising yawl, swung to her anchor without a flutter of the sails,

label: l>Line
line: and was at rest. The flood had made, the wind was nearly calm, and being bound

label: l>Line
line: down the river, the only thing for it was to come to and wait for the turn of

label: ll>Last Line
line: the tide.

label: fl>First Line
line: The sea-reach of the Thames stretched before us like the beginning of an

label: l>Line
line: interminable waterway. In the offing the sea and the sky were welded together

label: l>Line
line: without a joint, and in the luminous space the tanned sails of the barges

label: l>Line
line: drifting up with the tide seemed to stand still in red clusters of canvas

label: l>Line
line: sharply peaked, with gleams of varnished sprits. A haze rested on the low shores

label: l>Line
line: that ran out to sea in vanishing flatness. The air was dark above Gravesend, and

label: l>Line
line: farther back still seemed condensed into a mournful gloom, brooding motionless

label: ll>Last Line
line: over the biggest, and the greatest, town on earth.

label: fl>First Line
line: The Director of Companies was our captain and our host. We four affectionately

label: l>Line
line: watched his back as he stood in the bows looking to seaward.  On the whole river

label: l>Line
line: there was nothing that looked half so nautical. He resembled a pilot, which to a

label: l>Line
line: seaman is trustworthiness personified. It was difficult to realize his work was

label: l>Line
line: not out there in the luminous estuary, but behind him, within the brooding

label: ll>Last Line
line: gloom.

label: fl>First Line
line: Between us there was, as I have already said somewhere, the bond of the sea.

label: l>Line
line: Besides holding our hearts together through long periods of separation, it had

label: l>Line
line: the effect of making us tolerant of each other’s yarns—and even convictions. The

label: l>Line
line: Lawyer—the best of old fellows—had, because of his many years and many virtues,

label: l>Line
line: the only cushion on deck, and was lying on the only rug. The Accountant had

label: l>Line
line: brought out already a box of dominoes, and was toying architecturally with the

label: l>Line
line: bones. Marlow sat cross-legged right aft, leaning against the mizzen-mast. He

label: l>Line
line: had sunken cheeks, a yellow complexion, a straight back, an ascetic aspect, and,

label: l>Line
line: with his arms dropped, the palms of hands outwards, resembled an idol. The

label: l>Line
line: director, satisfied the anchor had good hold, made his way aft and sat down

label: l>Line
line: amongst us. We exchanged a few words lazily. Afterwards there was silence on

label: l>Line
line: board the yacht. For some reason or other we did not begin that game of

label: l>Line
line: dominoes. We felt meditative, and fit for nothing but placid staring. The day

label: l>Line
line: was ending in a serenity of still and exquisite brilliance. The water shone

label: l>Line
line: pacifically; the sky, without a speck, was a benign immensity of unstained

label: l>Line
line: light; the very mist on the Essex marsh was like a gauzy and radiant fabric,

label: l>Line
line: hung from the wooded rises inland, and draping the low shores in diaphanous

label: l>Line
line: folds. Only the gloom to the west, brooding over the upper reaches, became more

label: ll>Last Line
line: sombre every minute, as if angered by the approach of the sun.

label: fl>First Line
line: And at last, in its curved and imperceptible fall, the sun sank low, and from

label: l>Line
line: glowing white changed to a dull red without rays and without heat, as if about

label: l>Line
line: to go out suddenly, stricken to death by the touch of that gloom brooding over a

label: ll>Last Line
line: crowd of men.

label: fl>First Line
line: Forthwith a change came over the waters, and the serenity became less brilliant

label: l>Line
line: but more profound. The old river in its broad reach rested unruffled at the

label: l>Line
line: decline of day, after ages of good service done to the race that peopled its

label: l>Line
line: banks, spread out in the tranquil dignity of a waterway leading to the uttermost

label: l>Line
line: ends of the earth. We looked at the venerable stream not in the vivid flush of a

label: l>Line
line: short day that comes and departs for ever, but in the august light of abiding

label: l>Line
line: memories. And indeed nothing is easier for a man who has, as the phrase goes,

label: l>Line
line: “followed the sea” with reverence and affection, than to evoke the great spirit

label: l>Line
line: of the past upon the lower reaches of the Thames. The tidal current runs to and

label: l>Line
line: fro in its unceasing service, crowded with memories of men and ships it had

label: l>Line
line: borne to the rest of home or to the battles of the sea. It had known and served

label: l>Line
line: all the men of whom the nation is proud, from Sir Francis Drake to Sir John

label: l>Line
line: Franklin, knights all, titled and untitled—the great knights-errant of the sea.

label: l>Line
line: It had borne all the ships whose names are like jewels flashing in the night of

label: l>Line
line: time, from the _Golden Hind_ returning with her rotund flanks full of treasure,

label: l>Line
line: to be visited by the Queen’s Highness and thus pass out of the gigantic tale, to

label: l>Line
line: the _Erebus_ and _Terror_, bound on other conquests—and that never returned. It

label: l>Line
line: had known the ships and the men. They had sailed from Deptford, from Greenwich,

label: l>Line
line: from Erith—the adventurers and the settlers; kings’ ships and the ships of men

label: l>Line
line: on ’Change; captains, admirals, the dark “interlopers” of the Eastern trade, and

label: l>Line
line: the commissioned “generals” of East India fleets. Hunters for gold or pursuers

label: l>Line
line: of fame, they all had gone out on that stream, bearing the sword, and often the

label: l>Line
line: torch, messengers of the might within the land, bearers of a spark from the

label: l>Line
line: sacred fire. What greatness had not floated on the ebb of that river into the

label: l>Line
line: mystery of an unknown earth!... The dreams of men, the seed of commonwealths,

label: ll>Last Line
line: the germs of empires.

label: fl>First Line
line: The sun set; the dusk fell on the stream, and lights began to appear along the

label: l>Line
line: shore. The Chapman light-house, a three-legged thing erect on a mud-flat, shone

label: l>Line
line: strongly. Lights of ships moved in the fairway—a great stir of lights going up

label: l>Line
line: and going down. And farther west on the upper reaches the place of the monstrous

label: l>Line
line: town was still marked ominously on the sky, a brooding gloom in sunshine, a

label: ll>Last Line
line: lurid glare under the stars.

label: fl>First Line
line: “And this also,” said Marlow suddenly, “has been one of the dark places of the

label: ll>Last Line
line: earth.”

label: fl>First Line
line: He was the only man of us who still “followed the sea.” The worst that could be

label: l>Line
line: said of him was that he did not represent his class. He was a seaman, but he was

label: l>Line
line: a wanderer, too, while most seamen lead, if one may so express it, a sedentary

label: l>Line
line: life. Their minds are of the stay-at-home order, and their home is always with

label: l>Line
line: them—the ship; and so is their country—the sea. One ship is very much like

label: l>Line
line: another, and the sea is always the same. In the immutability of their

label: l>Line
line: surroundings the foreign shores, the foreign faces, the changing immensity of

label: l>Line
line: life, glide past, veiled not by a sense of mystery but by a slightly disdainful

label: l>Line
line: ignorance; for there is nothing mysterious to a seaman unless it be the sea

label: l>Line
line: itself, which is the mistress of his existence and as inscrutable as Destiny.

label: l>Line
line: For the rest, after his hours of work, a casual stroll or a casual spree on

label: l>Line
line: shore suffices to unfold for him the secret of a whole continent, and generally

label: l>Line
line: he finds the secret not worth knowing. The yarns of seamen have a direct

label: l>Line
line: simplicity, the whole meaning of which lies within the shell of a cracked nut.

label: l>Line
line: But Marlow was not typical (if his propensity to spin yarns be excepted), and to

label: l>Line
line: him the meaning of an episode was not inside like a kernel but outside,

label: l>Line
line: enveloping the tale which brought it out only as a glow brings out a haze, in

label: l>Line
line: the likeness of one of these misty halos that sometimes are made visible by the

label: ll>Last Line
line: spectral illumination of moonshine.

label: fl>First Line
line: His remark did not seem at all surprising. It was just like Marlow. It was

label: l>Line
line: accepted in silence. No one took the trouble to grunt even; and presently he

label: l>Line
line: said, very slow—“I was thinking of very old times, when the Romans first came

label: l>Line
line: here, nineteen hundred years ago—the other day .... Light came out of this river

label: l>Line
line: since—you say Knights? Yes; but it is like a running blaze on a plain, like a

label: l>Line
line: flash of lightning in the clouds. We live in the flicker—may it last as long as

label: l>Line
line: the old earth keeps rolling! But darkness was here yesterday. Imagine the

label: l>Line
line: feelings of a commander of a fine—what d’ye call ’em?—trireme in the

label: l>Line
line: Mediterranean, ordered suddenly to the north; run overland across the Gauls in a

label: l>Line
line: hurry; put in charge of one of these craft the legionaries—a wonderful lot of

label: l>Line
line: handy men they must have been, too—used to build, apparently by the hundred, in

label: l>Line
line: a month or two, if we may believe what we read. Imagine him here—the very end of

label: l>Line
line: the world, a sea the colour of lead, a sky the colour of smoke, a kind of ship

label: l>Line
line: about as rigid as a concertina—and going up this river with stores, or orders,

label: l>Line
line: or what you like. Sand-banks, marshes, forests, savages,—precious little to eat

label: l>Line
line: fit for a civilized man, nothing but Thames water to drink. No Falernian wine

label: l>Line
line: here, no going ashore. Here and there a military camp lost in a wilderness, like

label: l>Line
line: a needle in a bundle of hay—cold, fog, tempests, disease, exile, and death—death

label: l>Line
line: skulking in the air, in the water, in the bush. They must have been dying like

label: l>Line
line: flies here. Oh, yes—he did it. Did it very well, too, no doubt, and without

label: l>Line
line: thinking much about it either, except afterwards to brag of what he had gone

label: l>Line
line: through in his time, perhaps. They were men enough to face the darkness. And

label: l>Line
line: perhaps he was cheered by keeping his eye on a chance of promotion to the fleet

label: l>Line
line: at Ravenna by and by, if he had good friends in Rome and survived the awful

label: l>Line
line: climate. Or think of a decent young citizen in a toga—perhaps too much dice, you

label: l>Line
line: know—coming out here in the train of some prefect, or tax-gatherer, or trader

label: l>Line
line: even, to mend his fortunes. Land in a swamp, march through the woods, and in

label: l>Line
line: some inland post feel the savagery, the utter savagery, had closed round him—all

label: l>Line
line: that mysterious life of the wilderness that stirs in the forest, in the jungles,

label: l>Line
line: in the hearts of wild men. There’s no initiation either into such mysteries. He

label: l>Line
line: has to live in the midst of the incomprehensible, which is also detestable. And

label: l>Line
line: it has a fascination, too, that goes to work upon him.  The fascination of the

label: l>Line
line: abomination—you know, imagine the growing regrets, the longing to escape, the

label: ll>Last Line
line: powerless disgust, the surrender, the hate.”

label: sl>Single Line
line: He paused.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Mind,” he began again, lifting one arm from the elbow, the palm of the hand

label: l>Line
line: outwards, so that, with his legs folded before him, he had the pose of a Buddha

label: l>Line
line: preaching in European clothes and without a lotus-flower—“Mind, none of us would

label: l>Line
line: feel exactly like this. What saves us is efficiency—the devotion to efficiency.

label: l>Line
line: But these chaps were not much account, really. They were no colonists; their

label: l>Line
line: administration was merely a squeeze, and nothing more, I suspect. They were

label: l>Line
line: conquerors, and for that you want only brute force—nothing to boast of, when you

label: l>Line
line: have it, since your strength is just an accident arising from the weakness of

label: l>Line
line: others. They grabbed what they could get for the sake of what was to be got. It

label: l>Line
line: was just robbery with violence, aggravated murder on a great scale, and men

label: l>Line
line: going at it blind—as is very proper for those who tackle a darkness. The

label: l>Line
line: conquest of the earth, which mostly means the taking it away from those who have

label: l>Line
line: a different complexion or slightly flatter noses than ourselves, is not a pretty

label: l>Line
line: thing when you look into it too much. What redeems it is the idea only. An idea

label: l>Line
line: at the back of it; not a sentimental pretence but an idea; and an unselfish

label: l>Line
line: belief in the idea—something you can set up, and bow down before, and offer a

label: ll>Last Line
line: sacrifice to....”

label: fl>First Line
line: He broke off. Flames glided in the river, small green flames, red flames, white

label: l>Line
line: flames, pursuing, overtaking, joining, crossing each other—then separating

label: l>Line
line: slowly or hastily. The traffic of the great city went on in the deepening night

label: l>Line
line: upon the sleepless river. We looked on, waiting patiently—there was nothing else

label: l>Line
line: to do till the end of the flood; but it was only after a long silence, when he

label: l>Line
line: said, in a hesitating voice, “I suppose you fellows remember I did once turn

label: l>Line
line: fresh-water sailor for a bit,” that we knew we were fated, before the ebb began

label: ll>Last Line
line: to run, to hear about one of Marlow’s inconclusive experiences.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I don’t want to bother you much with what happened to me personally,” he began,

label: l>Line
line: showing in this remark the weakness of many tellers of tales who seem so often

label: l>Line
line: unaware of what their audience would like best to hear; “yet to understand the

label: l>Line
line: effect of it on me you ought to know how I got out there, what I saw, how I went

label: l>Line
line: up that river to the place where I first met the poor chap. It was the farthest

label: l>Line
line: point of navigation and the culminating point of my experience. It seemed

label: l>Line
line: somehow to throw a kind of light on everything about me—and into my thoughts. It

label: l>Line
line: was sombre enough, too—and pitiful—not extraordinary in any way—not very clear

label: ll>Last Line
line: either. No, not very clear. And yet it seemed to throw a kind of light.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had then, as you remember, just returned to London after a lot of Indian

label: l>Line
line: Ocean, Pacific, China Seas—a regular dose of the East—six years or so, and I was

label: l>Line
line: loafing about, hindering you fellows in your work and invading your homes, just

label: l>Line
line: as though I had got a heavenly mission to civilize you. It was very fine for a

label: l>Line
line: time, but after a bit I did get tired of resting. Then I began to look for a

label: l>Line
line: ship—I should think the hardest work on earth. But the ships wouldn’t even look

label: ll>Last Line
line: at me. And I got tired of that game, too.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Now when I was a little chap I had a passion for maps. I would look for hours

label: l>Line
line: at South America, or Africa, or Australia, and lose myself in all the glories of

label: l>Line
line: exploration. At that time there were many blank spaces on the earth, and when I

label: l>Line
line: saw one that looked particularly inviting on a map (but they all look that) I

label: l>Line
line: would put my finger on it and say, ‘When I grow up I will go there.’ The North

label: l>Line
line: Pole was one of these places, I remember. Well, I haven’t been there yet, and

label: l>Line
line: shall not try now. The glamour’s off. Other places were scattered about the

label: l>Line
line: hemispheres. I have been in some of them, and... well, we won’t talk about that.

label: l>Line
line: But there was one yet—the biggest, the most blank, so to speak—that I had a

label: ll>Last Line
line: hankering after.

label: fl>First Line
line: “True, by this time it was not a blank space any more. It had got filled since

label: l>Line
line: my boyhood with rivers and lakes and names. It had ceased to be a blank space of

label: l>Line
line: delightful mystery—a white patch for a boy to dream gloriously over. It had

label: l>Line
line: become a place of darkness. But there was in it one river especially, a mighty

label: l>Line
line: big river, that you could see on the map, resembling an immense snake uncoiled,

label: l>Line
line: with its head in the sea, its body at rest curving afar over a vast country, and

label: l>Line
line: its tail lost in the depths of the land. And as I looked at the map of it in a

label: l>Line
line: shop-window, it fascinated me as a snake would a bird—a silly little bird. Then

label: l>Line
line: I remembered there was a big concern, a Company for trade on that river. Dash it

label: l>Line
line: all! I thought to myself, they can’t trade without using some kind of craft on

label: l>Line
line: that lot of fresh water—steamboats! Why shouldn’t I try to get charge of one? I

label: l>Line
line: went on along Fleet Street, but could not shake off the idea. The snake had

label: ll>Last Line
line: charmed me.

label: fl>First Line
line: “You understand it was a Continental concern, that Trading society; but I have a

label: l>Line
line: lot of relations living on the Continent, because it’s cheap and not so nasty as

label: ll>Last Line
line: it looks, they say.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I am sorry to own I began to worry them. This was already a fresh departure for

label: l>Line
line: me. I was not used to get things that way, you know. I always went my own road

label: l>Line
line: and on my own legs where I had a mind to go. I wouldn’t have believed it of

label: l>Line
line: myself; but, then—you see—I felt somehow I must get there by hook or by crook.

label: l>Line
line: So I worried them. The men said ’My dear fellow,’ and did nothing. Then—would

label: l>Line
line: you believe it?—I tried the women. I, Charlie Marlow, set the women to work—to

label: l>Line
line: get a job. Heavens! Well, you see, the notion drove me. I had an aunt, a dear

label: l>Line
line: enthusiastic soul. She wrote: ‘It will be delightful. I am ready to do anything,

label: l>Line
line: anything for you.  It is a glorious idea. I know the wife of a very high

label: l>Line
line: personage in the Administration, and also a man who has lots of influence with,’

label: l>Line
line: etc. She was determined to make no end of fuss to get me appointed skipper of a

label: ll>Last Line
line: river steamboat, if such was my fancy.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I got my appointment—of course; and I got it very quick. It appears the Company

label: l>Line
line: had received news that one of their captains had been killed in a scuffle with

label: l>Line
line: the natives. This was my chance, and it made me the more anxious to go. It was

label: l>Line
line: only months and months afterwards, when I made the attempt to recover what was

label: l>Line
line: left of the body, that I heard the original quarrel arose from a

label: l>Line
line: misunderstanding about some hens. Yes, two black hens.  Fresleven—that was the

label: l>Line
line: fellow’s name, a Dane—thought himself wronged somehow in the bargain, so he went

label: l>Line
line: ashore and started to hammer the chief of the village with a stick. Oh, it

label: l>Line
line: didn’t surprise me in the least to hear this, and at the same time to be told

label: l>Line
line: that Fresleven was the gentlest, quietest creature that ever walked on two legs.

label: l>Line
line: No doubt he was; but he had been a couple of years already out there engaged in

label: l>Line
line: the noble cause, you know, and he probably felt the need at last of asserting

label: l>Line
line: his self-respect in some way. Therefore he whacked the old nigger mercilessly,

label: l>Line
line: while a big crowd of his people watched him, thunderstruck, till some man—I was

label: l>Line
line: told the chief’s son—in desperation at hearing the old chap yell, made a

label: l>Line
line: tentative jab with a spear at the white man—and of course it went quite easy

label: l>Line
line: between the shoulder-blades. Then the whole population cleared into the forest,

label: l>Line
line: expecting all kinds of calamities to happen, while, on the other hand, the

label: l>Line
line: steamer Fresleven commanded left also in a bad panic, in charge of the engineer,

label: l>Line
line: I believe. Afterwards nobody seemed to trouble much about Fresleven’s remains,

label: l>Line
line: till I got out and stepped into his shoes.  I couldn’t let it rest, though; but

label: l>Line
line: when an opportunity offered at last to meet my predecessor, the grass growing

label: l>Line
line: through his ribs was tall enough to hide his bones. They were all there. The

label: l>Line
line: supernatural being had not been touched after he fell. And the village was

label: l>Line
line: deserted, the huts gaped black, rotting, all askew within the fallen enclosures.

label: l>Line
line: A calamity had come to it, sure enough. The people had vanished. Mad terror had

label: l>Line
line: scattered them, men, women, and children, through the bush, and they had never

label: l>Line
line: returned. What became of the hens I don’t know either. I should think the cause

label: l>Line
line: of progress got them, anyhow. However, through this glorious affair I got my

label: ll>Last Line
line: appointment, before I had fairly begun to hope for it.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I flew around like mad to get ready, and before forty-eight hours I was

label: l>Line
line: crossing the Channel to show myself to my employers, and sign the contract.  In

label: l>Line
line: a very few hours I arrived in a city that always makes me think of a whited

label: l>Line
line: sepulchre. Prejudice no doubt. I had no difficulty in finding the Company’s

label: l>Line
line: offices. It was the biggest thing in the town, and everybody I met was full of

label: ll>Last Line
line: it. They were going to run an over-sea empire, and make no end of coin by trade.

label: fl>First Line
line: “A narrow and deserted street in deep shadow, high houses, innumerable windows

label: l>Line
line: with venetian blinds, a dead silence, grass sprouting right and left, immense

label: l>Line
line: double doors standing ponderously ajar. I slipped through one of these cracks,

label: l>Line
line: went up a swept and ungarnished staircase, as arid as a desert, and opened the

label: l>Line
line: first door I came to. Two women, one fat and the other slim, sat on

label: l>Line
line: straw-bottomed chairs, knitting black wool. The slim one got up and walked

label: l>Line
line: straight at me—still knitting with downcast eyes—and only just as I began to

label: l>Line
line: think of getting out of her way, as you would for a somnambulist, stood still,

label: l>Line
line: and looked up. Her dress was as plain as an umbrella-cover, and she turned round

label: l>Line
line: without a word and preceded me into a waiting-room. I gave my name, and looked

label: l>Line
line: about. Deal table in the middle, plain chairs all round the walls, on one end a

label: l>Line
line: large shining map, marked with all the colours of a rainbow. There was a vast

label: l>Line
line: amount of red—good to see at any time, because one knows that some real work is

label: l>Line
line: done in there, a deuce of a lot of blue, a little green, smears of orange, and,

label: l>Line
line: on the East Coast, a purple patch, to show where the jolly pioneers of progress

label: l>Line
line: drink the jolly lager-beer. However, I wasn’t going into any of these.  I was

label: l>Line
line: going into the yellow. Dead in the centre. And the river was

label: l>Line
line: there—fascinating—deadly—like a snake. Ough! A door opened, a white-haired

label: l>Line
line: secretarial head, but wearing a compassionate expression, appeared, and a skinny

label: l>Line
line: forefinger beckoned me into the sanctuary. Its light was dim, and a heavy

label: l>Line
line: writing-desk squatted in the middle. From behind that structure came out an

label: l>Line
line: impression of pale plumpness in a frock-coat. The great man himself. He was five

label: l>Line
line: feet six, I should judge, and had his grip on the handle-end of ever so many

label: l>Line
line: millions. He shook hands, I fancy, murmured vaguely, was satisfied with my

label: ll>Last Line
line: French. _Bon Voyage_.

label: fl>First Line
line: “In about forty-five seconds I found myself again in the waiting-room with the

label: l>Line
line: compassionate secretary, who, full of desolation and sympathy, made me sign some

label: l>Line
line: document. I believe I undertook amongst other things not to disclose any trade

label: ll>Last Line
line: secrets. Well, I am not going to.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I began to feel slightly uneasy. You know I am not used to such ceremonies, and

label: l>Line
line: there was something ominous in the atmosphere. It was just as though I had been

label: l>Line
line: let into some conspiracy—I don’t know—something not quite right; and I was glad

label: l>Line
line: to get out. In the outer room the two women knitted black wool feverishly.

label: l>Line
line: People were arriving, and the younger one was walking back and forth introducing

label: l>Line
line: them. The old one sat on her chair.  Her flat cloth slippers were propped up on

label: l>Line
line: a foot-warmer, and a cat reposed on her lap. She wore a starched white affair on

label: l>Line
line: her head, had a wart on one cheek, and silver-rimmed spectacles hung on the tip

label: l>Line
line: of her nose. She glanced at me above the glasses. The swift and indifferent

label: l>Line
line: placidity of that look troubled me. Two youths with foolish and cheery

label: l>Line
line: countenances were being piloted over, and she threw at them the same quick

label: l>Line
line: glance of unconcerned wisdom. She seemed to know all about them and about me,

label: l>Line
line: too. An eerie feeling came over me. She seemed uncanny and fateful. Often far

label: l>Line
line: away there I thought of these two, guarding the door of Darkness, knitting black

label: l>Line
line: wool as for a warm pall, one introducing, introducing continuously to the

label: l>Line
line: unknown, the other scrutinizing the cheery and foolish faces with unconcerned

label: l>Line
line: old eyes. _Ave!_ Old knitter of black wool. _Morituri te salutant_. Not many of

label: ll>Last Line
line: those she looked at ever saw her again—not half, by a long way.

label: fl>First Line
line: “There was yet a visit to the doctor. ‘A simple formality,’ assured me the

label: l>Line
line: secretary, with an air of taking an immense part in all my sorrows.  Accordingly

label: l>Line
line: a young chap wearing his hat over the left eyebrow, some clerk I suppose—there

label: l>Line
line: must have been clerks in the business, though the house was as still as a house

label: l>Line
line: in a city of the dead—came from somewhere up-stairs, and led me forth. He was

label: l>Line
line: shabby and careless, with inkstains on the sleeves of his jacket, and his cravat

label: l>Line
line: was large and billowy, under a chin shaped like the toe of an old boot. It was a

label: l>Line
line: little too early for the doctor, so I proposed a drink, and thereupon he

label: l>Line
line: developed a vein of joviality. As we sat over our vermouths he glorified the

label: l>Line
line: Company’s business, and by and by I expressed casually my surprise at him not

label: l>Line
line: going out there. He became very cool and collected all at once. ‘I am not such a

label: l>Line
line: fool as I look, quoth Plato to his disciples,’ he said sententiously, emptied

label: ll>Last Line
line: his glass with great resolution, and we rose.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The old doctor felt my pulse, evidently thinking of something else the while.

label: l>Line
line: ‘Good, good for there,’ he mumbled, and then with a certain eagerness asked me

label: l>Line
line: whether I would let him measure my head. Rather surprised, I said Yes, when he

label: l>Line
line: produced a thing like calipers and got the dimensions back and front and every

label: l>Line
line: way, taking notes carefully. He was an unshaven little man in a threadbare coat

label: l>Line
line: like a gaberdine, with his feet in slippers, and I thought him a harmless fool.

label: l>Line
line: ‘I always ask leave, in the interests of science, to measure the crania of those

label: l>Line
line: going out there,’ he said. ‘And when they come back, too?’ I asked. ‘Oh, I never

label: l>Line
line: see them,’ he remarked; ‘and, moreover, the changes take place inside, you

label: l>Line
line: know.’ He smiled, as if at some quiet joke. ‘So you are going out there. Famous.

label: l>Line
line: Interesting, too.’ He gave me a searching glance, and made another note.  ‘Ever

label: l>Line
line: any madness in your family?’ he asked, in a matter-of-fact tone.  I felt very

label: l>Line
line: annoyed. ‘Is that question in the interests of science, too?’ ‘It would be,’ he

label: l>Line
line: said, without taking notice of my irritation, ‘interesting for science to watch

label: l>Line
line: the mental changes of individuals, on the spot, but...’ ‘Are you an alienist?’ I

label: l>Line
line: interrupted. ‘Every doctor should be—a little,’ answered that original,

label: l>Line
line: imperturbably. ‘I have a little theory which you messieurs who go out there must

label: l>Line
line: help me to prove. This is my share in the advantages my country shall reap from

label: l>Line
line: the possession of such a magnificent dependency. The mere wealth I leave to

label: l>Line
line: others. Pardon my questions, but you are the first Englishman coming under my

label: l>Line
line: observation...’ I hastened to assure him I was not in the least typical. ’If I

label: l>Line
line: were,’ said I, ‘I wouldn’t be talking like this with you.’ ‘What you say is

label: l>Line
line: rather profound, and probably erroneous,’ he said, with a laugh. ‘Avoid

label: l>Line
line: irritation more than exposure to the sun. _Adieu_. How do you English say, eh?

label: l>Line
line: Good-bye. Ah! Good-bye. _Adieu_. In the tropics one must before everything keep

label: ll>Last Line
line: calm.’... He lifted a warning forefinger.... ’_Du calme, du calme_.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “One thing more remained to do—say good-bye to my excellent aunt. I found her

label: l>Line
line: triumphant. I had a cup of tea—the last decent cup of tea for many days—and in a

label: l>Line
line: room that most soothingly looked just as you would expect a lady’s drawing-room

label: l>Line
line: to look, we had a long quiet chat by the fireside. In the course of these

label: l>Line
line: confidences it became quite plain to me I had been represented to the wife of

label: l>Line
line: the high dignitary, and goodness knows to how many more people besides, as an

label: l>Line
line: exceptional and gifted creature—a piece of good fortune for the Company—a man

label: l>Line
line: you don’t get hold of every day. Good heavens! and I was going to take charge of

label: l>Line
line: a two-penny-half-penny river-steamboat with a penny whistle attached! It

label: l>Line
line: appeared, however, I was also one of the Workers, with a capital—you know.

label: l>Line
line: Something like an emissary of light, something like a lower sort of apostle.

label: l>Line
line: There had been a lot of such rot let loose in print and talk just about that

label: l>Line
line: time, and the excellent woman, living right in the rush of all that humbug, got

label: l>Line
line: carried off her feet. She talked about ‘weaning those ignorant millions from

label: l>Line
line: their horrid ways,’ till, upon my word, she made me quite uncomfortable.  I

label: ll>Last Line
line: ventured to hint that the Company was run for profit.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘You forget, dear Charlie, that the labourer is worthy of his hire,’ she said,

label: l>Line
line: brightly. It’s queer how out of touch with truth women are. They live in a world

label: l>Line
line: of their own, and there has never been anything like it, and never can be. It is

label: l>Line
line: too beautiful altogether, and if they were to set it up it would go to pieces

label: l>Line
line: before the first sunset. Some confounded fact we men have been living

label: l>Line
line: contentedly with ever since the day of creation would start up and knock the

label: ll>Last Line
line: whole thing over.

label: fl>First Line
line: “After this I got embraced, told to wear flannel, be sure to write often, and so

label: l>Line
line: on—and I left. In the street—I don’t know why—a queer feeling came to me that I

label: l>Line
line: was an imposter. Odd thing that I, who used to clear out for any part of the

label: l>Line
line: world at twenty-four hours’ notice, with less thought than most men give to the

label: l>Line
line: crossing of a street, had a moment—I won’t say of hesitation, but of startled

label: l>Line
line: pause, before this commonplace affair. The best way I can explain it to you is

label: l>Line
line: by saying that, for a second or two, I felt as though, instead of going to the

label: ll>Last Line
line: centre of a continent, I were about to set off for the centre of the earth.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I left in a French steamer, and she called in every blamed port they have out

label: l>Line
line: there, for, as far as I could see, the sole purpose of landing soldiers and

label: l>Line
line: custom-house officers. I watched the coast. Watching a coast as it slips by the

label: l>Line
line: ship is like thinking about an enigma. There it is before you—smiling, frowning,

label: l>Line
line: inviting, grand, mean, insipid, or savage, and always mute with an air of

label: l>Line
line: whispering, ‘Come and find out.’ This one was almost featureless, as if still in

label: l>Line
line: the making, with an aspect of monotonous grimness. The edge of a colossal

label: l>Line
line: jungle, so dark-green as to be almost black, fringed with white surf, ran

label: l>Line
line: straight, like a ruled line, far, far away along a blue sea whose glitter was

label: l>Line
line: blurred by a creeping mist. The sun was fierce, the land seemed to glisten and

label: l>Line
line: drip with steam. Here and there greyish-whitish specks showed up clustered

label: l>Line
line: inside the white surf, with a flag flying above them perhaps. Settlements some

label: l>Line
line: centuries old, and still no bigger than pinheads on the untouched expanse of

label: l>Line
line: their background. We pounded along, stopped, landed soldiers; went on, landed

label: l>Line
line: custom-house clerks to levy toll in what looked like a God-forsaken wilderness,

label: l>Line
line: with a tin shed and a flag-pole lost in it; landed more soldiers—to take care of

label: l>Line
line: the custom-house clerks, presumably. Some, I heard, got drowned in the surf; but

label: l>Line
line: whether they did or not, nobody seemed particularly to care. They were just

label: l>Line
line: flung out there, and on we went. Every day the coast looked the same, as though

label: l>Line
line: we had not moved; but we passed various places—trading places—with names like

label: l>Line
line: Gran’ Bassam, Little Popo; names that seemed to belong to some sordid farce

label: l>Line
line: acted in front of a sinister back-cloth. The idleness of a passenger, my

label: l>Line
line: isolation amongst all these men with whom I had no point of contact, the oily

label: l>Line
line: and languid sea, the uniform sombreness of the coast, seemed to keep me away

label: l>Line
line: from the truth of things, within the toil of a mournful and senseless delusion.

label: l>Line
line: The voice of the surf heard now and then was a positive pleasure, like the

label: l>Line
line: speech of a brother. It was something natural, that had its reason, that had a

label: l>Line
line: meaning. Now and then a boat from the shore gave one a momentary contact with

label: l>Line
line: reality. It was paddled by black fellows. You could see from afar the white of

label: l>Line
line: their eyeballs glistening. They shouted, sang; their bodies streamed with

label: l>Line
line: perspiration; they had faces like grotesque masks—these chaps; but they had

label: l>Line
line: bone, muscle, a wild vitality, an intense energy of movement, that was as

label: l>Line
line: natural and true as the surf along their coast. They wanted no excuse for being

label: l>Line
line: there. They were a great comfort to look at. For a time I would feel I belonged

label: l>Line
line: still to a world of straightforward facts; but the feeling would not last long.

label: l>Line
line: Something would turn up to scare it away. Once, I remember, we came upon a

label: l>Line
line: man-of-war anchored off the coast. There wasn’t even a shed there, and she was

label: l>Line
line: shelling the bush. It appears the French had one of their wars going on

label: l>Line
line: thereabouts. Her ensign dropped limp like a rag; the muzzles of the long

label: l>Line
line: six-inch guns stuck out all over the low hull; the greasy, slimy swell swung her

label: l>Line
line: up lazily and let her down, swaying her thin masts. In the empty immensity of

label: l>Line
line: earth, sky, and water, there she was, incomprehensible, firing into a continent.

label: l>Line
line: Pop, would go one of the six-inch guns; a small flame would dart and vanish, a

label: l>Line
line: little white smoke would disappear, a tiny projectile would give a feeble

label: l>Line
line: screech—and nothing happened. Nothing could happen. There was a touch of

label: l>Line
line: insanity in the proceeding, a sense of lugubrious drollery in the sight; and it

label: l>Line
line: was not dissipated by somebody on board assuring me earnestly there was a camp

label: ll>Last Line
line: of natives—he called them enemies!—hidden out of sight somewhere.

label: fl>First Line
line: “We gave her her letters (I heard the men in that lonely ship were dying of

label: l>Line
line: fever at the rate of three a day) and went on. We called at some more places

label: l>Line
line: with farcical names, where the merry dance of death and trade goes on in a still

label: l>Line
line: and earthy atmosphere as of an overheated catacomb; all along the formless coast

label: l>Line
line: bordered by dangerous surf, as if Nature herself had tried to ward off

label: l>Line
line: intruders; in and out of rivers, streams of death in life, whose banks were

label: l>Line
line: rotting into mud, whose waters, thickened into slime, invaded the contorted

label: l>Line
line: mangroves, that seemed to writhe at us in the extremity of an impotent despair.

label: l>Line
line: Nowhere did we stop long enough to get a particularized impression, but the

label: l>Line
line: general sense of vague and oppressive wonder grew upon me. It was like a weary

label: ll>Last Line
line: pilgrimage amongst hints for nightmares.

label: fl>First Line
line: “It was upward of thirty days before I saw the mouth of the big river. We

label: l>Line
line: anchored off the seat of the government. But my work would not begin till some

label: l>Line
line: two hundred miles farther on. So as soon as I could I made a start for a place

label: ll>Last Line
line: thirty miles higher up.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had my passage on a little sea-going steamer. Her captain was a Swede, and

label: l>Line
line: knowing me for a seaman, invited me on the bridge. He was a young man, lean,

label: l>Line
line: fair, and morose, with lanky hair and a shuffling gait. As we left the miserable

label: l>Line
line: little wharf, he tossed his head contemptuously at the shore.  ‘Been living

label: l>Line
line: there?’ he asked. I said, ‘Yes.’ ‘Fine lot these government chaps—are they not?’

label: l>Line
line: he went on, speaking English with great precision and considerable bitterness.

label: l>Line
line: ‘It is funny what some people will do for a few francs a month. I wonder what

label: l>Line
line: becomes of that kind when it goes upcountry?’ I said to him I expected to see

label: l>Line
line: that soon. ‘So-o-o!’ he exclaimed. He shuffled athwart, keeping one eye ahead

label: l>Line
line: vigilantly. ‘Don’t be too sure,’ he continued. ‘The other day I took up a man

label: l>Line
line: who hanged himself on the road.  He was a Swede, too.’ ’Hanged himself! Why, in

label: l>Line
line: God’s name?’ I cried. He kept on looking out watchfully. ‘Who knows? The sun too

label: ll>Last Line
line: much for him, or the country perhaps.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “At last we opened a reach. A rocky cliff appeared, mounds of turned-up earth by

label: l>Line
line: the shore, houses on a hill, others with iron roofs, amongst a waste of

label: l>Line
line: excavations, or hanging to the declivity. A continuous noise of the rapids above

label: l>Line
line: hovered over this scene of inhabited devastation. A lot of people, mostly black

label: l>Line
line: and naked, moved about like ants. A jetty projected into the river. A blinding

label: l>Line
line: sunlight drowned all this at times in a sudden recrudescence of glare. ‘There’s

label: l>Line
line: your Company’s station,’ said the Swede, pointing to three wooden barrack-like

label: l>Line
line: structures on the rocky slope. ‘I will send your things up. Four boxes did you

label: ll>Last Line
line: say? So. Farewell.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I came upon a boiler wallowing in the grass, then found a path leading up the

label: l>Line
line: hill. It turned aside for the boulders, and also for an undersized railway-truck

label: l>Line
line: lying there on its back with its wheels in the air. One was off. The thing

label: l>Line
line: looked as dead as the carcass of some animal. I came upon more pieces of

label: l>Line
line: decaying machinery, a stack of rusty rails. To the left a clump of trees made a

label: l>Line
line: shady spot, where dark things seemed to stir feebly. I blinked, the path was

label: l>Line
line: steep. A horn tooted to the right, and I saw the black people run. A heavy and

label: l>Line
line: dull detonation shook the ground, a puff of smoke came out of the cliff, and

label: l>Line
line: that was all. No change appeared on the face of the rock. They were building a

label: l>Line
line: railway. The cliff was not in the way or anything; but this objectless blasting

label: ll>Last Line
line: was all the work going on.

label: fl>First Line
line: “A slight clinking behind me made me turn my head. Six black men advanced in a

label: l>Line
line: file, toiling up the path. They walked erect and slow, balancing small baskets

label: l>Line
line: full of earth on their heads, and the clink kept time with their footsteps.

label: l>Line
line: Black rags were wound round their loins, and the short ends behind waggled to

label: l>Line
line: and fro like tails. I could see every rib, the joints of their limbs were like

label: l>Line
line: knots in a rope; each had an iron collar on his neck, and all were connected

label: l>Line
line: together with a chain whose bights swung between them, rhythmically clinking.

label: l>Line
line: Another report from the cliff made me think suddenly of that ship of war I had

label: l>Line
line: seen firing into a continent. It was the same kind of ominous voice; but these

label: l>Line
line: men could by no stretch of imagination be called enemies. They were called

label: l>Line
line: criminals, and the outraged law, like the bursting shells, had come to them, an

label: l>Line
line: insoluble mystery from the sea. All their meagre breasts panted together, the

label: l>Line
line: violently dilated nostrils quivered, the eyes stared stonily uphill. They passed

label: l>Line
line: me within six inches, without a glance, with that complete, deathlike

label: l>Line
line: indifference of unhappy savages. Behind this raw matter one of the reclaimed,

label: l>Line
line: the product of the new forces at work, strolled despondently, carrying a rifle

label: l>Line
line: by its middle. He had a uniform jacket with one button off, and seeing a white

label: l>Line
line: man on the path, hoisted his weapon to his shoulder with alacrity. This was

label: l>Line
line: simple prudence, white men being so much alike at a distance that he could not

label: l>Line
line: tell who I might be. He was speedily reassured, and with a large, white,

label: l>Line
line: rascally grin, and a glance at his charge, seemed to take me into partnership in

label: l>Line
line: his exalted trust. After all, I also was a part of the great cause of these high

label: ll>Last Line
line: and just proceedings.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Instead of going up, I turned and descended to the left. My idea was to let

label: l>Line
line: that chain-gang get out of sight before I climbed the hill. You know I am not

label: l>Line
line: particularly tender; I’ve had to strike and to fend off. I’ve had to resist and

label: l>Line
line: to attack sometimes—that’s only one way of resisting—without counting the exact

label: l>Line
line: cost, according to the demands of such sort of life as I had blundered into.

label: l>Line
line: I’ve seen the devil of violence, and the devil of greed, and the devil of hot

label: l>Line
line: desire; but, by all the stars! these were strong, lusty, red-eyed devils, that

label: l>Line
line: swayed and drove men—men, I tell you.  But as I stood on this hillside, I

label: l>Line
line: foresaw that in the blinding sunshine of that land I would become acquainted

label: l>Line
line: with a flabby, pretending, weak-eyed devil of a rapacious and pitiless folly.

label: l>Line
line: How insidious he could be, too, I was only to find out several months later and

label: l>Line
line: a thousand miles farther.  For a moment I stood appalled, as though by a

label: ll>Last Line
line: warning. Finally I descended the hill, obliquely, towards the trees I had seen.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I avoided a vast artificial hole somebody had been digging on the slope, the

label: l>Line
line: purpose of which I found it impossible to divine. It wasn’t a quarry or a

label: l>Line
line: sandpit, anyhow. It was just a hole. It might have been connected with the

label: l>Line
line: philanthropic desire of giving the criminals something to do. I don’t know. Then

label: l>Line
line: I nearly fell into a very narrow ravine, almost no more than a scar in the

label: l>Line
line: hillside. I discovered that a lot of imported drainage-pipes for the settlement

label: l>Line
line: had been tumbled in there. There wasn’t one that was not broken. It was a wanton

label: l>Line
line: smash-up. At last I got under the trees. My purpose was to stroll into the shade

label: l>Line
line: for a moment; but no sooner within than it seemed to me I had stepped into the

label: l>Line
line: gloomy circle of some Inferno.  The rapids were near, and an uninterrupted,

label: l>Line
line: uniform, headlong, rushing noise filled the mournful stillness of the grove,

label: l>Line
line: where not a breath stirred, not a leaf moved, with a mysterious sound—as though

label: ll>Last Line
line: the tearing pace of the launched earth had suddenly become audible.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Black shapes crouched, lay, sat between the trees leaning against the trunks,

label: l>Line
line: clinging to the earth, half coming out, half effaced within the dim light, in

label: l>Line
line: all the attitudes of pain, abandonment, and despair. Another mine on the cliff

label: l>Line
line: went off, followed by a slight shudder of the soil under my feet. The work was

label: l>Line
line: going on. The work! And this was the place where some of the helpers had

label: ll>Last Line
line: withdrawn to die.

label: fl>First Line
line: “They were dying slowly—it was very clear. They were not enemies, they were not

label: l>Line
line: criminals, they were nothing earthly now—nothing but black shadows of disease

label: l>Line
line: and starvation, lying confusedly in the greenish gloom. Brought from all the

label: l>Line
line: recesses of the coast in all the legality of time contracts, lost in uncongenial

label: l>Line
line: surroundings, fed on unfamiliar food, they sickened, became inefficient, and

label: l>Line
line: were then allowed to crawl away and rest. These moribund shapes were free as

label: l>Line
line: air—and nearly as thin. I began to distinguish the gleam of the eyes under the

label: l>Line
line: trees. Then, glancing down, I saw a face near my hand. The black bones reclined

label: l>Line
line: at full length with one shoulder against the tree, and slowly the eyelids rose

label: l>Line
line: and the sunken eyes looked up at me, enormous and vacant, a kind of blind, white

label: l>Line
line: flicker in the depths of the orbs, which died out slowly. The man seemed

label: l>Line
line: young—almost a boy—but you know with them it’s hard to tell. I found nothing

label: l>Line
line: else to do but to offer him one of my good Swede’s ship’s biscuits I had in my

label: l>Line
line: pocket. The fingers closed slowly on it and held—there was no other movement and

label: l>Line
line: no other glance. He had tied a bit of white worsted round his neck—Why? Where

label: l>Line
line: did he get it? Was it a badge—an ornament—a charm—a propitiatory act? Was there

label: l>Line
line: any idea at all connected with it? It looked startling round his black neck,

label: ll>Last Line
line: this bit of white thread from beyond the seas.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Near the same tree two more bundles of acute angles sat with their legs drawn

label: l>Line
line: up. One, with his chin propped on his knees, stared at nothing, in an

label: l>Line
line: intolerable and appalling manner: his brother phantom rested its forehead, as if

label: l>Line
line: overcome with a great weariness; and all about others were scattered in every

label: l>Line
line: pose of contorted collapse, as in some picture of a massacre or a pestilence.

label: l>Line
line: While I stood horror-struck, one of these creatures rose to his hands and knees,

label: l>Line
line: and went off on all-fours towards the river to drink.  He lapped out of his

label: l>Line
line: hand, then sat up in the sunlight, crossing his shins in front of him, and after

label: ll>Last Line
line: a time let his woolly head fall on his breastbone.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I didn’t want any more loitering in the shade, and I made haste towards the

label: l>Line
line: station. When near the buildings I met a white man, in such an unexpected

label: l>Line
line: elegance of get-up that in the first moment I took him for a sort of vision. I

label: l>Line
line: saw a high starched collar, white cuffs, a light alpaca jacket, snowy trousers,

label: l>Line
line: a clean necktie, and varnished boots. No hat. Hair parted, brushed, oiled, under

label: l>Line
line: a green-lined parasol held in a big white hand. He was amazing, and had a

label: ll>Last Line
line: penholder behind his ear.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I shook hands with this miracle, and I learned he was the Company’s chief

label: l>Line
line: accountant, and that all the book-keeping was done at this station. He had come

label: l>Line
line: out for a moment, he said, ‘to get a breath of fresh air. The expression sounded

label: l>Line
line: wonderfully odd, with its suggestion of sedentary desk-life. I wouldn’t have

label: l>Line
line: mentioned the fellow to you at all, only it was from his lips that I first heard

label: l>Line
line: the name of the man who is so indissolubly connected with the memories of that

label: l>Line
line: time. Moreover, I respected the fellow. Yes; I respected his collars, his vast

label: l>Line
line: cuffs, his brushed hair. His appearance was certainly that of a hairdresser’s

label: l>Line
line: dummy; but in the great demoralization of the land he kept up his appearance.

label: l>Line
line: That’s backbone. His starched collars and got-up shirt-fronts were achievements

label: l>Line
line: of character. He had been out nearly three years; and, later, I could not help

label: l>Line
line: asking him how he managed to sport such linen. He had just the faintest blush,

label: l>Line
line: and said modestly, ’I’ve been teaching one of the native women about the

label: l>Line
line: station. It was difficult. She had a distaste for the work.’ Thus this man had

label: l>Line
line: verily accomplished something. And he was devoted to his books, which were in

label: ll>Last Line
line: apple-pie order.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Everything else in the station was in a muddle—heads, things, buildings.

label: l>Line
line: Strings of dusty niggers with splay feet arrived and departed; a stream of

label: l>Line
line: manufactured goods, rubbishy cottons, beads, and brass-wire sent into the depths

label: ll>Last Line
line: of darkness, and in return came a precious trickle of ivory.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had to wait in the station for ten days—an eternity. I lived in a hut in the

label: l>Line
line: yard, but to be out of the chaos I would sometimes get into the accountant’s

label: l>Line
line: office. It was built of horizontal planks, and so badly put together that, as he

label: l>Line
line: bent over his high desk, he was barred from neck to heels with narrow strips of

label: l>Line
line: sunlight. There was no need to open the big shutter to see. It was hot there,

label: l>Line
line: too; big flies buzzed fiendishly, and did not sting, but stabbed. I sat

label: l>Line
line: generally on the floor, while, of faultless appearance (and even slightly

label: l>Line
line: scented), perching on a high stool, he wrote, he wrote. Sometimes he stood up

label: l>Line
line: for exercise. When a truckle-bed with a sick man (some invalid agent from

label: l>Line
line: upcountry) was put in there, he exhibited a gentle annoyance. ‘The groans of

label: l>Line
line: this sick person,’ he said, ‘distract my attention. And without that it is

label: ll>Last Line
line: extremely difficult to guard against clerical errors in this climate.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “One day he remarked, without lifting his head, ‘In the interior you will no

label: l>Line
line: doubt meet Mr. Kurtz.’ On my asking who Mr. Kurtz was, he said he was a

label: l>Line
line: first-class agent; and seeing my disappointment at this information, he added

label: l>Line
line: slowly, laying down his pen, ‘He is a very remarkable person.’ Further questions

label: l>Line
line: elicited from him that Mr. Kurtz was at present in charge of a trading-post, a

label: l>Line
line: very important one, in the true ivory-country, at ‘the very bottom of there.

label: l>Line
line: Sends in as much ivory as all the others put together...’ He began to write

label: ll>Last Line
line: again. The sick man was too ill to groan.  The flies buzzed in a great peace.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Suddenly there was a growing murmur of voices and a great tramping of feet. A

label: l>Line
line: caravan had come in. A violent babble of uncouth sounds burst out on the other

label: l>Line
line: side of the planks. All the carriers were speaking together, and in the midst of

label: l>Line
line: the uproar the lamentable voice of the chief agent was heard ‘giving it up’

label: l>Line
line: tearfully for the twentieth time that day.... He rose slowly. ‘What a frightful

label: l>Line
line: row,’ he said. He crossed the room gently to look at the sick man, and

label: l>Line
line: returning, said to me, ‘He does not hear.’ ‘What!  Dead?’ I asked, startled.

label: l>Line
line: ‘No, not yet,’ he answered, with great composure.  Then, alluding with a toss of

label: l>Line
line: the head to the tumult in the station-yard, ‘When one has got to make correct

label: l>Line
line: entries, one comes to hate those savages—hate them to the death.’ He remained

label: l>Line
line: thoughtful for a moment. ‘When you see Mr. Kurtz’ he went on, ‘tell him from me

label: l>Line
line: that everything here’—he glanced at the deck—’ is very satisfactory. I don’t

label: l>Line
line: like to write to him—with those messengers of ours you never know who may get

label: l>Line
line: hold of your letter—at that Central Station.’ He stared at me for a moment with

label: l>Line
line: his mild, bulging eyes. ‘Oh, he will go far, very far,’ he began again. ‘He will

label: l>Line
line: be a somebody in the Administration before long. They, above—the Council in

label: ll>Last Line
line: Europe, you know—mean him to be.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “He turned to his work. The noise outside had ceased, and presently in going out

label: l>Line
line: I stopped at the door. In the steady buzz of flies the homeward-bound agent was

label: l>Line
line: lying finished and insensible; the other, bent over his books, was making

label: l>Line
line: correct entries of perfectly correct transactions; and fifty feet below the

label: ll>Last Line
line: doorstep I could see the still tree-tops of the grove of death.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Next day I left that station at last, with a caravan of sixty men, for a

label: ll>Last Line
line: two-hundred-mile tramp.

label: fl>First Line
line: “No use telling you much about that. Paths, paths, everywhere; a stamped-in

label: l>Line
line: network of paths spreading over the empty land, through the long grass, through

label: l>Line
line: burnt grass, through thickets, down and up chilly ravines, up and down stony

label: l>Line
line: hills ablaze with heat; and a solitude, a solitude, nobody, not a hut. The

label: l>Line
line: population had cleared out a long time ago. Well, if a lot of mysterious niggers

label: l>Line
line: armed with all kinds of fearful weapons suddenly took to travelling on the road

label: l>Line
line: between Deal and Gravesend, catching the yokels right and left to carry heavy

label: l>Line
line: loads for them, I fancy every farm and cottage thereabouts would get empty very

label: l>Line
line: soon. Only here the dwellings were gone, too. Still I passed through several

label: l>Line
line: abandoned villages. There’s something pathetically childish in the ruins of

label: l>Line
line: grass walls. Day after day, with the stamp and shuffle of sixty pair of bare

label: l>Line
line: feet behind me, each pair under a 60-lb. load. Camp, cook, sleep, strike camp,

label: l>Line
line: march. Now and then a carrier dead in harness, at rest in the long grass near

label: l>Line
line: the path, with an empty water-gourd and his long staff lying by his side. A

label: l>Line
line: great silence around and above. Perhaps on some quiet night the tremor of

label: l>Line
line: far-off drums, sinking, swelling, a tremor vast, faint; a sound weird,

label: l>Line
line: appealing, suggestive, and wild—and perhaps with as profound a meaning as the

label: l>Line
line: sound of bells in a Christian country. Once a white man in an unbuttoned

label: l>Line
line: uniform, camping on the path with an armed escort of lank Zanzibaris, very

label: l>Line
line: hospitable and festive—not to say drunk. Was looking after the upkeep of the

label: l>Line
line: road, he declared. Can’t say I saw any road or any upkeep, unless the body of a

label: l>Line
line: middle-aged negro, with a bullet-hole in the forehead, upon which I absolutely

label: l>Line
line: stumbled three miles farther on, may be considered as a permanent improvement. I

label: l>Line
line: had a white companion, too, not a bad chap, but rather too fleshy and with the

label: l>Line
line: exasperating habit of fainting on the hot hillsides, miles away from the least

label: l>Line
line: bit of shade and water. Annoying, you know, to hold your own coat like a parasol

label: l>Line
line: over a man’s head while he is coming to. I couldn’t help asking him once what he

label: l>Line
line: meant by coming there at all. ‘To make money, of course. What do you think?’ he

label: l>Line
line: said, scornfully.  Then he got fever, and had to be carried in a hammock slung

label: l>Line
line: under a pole.  As he weighed sixteen stone I had no end of rows with the

label: l>Line
line: carriers. They jibbed, ran away, sneaked off with their loads in the night—quite

label: l>Line
line: a mutiny.  So, one evening, I made a speech in English with gestures, not one of

label: l>Line
line: which was lost to the sixty pairs of eyes before me, and the next morning I

label: l>Line
line: started the hammock off in front all right. An hour afterwards I came upon the

label: l>Line
line: whole concern wrecked in a bush—man, hammock, groans, blankets, horrors. The

label: l>Line
line: heavy pole had skinned his poor nose. He was very anxious for me to kill

label: l>Line
line: somebody, but there wasn’t the shadow of a carrier near.  I remembered the old

label: l>Line
line: doctor—‘It would be interesting for science to watch the mental changes of

label: l>Line
line: individuals, on the spot.’ I felt I was becoming scientifically interesting.

label: l>Line
line: However, all that is to no purpose. On the fifteenth day I came in sight of the

label: l>Line
line: big river again, and hobbled into the Central Station. It was on a back water

label: l>Line
line: surrounded by scrub and forest, with a pretty border of smelly mud on one side,

label: l>Line
line: and on the three others enclosed by a crazy fence of rushes. A neglected gap was

label: l>Line
line: all the gate it had, and the first glance at the place was enough to let you see

label: l>Line
line: the flabby devil was running that show. White men with long staves in their

label: l>Line
line: hands appeared languidly from amongst the buildings, strolling up to take a look

label: l>Line
line: at me, and then retired out of sight somewhere. One of them, a stout, excitable

label: l>Line
line: chap with black moustaches, informed me with great volubility and many

label: l>Line
line: digressions, as soon as I told him who I was, that my steamer was at the bottom

label: l>Line
line: of the river. I was thunderstruck. What, how, why? Oh, it was ‘all right.’ The

label: l>Line
line: ‘manager himself’ was there. All quite correct. ‘Everybody had behaved

label: l>Line
line: splendidly! splendidly!’—‘you must,’ he said in agitation, ‘go and see the

label: ll>Last Line
line: general manager at once. He is waiting!’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I did not see the real significance of that wreck at once. I fancy I see it

label: l>Line
line: now, but I am not sure—not at all. Certainly the affair was too stupid—when I

label: l>Line
line: think of it—to be altogether natural. Still... But at the moment it presented

label: l>Line
line: itself simply as a confounded nuisance. The steamer was sunk. They had started

label: l>Line
line: two days before in a sudden hurry up the river with the manager on board, in

label: l>Line
line: charge of some volunteer skipper, and before they had been out three hours they

label: l>Line
line: tore the bottom out of her on stones, and she sank near the south bank. I asked

label: l>Line
line: myself what I was to do there, now my boat was lost. As a matter of fact, I had

label: l>Line
line: plenty to do in fishing my command out of the river. I had to set about it the

label: l>Line
line: very next day. That, and the repairs when I brought the pieces to the station,

label: ll>Last Line
line: took some months.

label: fl>First Line
line: “My first interview with the manager was curious. He did not ask me to sit down

label: l>Line
line: after my twenty-mile walk that morning. He was commonplace in complexion, in

label: l>Line
line: features, in manners, and in voice. He was of middle size and of ordinary build.

label: l>Line
line: His eyes, of the usual blue, were perhaps remarkably cold, and he certainly

label: l>Line
line: could make his glance fall on one as trenchant and heavy as an axe. But even at

label: l>Line
line: these times the rest of his person seemed to disclaim the intention. Otherwise

label: l>Line
line: there was only an indefinable, faint expression of his lips, something

label: l>Line
line: stealthy—a smile—not a smile—I remember it, but I can’t explain. It was

label: l>Line
line: unconscious, this smile was, though just after he had said something it got

label: l>Line
line: intensified for an instant. It came at the end of his speeches like a seal

label: l>Line
line: applied on the words to make the meaning of the commonest phrase appear

label: l>Line
line: absolutely inscrutable. He was a common trader, from his youth up employed in

label: l>Line
line: these parts—nothing more. He was obeyed, yet he inspired neither love nor fear,

label: l>Line
line: nor even respect. He inspired uneasiness. That was it! Uneasiness. Not a

label: l>Line
line: definite mistrust—just uneasiness—nothing more. You have no idea how effective

label: l>Line
line: such a... a...  faculty can be. He had no genius for organizing, for initiative,

label: l>Line
line: or for order even. That was evident in such things as the deplorable state of

label: l>Line
line: the station. He had no learning, and no intelligence. His position had come to

label: l>Line
line: him—why? Perhaps because he was never ill... He had served three terms of three

label: l>Line
line: years out there... Because triumphant health in the general rout of

label: l>Line
line: constitutions is a kind of power in itself. When he went home on leave he rioted

label: l>Line
line: on a large scale—pompously. Jack ashore—with a difference—in externals only.

label: l>Line
line: This one could gather from his casual talk. He originated nothing, he could keep

label: l>Line
line: the routine going—that’s all. But he was great. He was great by this little

label: l>Line
line: thing that it was impossible to tell what could control such a man. He never

label: l>Line
line: gave that secret away. Perhaps there was nothing within him. Such a suspicion

label: l>Line
line: made one pause—for out there there were no external checks. Once when various

label: l>Line
line: tropical diseases had laid low almost every ‘agent’ in the station, he was heard

label: l>Line
line: to say, ‘Men who come out here should have no entrails.’ He sealed the utterance

label: l>Line
line: with that smile of his, as though it had been a door opening into a darkness he

label: l>Line
line: had in his keeping. You fancied you had seen things—but the seal was on. When

label: l>Line
line: annoyed at meal-times by the constant quarrels of the white men about

label: l>Line
line: precedence, he ordered an immense round table to be made, for which a special

label: l>Line
line: house had to be built. This was the station’s mess-room. Where he sat was the

label: l>Line
line: first place—the rest were nowhere. One felt this to be his unalterable

label: l>Line
line: conviction. He was neither civil nor uncivil. He was quiet. He allowed his

label: l>Line
line: ‘boy’—an overfed young negro from the coast—to treat the white men, under his

label: ll>Last Line
line: very eyes, with provoking insolence.

label: fl>First Line
line: “He began to speak as soon as he saw me. I had been very long on the road.  He

label: l>Line
line: could not wait. Had to start without me. The up-river stations had to be

label: l>Line
line: relieved. There had been so many delays already that he did not know who was

label: l>Line
line: dead and who was alive, and how they got on—and so on, and so on. He paid no

label: l>Line
line: attention to my explanations, and, playing with a stick of sealing-wax, repeated

label: l>Line
line: several times that the situation was ’very grave, very grave.’ There were

label: l>Line
line: rumours that a very important station was in jeopardy, and its chief, Mr. Kurtz,

label: l>Line
line: was ill. Hoped it was not true. Mr.  Kurtz was... I felt weary and irritable.

label: l>Line
line: Hang Kurtz, I thought.  I interrupted him by saying I had heard of Mr. Kurtz on

label: l>Line
line: the coast. ‘Ah! So they talk of him down there,’ he murmured to himself. Then he

label: l>Line
line: began again, assuring me Mr. Kurtz was the best agent he had, an exceptional

label: l>Line
line: man, of the greatest importance to the Company; therefore I could understand his

label: l>Line
line: anxiety. He was, he said, ‘very, very uneasy.’ Certainly he fidgeted on his

label: l>Line
line: chair a good deal, exclaimed, ‘Ah, Mr. Kurtz!’ broke the stick of sealing-wax

label: l>Line
line: and seemed dumfounded by the accident. Next thing he wanted to know ‘how long it

label: l>Line
line: would take to’... I interrupted him again. Being hungry, you know, and kept on

label: l>Line
line: my feet too. I was getting savage. ‘How can I tell?’ I said. ‘I haven’t even

label: l>Line
line: seen the wreck yet—some months, no doubt.’ All this talk seemed to me so futile.

label: l>Line
line: ‘Some months,’ he said. ‘Well, let us say three months before we can make a

label: l>Line
line: start. Yes. That ought to do the affair.’ I flung out of his hut (he lived all

label: l>Line
line: alone in a clay hut with a sort of verandah) muttering to myself my opinion of

label: l>Line
line: him. He was a chattering idiot.  Afterwards I took it back when it was borne in

label: l>Line
line: upon me startlingly with what extreme nicety he had estimated the time requisite

label: ll>Last Line
line: for the ’affair.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I went to work the next day, turning, so to speak, my back on that station. In

label: l>Line
line: that way only it seemed to me I could keep my hold on the redeeming facts of

label: l>Line
line: life. Still, one must look about sometimes; and then I saw this station, these

label: l>Line
line: men strolling aimlessly about in the sunshine of the yard. I asked myself

label: l>Line
line: sometimes what it all meant. They wandered here and there with their absurd long

label: l>Line
line: staves in their hands, like a lot of faithless pilgrims bewitched inside a

label: l>Line
line: rotten fence. The word ‘ivory’ rang in the air, was whispered, was sighed. You

label: l>Line
line: would think they were praying to it. A taint of imbecile rapacity blew through

label: l>Line
line: it all, like a whiff from some corpse. By Jove! I’ve never seen anything so

label: l>Line
line: unreal in my life. And outside, the silent wilderness surrounding this cleared

label: l>Line
line: speck on the earth struck me as something great and invincible, like evil or

label: ll>Last Line
line: truth, waiting patiently for the passing away of this fantastic invasion.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Oh, these months! Well, never mind. Various things happened. One evening a

label: l>Line
line: grass shed full of calico, cotton prints, beads, and I don’t know what else,

label: l>Line
line: burst into a blaze so suddenly that you would have thought the earth had opened

label: l>Line
line: to let an avenging fire consume all that trash. I was smoking my pipe quietly by

label: l>Line
line: my dismantled steamer, and saw them all cutting capers in the light, with their

label: l>Line
line: arms lifted high, when the stout man with moustaches came tearing down to the

label: l>Line
line: river, a tin pail in his hand, assured me that everybody was ‘behaving

label: l>Line
line: splendidly, splendidly,’ dipped about a quart of water and tore back again. I

label: ll>Last Line
line: noticed there was a hole in the bottom of his pail.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I strolled up. There was no hurry. You see the thing had gone off like a box of

label: l>Line
line: matches. It had been hopeless from the very first. The flame had leaped high,

label: l>Line
line: driven everybody back, lighted up everything—and collapsed.  The shed was

label: l>Line
line: already a heap of embers glowing fiercely. A nigger was being beaten near by.

label: l>Line
line: They said he had caused the fire in some way; be that as it may, he was

label: l>Line
line: screeching most horribly. I saw him, later, for several days, sitting in a bit

label: l>Line
line: of shade looking very sick and trying to recover himself; afterwards he arose

label: l>Line
line: and went out—and the wilderness without a sound took him into its bosom again.

label: l>Line
line: As I approached the glow from the dark I found myself at the back of two men,

label: l>Line
line: talking. I heard the name of Kurtz pronounced, then the words, ‘take advantage

label: l>Line
line: of this unfortunate accident.’ One of the men was the manager. I wished him a

label: l>Line
line: good evening. ‘Did you ever see anything like it—eh? it is incredible,’ he said,

label: l>Line
line: and walked off. The other man remained. He was a first-class agent, young,

label: l>Line
line: gentlemanly, a bit reserved, with a forked little beard and a hooked nose. He

label: l>Line
line: was stand-offish with the other agents, and they on their side said he was the

label: l>Line
line: manager’s spy upon them. As to me, I had hardly ever spoken to him before. We

label: l>Line
line: got into talk, and by and by we strolled away from the hissing ruins. Then he

label: l>Line
line: asked me to his room, which was in the main building of the station. He struck a

label: l>Line
line: match, and I perceived that this young aristocrat had not only a silver-mounted

label: l>Line
line: dressing-case but also a whole candle all to himself.  Just at that time the

label: l>Line
line: manager was the only man supposed to have any right to candles. Native mats

label: l>Line
line: covered the clay walls; a collection of spears, assegais, shields, knives was

label: l>Line
line: hung up in trophies. The business intrusted to this fellow was the making of

label: l>Line
line: bricks—so I had been informed; but there wasn’t a fragment of a brick anywhere

label: l>Line
line: in the station, and he had been there more than a year—waiting. It seems he

label: l>Line
line: could not make bricks without something, I don’t know what—straw maybe. Anyway,

label: l>Line
line: it could not be found there and as it was not likely to be sent from Europe, it

label: l>Line
line: did not appear clear to me what he was waiting for. An act of special creation

label: l>Line
line: perhaps.  However, they were all waiting—all the sixteen or twenty pilgrims of

label: l>Line
line: them—for something; and upon my word it did not seem an uncongenial occupation,

label: l>Line
line: from the way they took it, though the only thing that ever came to them was

label: l>Line
line: disease—as far as I could see. They beguiled the time by back-biting and

label: l>Line
line: intriguing against each other in a foolish kind of way.  There was an air of

label: l>Line
line: plotting about that station, but nothing came of it, of course. It was as unreal

label: l>Line
line: as everything else—as the philanthropic pretence of the whole concern, as their

label: l>Line
line: talk, as their government, as their show of work. The only real feeling was a

label: l>Line
line: desire to get appointed to a trading-post where ivory was to be had, so that

label: l>Line
line: they could earn percentages. They intrigued and slandered and hated each other

label: l>Line
line: only on that account—but as to effectually lifting a little finger—oh, no. By

label: l>Line
line: heavens! there is something after all in the world allowing one man to steal a

label: l>Line
line: horse while another must not look at a halter. Steal a horse straight out. Very

label: l>Line
line: well. He has done it. Perhaps he can ride. But there is a way of looking at a

label: ll>Last Line
line: halter that would provoke the most charitable of saints into a kick.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had no idea why he wanted to be sociable, but as we chatted in there it

label: l>Line
line: suddenly occurred to me the fellow was trying to get at something—in fact,

label: l>Line
line: pumping me. He alluded constantly to Europe, to the people I was supposed to

label: l>Line
line: know there—putting leading questions as to my acquaintances in the sepulchral

label: l>Line
line: city, and so on. His little eyes glittered like mica discs—with curiosity—though

label: l>Line
line: he tried to keep up a bit of superciliousness. At first I was astonished, but

label: l>Line
line: very soon I became awfully curious to see what he would find out from me. I

label: l>Line
line: couldn’t possibly imagine what I had in me to make it worth his while. It was

label: l>Line
line: very pretty to see how he baffled himself, for in truth my body was full only of

label: l>Line
line: chills, and my head had nothing in it but that wretched steamboat business. It

label: l>Line
line: was evident he took me for a perfectly shameless prevaricator. At last he got

label: l>Line
line: angry, and, to conceal a movement of furious annoyance, he yawned. I rose. Then

label: l>Line
line: I noticed a small sketch in oils, on a panel, representing a woman, draped and

label: l>Line
line: blindfolded, carrying a lighted torch. The background was sombre—almost black.

label: l>Line
line: The movement of the woman was stately, and the effect of the torchlight on the

label: ll>Last Line
line: face was sinister.

label: fl>First Line
line: “It arrested me, and he stood by civilly, holding an empty half-pint champagne

label: l>Line
line: bottle (medical comforts) with the candle stuck in it. To my question he said

label: l>Line
line: Mr. Kurtz had painted this—in this very station more than a year ago—while

label: l>Line
line: waiting for means to go to his trading post. ’Tell me, pray,’ said I, ‘who is

label: ll>Last Line
line: this Mr. Kurtz?’

label: fl>First Line
