line: “‘The chief of the Inner Station,’ he answered in a short tone, looking away.

label: l>Line
line: ‘Much obliged,’ I said, laughing. ‘And you are the brickmaker of the Central

label: l>Line
line: Station. Every one knows that.’ He was silent for a while. ’He is a prodigy,’ he

label: l>Line
line: said at last. ‘He is an emissary of pity and science and progress, and devil

label: l>Line
line: knows what else. We want,’ he began to declaim suddenly, ‘for the guidance of

label: l>Line
line: the cause intrusted to us by Europe, so to speak, higher intelligence, wide

label: l>Line
line: sympathies, a singleness of purpose.’ ‘Who says that?’ I asked. ‘Lots of them,’

label: l>Line
line: he replied. ‘Some even write that; and so _he_ comes here, a special being, as

label: l>Line
line: you ought to know.’ ‘Why ought I to know?’ I interrupted, really surprised. He

label: l>Line
line: paid no attention. ‘Yes. Today he is chief of the best station, next year he

label: l>Line
line: will be assistant-manager, two years more and... but I dare-say you know what he

label: l>Line
line: will be in two years’ time. You are of the new gang—the gang of virtue. The same

label: l>Line
line: people who sent him specially also recommended you. Oh, don’t say no. I’ve my

label: l>Line
line: own eyes to trust.’ Light dawned upon me. My dear aunt’s influential

label: l>Line
line: acquaintances were producing an unexpected effect upon that young man. I nearly

label: l>Line
line: burst into a laugh. ‘Do you read the Company’s confidential correspondence?’ I

label: l>Line
line: asked. He hadn’t a word to say. It was great fun. ‘When Mr. Kurtz,’ I continued,

label: ll>Last Line
line: severely, ‘is General Manager, you won’t have the opportunity.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “He blew the candle out suddenly, and we went outside. The moon had risen.

label: l>Line
line: Black figures strolled about listlessly, pouring water on the glow, whence

label: l>Line
line: proceeded a sound of hissing; steam ascended in the moonlight, the beaten nigger

label: l>Line
line: groaned somewhere. ‘What a row the brute makes!’ said the indefatigable man with

label: l>Line
line: the moustaches, appearing near us. ‘Serve him right.

label: l>Line
line: Transgression—punishment—bang! Pitiless, pitiless. That’s the only way.  This

label: l>Line
line: will prevent all conflagrations for the future. I was just telling the

label: l>Line
line: manager...’ He noticed my companion, and became crestfallen all at once.  ‘Not

label: l>Line
line: in bed yet,’ he said, with a kind of servile heartiness; ‘it’s so natural. Ha!

label: l>Line
line: Danger—agitation.’ He vanished. I went on to the riverside, and the other

label: l>Line
line: followed me. I heard a scathing murmur at my ear, ‘Heap of muffs—go to.’ The

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims could be seen in knots gesticulating, discussing. Several had still

label: l>Line
line: their staves in their hands. I verily believe they took these sticks to bed with

label: l>Line
line: them. Beyond the fence the forest stood up spectrally in the moonlight, and

label: l>Line
line: through that dim stir, through the faint sounds of that lamentable courtyard,

label: l>Line
line: the silence of the land went home to one’s very heart—its mystery, its

label: l>Line
line: greatness, the amazing reality of its concealed life. The hurt nigger moaned

label: l>Line
line: feebly somewhere near by, and then fetched a deep sigh that made me mend my pace

label: l>Line
line: away from there. I felt a hand introducing itself under my arm. ’My dear sir,’

label: l>Line
line: said the fellow, ‘I don’t want to be misunderstood, and especially by you, who

label: l>Line
line: will see Mr.  Kurtz long before I can have that pleasure. I wouldn’t like him to

label: ll>Last Line
line: get a false idea of my disposition....’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I let him run on, this _papier-mache_ Mephistopheles, and it seemed to me that

label: l>Line
line: if I tried I could poke my forefinger through him, and would find nothing inside

label: l>Line
line: but a little loose dirt, maybe. He, don’t you see, had been planning to be

label: l>Line
line: assistant-manager by and by under the present man, and I could see that the

label: l>Line
line: coming of that Kurtz had upset them both not a little.  He talked precipitately,

label: l>Line
line: and I did not try to stop him. I had my shoulders against the wreck of my

label: l>Line
line: steamer, hauled up on the slope like a carcass of some big river animal. The

label: l>Line
line: smell of mud, of primeval mud, by Jove! was in my nostrils, the high stillness

label: l>Line
line: of primeval forest was before my eyes; there were shiny patches on the black

label: l>Line
line: creek. The moon had spread over everything a thin layer of silver—over the rank

label: l>Line
line: grass, over the mud, upon the wall of matted vegetation standing higher than the

label: l>Line
line: wall of a temple, over the great river I could see through a sombre gap

label: l>Line
line: glittering, glittering, as it flowed broadly by without a murmur. All this was

label: l>Line
line: great, expectant, mute, while the man jabbered about himself. I wondered whether

label: l>Line
line: the stillness on the face of the immensity looking at us two were meant as an

label: l>Line
line: appeal or as a menace. What were we who had strayed in here? Could we handle

label: l>Line
line: that dumb thing, or would it handle us? I felt how big, how confoundedly big,

label: l>Line
line: was that thing that couldn’t talk, and perhaps was deaf as well. What was in

label: l>Line
line: there? I could see a little ivory coming out from there, and I had heard Mr.

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz was in there. I had heard enough about it, too—God knows! Yet somehow it

label: l>Line
line: didn’t bring any image with it—no more than if I had been told an angel or a

label: l>Line
line: fiend was in there. I believed it in the same way one of you might believe there

label: l>Line
line: are inhabitants in the planet Mars.  I knew once a Scotch sailmaker who was

label: l>Line
line: certain, dead sure, there were people in Mars. If you asked him for some idea

label: l>Line
line: how they looked and behaved, he would get shy and mutter something about

label: l>Line
line: ‘walking on all-fours.’ If you as much as smiled, he would—though a man of

label: l>Line
line: sixty—offer to fight you. I would not have gone so far as to fight for Kurtz,

label: l>Line
line: but I went for him near enough to a lie. You know I hate, detest, and can’t bear

label: l>Line
line: a lie, not because I am straighter than the rest of us, but simply because it

label: l>Line
line: appalls me. There is a taint of death, a flavour of mortality in lies—which is

label: l>Line
line: exactly what I hate and detest in the world—what I want to forget. It makes me

label: l>Line
line: miserable and sick, like biting something rotten would do. Temperament, I

label: l>Line
line: suppose. Well, I went near enough to it by letting the young fool there believe

label: l>Line
line: anything he liked to imagine as to my influence in Europe. I became in an

label: l>Line
line: instant as much of a pretence as the rest of the bewitched pilgrims. This simply

label: l>Line
line: because I had a notion it somehow would be of help to that Kurtz whom at the

label: l>Line
line: time I did not see—you understand. He was just a word for me. I did not see the

label: l>Line
line: man in the name any more than you do.  Do you see him? Do you see the story? Do

label: l>Line
line: you see anything? It seems to me I am trying to tell you a dream—making a vain

label: l>Line
line: attempt, because no relation of a dream can convey the dream-sensation, that

label: l>Line
line: commingling of absurdity, surprise, and bewilderment in a tremor of struggling

label: l>Line
line: revolt, that notion of being captured by the incredible which is of the very

label: ll>Last Line
line: essence of dreams....”

label: sl>Single Line
line: He was silent for a while.

label: fl>First Line
line: “... No, it is impossible; it is impossible to convey the life-sensation of any

label: l>Line
line: given epoch of one’s existence—that which makes its truth, its meaning—its

label: l>Line
line: subtle and penetrating essence. It is impossible. We live, as we

label: ll>Last Line
line: dream—alone....”

label: sl>Single Line
line: He paused again as if reflecting, then added:

label: fl>First Line
line: “Of course in this you fellows see more than I could then. You see me, whom you

label: ll>Last Line
line: know....”

label: fl>First Line
line: It had become so pitch dark that we listeners could hardly see one another.  For

label: l>Line
line: a long time already he, sitting apart, had been no more to us than a voice.

label: l>Line
line: There was not a word from anybody. The others might have been asleep, but I was

label: l>Line
line: awake. I listened, I listened on the watch for the sentence, for the word, that

label: l>Line
line: would give me the clue to the faint uneasiness inspired by this narrative that

label: ll>Last Line
line: seemed to shape itself without human lips in the heavy night-air of the river.

label: fl>First Line
line: “... Yes—I let him run on,” Marlow began again, “and think what he pleased about

label: l>Line
line: the powers that were behind me. I did! And there was nothing behind me! There

label: l>Line
line: was nothing but that wretched, old, mangled steamboat I was leaning against,

label: l>Line
line: while he talked fluently about ‘the necessity for every man to get on.’ ‘And

label: l>Line
line: when one comes out here, you conceive, it is not to gaze at the moon.’ Mr. Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: was a ‘universal genius,’ but even a genius would find it easier to work with

label: l>Line
line: ‘adequate tools—intelligent men.’ He did not make bricks—why, there was a

label: l>Line
line: physical impossibility in the way—as I was well aware; and if he did secretarial

label: l>Line
line: work for the manager, it was because ‘no sensible man rejects wantonly the

label: l>Line
line: confidence of his superiors.’ Did I see it? I saw it. What more did I want? What

label: l>Line
line: I really wanted was rivets, by heaven! Rivets. To get on with the work—to stop

label: l>Line
line: the hole. Rivets I wanted. There were cases of them down at the

label: l>Line
line: coast—cases—piled up—burst—split! You kicked a loose rivet at every second step

label: l>Line
line: in that station-yard on the hillside. Rivets had rolled into the grove of death.

label: l>Line
line: You could fill your pockets with rivets for the trouble of stooping down—and

label: l>Line
line: there wasn’t one rivet to be found where it was wanted. We had plates that would

label: l>Line
line: do, but nothing to fasten them with. And every week the messenger, a long negro,

label: l>Line
line: letter-bag on shoulder and staff in hand, left our station for the coast. And

label: l>Line
line: several times a week a coast caravan came in with trade goods—ghastly glazed

label: l>Line
line: calico that made you shudder only to look at it, glass beads value about a penny

label: l>Line
line: a quart, confounded spotted cotton handkerchiefs. And no rivets. Three carriers

label: ll>Last Line
line: could have brought all that was wanted to set that steamboat afloat.

label: fl>First Line
line: “He was becoming confidential now, but I fancy my unresponsive attitude must

label: l>Line
line: have exasperated him at last, for he judged it necessary to inform me he feared

label: l>Line
line: neither God nor devil, let alone any mere man. I said I could see that very

label: l>Line
line: well, but what I wanted was a certain quantity of rivets—and rivets were what

label: l>Line
line: really Mr. Kurtz wanted, if he had only known it. Now letters went to the coast

label: l>Line
line: every week.... ‘My dear sir,’ he cried, ‘I write from dictation.’ I demanded

label: l>Line
line: rivets. There was a way—for an intelligent man.  He changed his manner; became

label: l>Line
line: very cold, and suddenly began to talk about a hippopotamus; wondered whether

label: l>Line
line: sleeping on board the steamer (I stuck to my salvage night and day) I wasn’t

label: l>Line
line: disturbed. There was an old hippo that had the bad habit of getting out on the

label: l>Line
line: bank and roaming at night over the station grounds. The pilgrims used to turn

label: l>Line
line: out in a body and empty every rifle they could lay hands on at him. Some even

label: l>Line
line: had sat up o’ nights for him. All this energy was wasted, though. ‘That animal

label: l>Line
line: has a charmed life,’ he said; ’but you can say this only of brutes in this

label: l>Line
line: country. No man—you apprehend me?—no man here bears a charmed life.’ He stood

label: l>Line
line: there for a moment in the moonlight with his delicate hooked nose set a little

label: l>Line
line: askew, and his mica eyes glittering without a wink, then, with a curt

label: l>Line
line: Good-night, he strode off. I could see he was disturbed and considerably

label: l>Line
line: puzzled, which made me feel more hopeful than I had been for days. It was a

label: l>Line
line: great comfort to turn from that chap to my influential friend, the battered,

label: l>Line
line: twisted, ruined, tin-pot steamboat. I clambered on board. She rang under my feet

label: l>Line
line: like an empty Huntley & Palmer biscuit-tin kicked along a gutter; she was

label: l>Line
line: nothing so solid in make, and rather less pretty in shape, but I had expended

label: l>Line
line: enough hard work on her to make me love her. No influential friend would have

label: l>Line
line: served me better. She had given me a chance to come out a bit—to find out what I

label: l>Line
line: could do. No, I don’t like work. I had rather laze about and think of all the

label: l>Line
line: fine things that can be done. I don’t like work—no man does—but I like what is

label: l>Line
line: in the work—the chance to find yourself. Your own reality—for yourself, not for

label: l>Line
line: others—what no other man can ever know. They can only see the mere show, and

label: ll>Last Line
line: never can tell what it really means.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I was not surprised to see somebody sitting aft, on the deck, with his legs

label: l>Line
line: dangling over the mud. You see I rather chummed with the few mechanics there

label: l>Line
line: were in that station, whom the other pilgrims naturally despised—on account of

label: l>Line
line: their imperfect manners, I suppose. This was the foreman—a boiler-maker by

label: l>Line
line: trade—a good worker. He was a lank, bony, yellow-faced man, with big intense

label: l>Line
line: eyes. His aspect was worried, and his head was as bald as the palm of my hand;

label: l>Line
line: but his hair in falling seemed to have stuck to his chin, and had prospered in

label: l>Line
line: the new locality, for his beard hung down to his waist. He was a widower with

label: l>Line
line: six young children (he had left them in charge of a sister of his to come out

label: l>Line
line: there), and the passion of his life was pigeon-flying. He was an enthusiast and

label: l>Line
line: a connoisseur. He would rave about pigeons. After work hours he used sometimes

label: l>Line
line: to come over from his hut for a talk about his children and his pigeons; at

label: l>Line
line: work, when he had to crawl in the mud under the bottom of the steamboat, he

label: l>Line
line: would tie up that beard of his in a kind of white serviette he brought for the

label: l>Line
line: purpose. It had loops to go over his ears. In the evening he could be seen

label: l>Line
line: squatted on the bank rinsing that wrapper in the creek with great care, then

label: ll>Last Line
line: spreading it solemnly on a bush to dry.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I slapped him on the back and shouted, ‘We shall have rivets!’ He scrambled to

label: l>Line
line: his feet exclaiming, ‘No! Rivets!’ as though he couldn’t believe his ears. Then

label: l>Line
line: in a low voice, ‘You... eh?’ I don’t know why we behaved like lunatics. I put my

label: l>Line
line: finger to the side of my nose and nodded mysteriously. ‘Good for you!’ he cried,

label: l>Line
line: snapped his fingers above his head, lifting one foot. I tried a jig. We capered

label: l>Line
line: on the iron deck. A frightful clatter came out of that hulk, and the virgin

label: l>Line
line: forest on the other bank of the creek sent it back in a thundering roll upon the

label: l>Line
line: sleeping station. It must have made some of the pilgrims sit up in their hovels.

label: l>Line
line: A dark figure obscured the lighted doorway of the manager’s hut, vanished, then,

label: l>Line
line: a second or so after, the doorway itself vanished, too. We stopped, and the

label: l>Line
line: silence driven away by the stamping of our feet flowed back again from the

label: l>Line
line: recesses of the land. The great wall of vegetation, an exuberant and entangled

label: l>Line
line: mass of trunks, branches, leaves, boughs, festoons, motionless in the moonlight,

label: l>Line
line: was like a rioting invasion of soundless life, a rolling wave of plants, piled

label: l>Line
line: up, crested, ready to topple over the creek, to sweep every little man of us out

label: l>Line
line: of his little existence. And it moved not. A deadened burst of mighty splashes

label: l>Line
line: and snorts reached us from afar, as though an icthyosaurus had been taking a

label: l>Line
line: bath of glitter in the great river. ‘After all,’ said the boiler-maker in a

label: l>Line
line: reasonable tone, ‘why shouldn’t we get the rivets?’ Why not, indeed! I did not

label: l>Line
line: know of any reason why we shouldn’t.  ‘They’ll come in three weeks,’ I said

label: ll>Last Line
line: confidently.

label: fl>First Line
line: “But they didn’t. Instead of rivets there came an invasion, an infliction, a

label: l>Line
line: visitation. It came in sections during the next three weeks, each section headed

label: l>Line
line: by a donkey carrying a white man in new clothes and tan shoes, bowing from that

label: l>Line
line: elevation right and left to the impressed pilgrims.  A quarrelsome band of

label: l>Line
line: footsore sulky niggers trod on the heels of the donkey; a lot of tents,

label: l>Line
line: camp-stools, tin boxes, white cases, brown bales would be shot down in the

label: l>Line
line: courtyard, and the air of mystery would deepen a little over the muddle of the

label: l>Line
line: station. Five such instalments came, with their absurd air of disorderly flight

label: l>Line
line: with the loot of innumerable outfit shops and provision stores, that, one would

label: l>Line
line: think, they were lugging, after a raid, into the wilderness for equitable

label: l>Line
line: division. It was an inextricable mess of things decent in themselves but that

label: ll>Last Line
line: human folly made look like the spoils of thieving.

label: fl>First Line
line: “This devoted band called itself the Eldorado Exploring Expedition, and I

label: l>Line
line: believe they were sworn to secrecy. Their talk, however, was the talk of sordid

label: l>Line
line: buccaneers: it was reckless without hardihood, greedy without audacity, and

label: l>Line
line: cruel without courage; there was not an atom of foresight or of serious

label: l>Line
line: intention in the whole batch of them, and they did not seem aware these things

label: l>Line
line: are wanted for the work of the world. To tear treasure out of the bowels of the

label: l>Line
line: land was their desire, with no more moral purpose at the back of it than there

label: l>Line
line: is in burglars breaking into a safe. Who paid the expenses of the noble

label: ll>Last Line
line: enterprise I don’t know; but the uncle of our manager was leader of that lot.

label: fl>First Line
line: “In exterior he resembled a butcher in a poor neighbourhood, and his eyes had a

label: l>Line
line: look of sleepy cunning. He carried his fat paunch with ostentation on his short

label: l>Line
line: legs, and during the time his gang infested the station spoke to no one but his

label: l>Line
line: nephew. You could see these two roaming about all day long with their heads

label: ll>Last Line
line: close together in an everlasting confab.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had given up worrying myself about the rivets. One’s capacity for that kind

label: l>Line
line: of folly is more limited than you would suppose. I said Hang!—and let things

label: l>Line
line: slide. I had plenty of time for meditation, and now and then I would give some

label: l>Line
line: thought to Kurtz. I wasn’t very interested in him. No. Still, I was curious to

label: l>Line
line: see whether this man, who had come out equipped with moral ideas of some sort,

label: l>Line
line: would climb to the top after all and how he would set about his work when

label: ll>Last Line
line: there.”

label: lvl1>Chapter
line: II

label: fl>First Line
line: “One evening as I was lying flat on the deck of my steamboat, I heard voices

label: l>Line
line: approaching—and there were the nephew and the uncle strolling along the bank. I

label: l>Line
line: laid my head on my arm again, and had nearly lost myself in a doze, when

label: l>Line
line: somebody said in my ear, as it were: ‘I am as harmless as a little child, but I

label: l>Line
line: don’t like to be dictated to. Am I the manager—or am I not? I was ordered to

label: l>Line
line: send him there. It’s incredible.’ ... I became aware that the two were standing

label: l>Line
line: on the shore alongside the forepart of the steamboat, just below my head. I did

label: l>Line
line: not move; it did not occur to me to move: I was sleepy. ‘It _is_ unpleasant,’

label: l>Line
line: grunted the uncle. ‘He has asked the Administration to be sent there,’ said the

label: l>Line
line: other, ‘with the idea of showing what he could do; and I was instructed

label: l>Line
line: accordingly. Look at the influence that man must have. Is it not frightful?’

label: l>Line
line: They both agreed it was frightful, then made several bizarre remarks: ‘Make rain

label: l>Line
line: and fine weather—one man—the Council—by the nose’—bits of absurd sentences that

label: l>Line
line: got the better of my drowsiness, so that I had pretty near the whole of my wits

label: l>Line
line: about me when the uncle said, ‘The climate may do away with this difficulty for

label: l>Line
line: you. Is he alone there?’ ‘Yes,’ answered the manager; ‘he sent his assistant

label: l>Line
line: down the river with a note to me in these terms: ”Clear this poor devil out of

label: l>Line
line: the country, and don’t bother sending more of that sort. I had rather be alone

label: l>Line
line: than have the kind of men you can dispose of with me.“ It was more than a year

label: l>Line
line: ago. Can you imagine such impudence!’ ‘Anything since then?’ asked the other

label: l>Line
line: hoarsely. ‘Ivory,’ jerked the nephew; ‘lots of it—prime sort—lots—most annoying,

label: l>Line
line: from him.’ ‘And with that?’ questioned the heavy rumble. ‘Invoice,’ was the

label: ll>Last Line
line: reply fired out, so to speak. Then silence. They had been talking about Kurtz.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I was broad awake by this time, but, lying perfectly at ease, remained still,

label: l>Line
line: having no inducement to change my position. ‘How did that ivory come all this

label: l>Line
line: way?’ growled the elder man, who seemed very vexed. The other explained that it

label: l>Line
line: had come with a fleet of canoes in charge of an English half-caste clerk Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: had with him; that Kurtz had apparently intended to return himself, the station

label: l>Line
line: being by that time bare of goods and stores, but after coming three hundred

label: l>Line
line: miles, had suddenly decided to go back, which he started to do alone in a small

label: l>Line
line: dugout with four paddlers, leaving the half-caste to continue down the river

label: l>Line
line: with the ivory. The two fellows there seemed astounded at anybody attempting

label: l>Line
line: such a thing. They were at a loss for an adequate motive. As to me, I seemed to

label: l>Line
line: see Kurtz for the first time. It was a distinct glimpse: the dugout, four

label: l>Line
line: paddling savages, and the lone white man turning his back suddenly on the

label: l>Line
line: headquarters, on relief, on thoughts of home—perhaps; setting his face towards

label: l>Line
line: the depths of the wilderness, towards his empty and desolate station. I did not

label: l>Line
line: know the motive. Perhaps he was just simply a fine fellow who stuck to his work

label: l>Line
line: for its own sake. His name, you understand, had not been pronounced once. He was

label: l>Line
line: ‘that man.’ The half-caste, who, as far as I could see, had conducted a

label: l>Line
line: difficult trip with great prudence and pluck, was invariably alluded to as ‘that

label: l>Line
line: scoundrel.’ The ‘scoundrel’ had reported that the ‘man’ had been very ill—had

label: l>Line
line: recovered imperfectly.... The two below me moved away then a few paces, and

label: l>Line
line: strolled back and forth at some little distance. I heard: ’Military

label: l>Line
line: post—doctor—two hundred miles—quite alone now—unavoidable delays—nine months—no

label: l>Line
line: news—strange rumours.’ They approached again, just as the manager was saying,

label: l>Line
line: ‘No one, as far as I know, unless a species of wandering trader—a pestilential

label: l>Line
line: fellow, snapping ivory from the natives.’ Who was it they were talking about

label: l>Line
line: now? I gathered in snatches that this was some man supposed to be in Kurtz’s

label: l>Line
line: district, and of whom the manager did not approve. ‘We will not be free from

label: l>Line
line: unfair competition till one of these fellows is hanged for an example,’ he said.

label: l>Line
line: ‘Certainly,’ grunted the other; ‘get him hanged! Why not? Anything—anything can

label: l>Line
line: be done in this country. That’s what I say; nobody here, you understand, _here_,

label: l>Line
line: can endanger your position. And why? You stand the climate—you outlast them all.

label: l>Line
line: The danger is in Europe; but there before I left I took care to—’ They moved off

label: l>Line
line: and whispered, then their voices rose again. ‘The extraordinary series of delays

label: l>Line
line: is not my fault. I did my best.’ The fat man sighed. ‘Very sad.’ ‘And the

label: l>Line
line: pestiferous absurdity of his talk,’ continued the other; ‘he bothered me enough

label: l>Line
line: when he was here. ”Each station should be like a beacon on the road towards

label: l>Line
line: better things, a centre for trade of course, but also for humanizing, improving,

label: l>Line
line: instructing.“ Conceive you—that ass! And he wants to be manager! No, it’s—’ Here

label: l>Line
line: he got choked by excessive indignation, and I lifted my head the least bit. I

label: l>Line
line: was surprised to see how near they were—right under me. I could have spat upon

label: l>Line
line: their hats. They were looking on the ground, absorbed in thought. The manager

label: l>Line
line: was switching his leg with a slender twig: his sagacious relative lifted his

label: l>Line
line: head. ‘You have been well since you came out this time?’ he asked. The other

label: l>Line
line: gave a start. ‘Who? I? Oh! Like a charm—like a charm. But the rest—oh, my

label: l>Line
line: goodness! All sick. They die so quick, too, that I haven’t the time to send them

label: l>Line
line: out of the country—it’s incredible!’ ‘Hm’m. Just so,’ grunted the uncle. ‘Ah! my

label: l>Line
line: boy, trust to this—I say, trust to this.’ I saw him extend his short flipper of

label: l>Line
line: an arm for a gesture that took in the forest, the creek, the mud, the

label: l>Line
line: river—seemed to beckon with a dishonouring flourish before the sunlit face of

label: l>Line
line: the land a treacherous appeal to the lurking death, to the hidden evil, to the

label: l>Line
line: profound darkness of its heart. It was so startling that I leaped to my feet and

label: l>Line
line: looked back at the edge of the forest, as though I had expected an answer of

label: l>Line
line: some sort to that black display of confidence. You know the foolish notions that

label: l>Line
line: come to one sometimes. The high stillness confronted these two figures with its

label: ll>Last Line
line: ominous patience, waiting for the passing away of a fantastic invasion.

label: fl>First Line
line: “They swore aloud together—out of sheer fright, I believe—then pretending not to

label: l>Line
line: know anything of my existence, turned back to the station. The sun was low; and

label: l>Line
line: leaning forward side by side, they seemed to be tugging painfully uphill their

label: l>Line
line: two ridiculous shadows of unequal length, that trailed behind them slowly over

label: ll>Last Line
line: the tall grass without bending a single blade.

label: fl>First Line
line: “In a few days the Eldorado Expedition went into the patient wilderness, that

label: l>Line
line: closed upon it as the sea closes over a diver. Long afterwards the news came

label: l>Line
line: that all the donkeys were dead. I know nothing as to the fate of the less

label: l>Line
line: valuable animals. They, no doubt, like the rest of us, found what they deserved.

label: l>Line
line: I did not inquire. I was then rather excited at the prospect of meeting Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: very soon. When I say very soon I mean it comparatively.  It was just two months

label: ll>Last Line
line: from the day we left the creek when we came to the bank below Kurtz’s station.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Going up that river was like traveling back to the earliest beginnings of the

label: l>Line
line: world, when vegetation rioted on the earth and the big trees were kings. An

label: l>Line
line: empty stream, a great silence, an impenetrable forest. The air was warm, thick,

label: l>Line
line: heavy, sluggish. There was no joy in the brilliance of sunshine. The long

label: l>Line
line: stretches of the waterway ran on, deserted, into the gloom of overshadowed

label: l>Line
line: distances. On silvery sand-banks hippos and alligators sunned themselves side by

label: l>Line
line: side. The broadening waters flowed through a mob of wooded islands; you lost

label: l>Line
line: your way on that river as you would in a desert, and butted all day long against

label: l>Line
line: shoals, trying to find the channel, till you thought yourself bewitched and cut

label: l>Line
line: off for ever from everything you had known once—somewhere—far away—in another

label: l>Line
line: existence perhaps. There were moments when one’s past came back to one, as it

label: l>Line
line: will sometimes when you have not a moment to spare for yourself; but it came in

label: l>Line
line: the shape of an unrestful and noisy dream, remembered with wonder amongst the

label: l>Line
line: overwhelming realities of this strange world of plants, and water, and silence.

label: l>Line
line: And this stillness of life did not in the least resemble a peace.  It was the

label: l>Line
line: stillness of an implacable force brooding over an inscrutable intention. It

label: l>Line
line: looked at you with a vengeful aspect. I got used to it afterwards; I did not see

label: l>Line
line: it any more; I had no time. I had to keep guessing at the channel; I had to

label: l>Line
line: discern, mostly by inspiration, the signs of hidden banks; I watched for sunken

label: l>Line
line: stones; I was learning to clap my teeth smartly before my heart flew out, when I

label: l>Line
line: shaved by a fluke some infernal sly old snag that would have ripped the life out

label: l>Line
line: of the tin-pot steamboat and drowned all the pilgrims; I had to keep a lookout

label: l>Line
line: for the signs of dead wood we could cut up in the night for next day’s steaming.

label: l>Line
line: When you have to attend to things of that sort, to the mere incidents of the

label: l>Line
line: surface, the reality—the reality, I tell you—fades. The inner truth is

label: l>Line
line: hidden—luckily, luckily. But I felt it all the same; I felt often its mysterious

label: l>Line
line: stillness watching me at my monkey tricks, just as it watches you fellows

label: l>Line
line: performing on your respective tight-ropes for—what is it?  half-a-crown a

label: ll>Last Line
line: tumble—”

label: fl>First Line
line: “Try to be civil, Marlow,” growled a voice, and I knew there was at least one

label: ll>Last Line
line: listener awake besides myself.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I beg your pardon. I forgot the heartache which makes up the rest of the price.

label: l>Line
line: And indeed what does the price matter, if the trick be well done?  You do your

label: l>Line
line: tricks very well. And I didn’t do badly either, since I managed not to sink that

label: l>Line
line: steamboat on my first trip. It’s a wonder to me yet.  Imagine a blindfolded man

label: l>Line
line: set to drive a van over a bad road. I sweated and shivered over that business

label: l>Line
line: considerably, I can tell you. After all, for a seaman, to scrape the bottom of

label: l>Line
line: the thing that’s supposed to float all the time under his care is the

label: l>Line
line: unpardonable sin. No one may know of it, but you never forget the thump—eh? A

label: l>Line
line: blow on the very heart. You remember it, you dream of it, you wake up at night

label: l>Line
line: and think of it—years after—and go hot and cold all over. I don’t pretend to say

label: l>Line
line: that steamboat floated all the time. More than once she had to wade for a bit,

label: l>Line
line: with twenty cannibals splashing around and pushing. We had enlisted some of

label: l>Line
line: these chaps on the way for a crew. Fine fellows—cannibals—in their place. They

label: l>Line
line: were men one could work with, and I am grateful to them. And, after all, they

label: l>Line
line: did not eat each other before my face: they had brought along a provision of

label: l>Line
line: hippo-meat which went rotten, and made the mystery of the wilderness stink in my

label: l>Line
line: nostrils. Phoo! I can sniff it now. I had the manager on board and three or four

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims with their staves—all complete.  Sometimes we came upon a station close

label: l>Line
line: by the bank, clinging to the skirts of the unknown, and the white men rushing

label: l>Line
line: out of a tumble-down hovel, with great gestures of joy and surprise and welcome,

label: l>Line
line: seemed very strange—had the appearance of being held there captive by a spell.

label: l>Line
line: The word ivory would ring in the air for a while—and on we went again into the

label: l>Line
line: silence, along empty reaches, round the still bends, between the high walls of

label: l>Line
line: our winding way, reverberating in hollow claps the ponderous beat of the

label: l>Line
line: stern-wheel.  Trees, trees, millions of trees, massive, immense, running up

label: l>Line
line: high; and at their foot, hugging the bank against the stream, crept the little

label: l>Line
line: begrimed steamboat, like a sluggish beetle crawling on the floor of a lofty

label: l>Line
line: portico.  It made you feel very small, very lost, and yet it was not altogether

label: l>Line
line: depressing, that feeling. After all, if you were small, the grimy beetle crawled

label: l>Line
line: on—which was just what you wanted it to do. Where the pilgrims imagined it

label: l>Line
line: crawled to I don’t know. To some place where they expected to get something. I

label: l>Line
line: bet! For me it crawled towards Kurtz—exclusively; but when the steam-pipes

label: l>Line
line: started leaking we crawled very slow. The reaches opened before us and closed

label: l>Line
line: behind, as if the forest had stepped leisurely across the water to bar the way

label: l>Line
line: for our return. We penetrated deeper and deeper into the heart of darkness. It

label: l>Line
line: was very quiet there. At night sometimes the roll of drums behind the curtain of

label: l>Line
line: trees would run up the river and remain sustained faintly, as if hovering in the

label: l>Line
line: air high over our heads, till the first break of day. Whether it meant war,

label: l>Line
line: peace, or prayer we could not tell. The dawns were heralded by the descent of a

label: l>Line
line: chill stillness; the wood-cutters slept, their fires burned low; the snapping of

label: l>Line
line: a twig would make you start. We were wanderers on a prehistoric earth, on an

label: l>Line
line: earth that wore the aspect of an unknown planet. We could have fancied ourselves

label: l>Line
line: the first of men taking possession of an accursed inheritance, to be subdued at

label: l>Line
line: the cost of profound anguish and of excessive toil. But suddenly, as we

label: l>Line
line: struggled round a bend, there would be a glimpse of rush walls, of peaked

label: l>Line
line: grass-roofs, a burst of yells, a whirl of black limbs, a mass of hands clapping

label: l>Line
line: of feet stamping, of bodies swaying, of eyes rolling, under the droop of heavy

label: l>Line
line: and motionless foliage. The steamer toiled along slowly on the edge of a black

label: l>Line
line: and incomprehensible frenzy. The prehistoric man was cursing us, praying to us,

label: l>Line
line: welcoming us—who could tell? We were cut off from the comprehension of our

label: l>Line
line: surroundings; we glided past like phantoms, wondering and secretly appalled, as

label: l>Line
line: sane men would be before an enthusiastic outbreak in a madhouse. We could not

label: l>Line
line: understand because we were too far and could not remember because we were

label: l>Line
line: travelling in the night of first ages, of those ages that are gone, leaving

label: ll>Last Line
line: hardly a sign—and no memories.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The earth seemed unearthly. We are accustomed to look upon the shackled form of

label: l>Line
line: a conquered monster, but there—there you could look at a thing monstrous and

label: l>Line
line: free. It was unearthly, and the men were—No, they were not inhuman. Well, you

label: l>Line
line: know, that was the worst of it—this suspicion of their not being inhuman. It

label: l>Line
line: would come slowly to one. They howled and leaped, and spun, and made horrid

label: l>Line
line: faces; but what thrilled you was just the thought of their humanity—like

label: l>Line
line: yours—the thought of your remote kinship with this wild and passionate uproar.

label: l>Line
line: Ugly. Yes, it was ugly enough; but if you were man enough you would admit to

label: l>Line
line: yourself that there was in you just the faintest trace of a response to the

label: l>Line
line: terrible frankness of that noise, a dim suspicion of there being a meaning in it

label: l>Line
line: which you—you so remote from the night of first ages—could comprehend. And why

label: l>Line
line: not? The mind of man is capable of anything—because everything is in it, all the

label: l>Line
line: past as well as all the future. What was there after all? Joy, fear, sorrow,

label: l>Line
line: devotion, valour, rage—who can tell?—but truth—truth stripped of its cloak of

label: l>Line
line: time.  Let the fool gape and shudder—the man knows, and can look on without a

label: l>Line
line: wink. But he must at least be as much of a man as these on the shore. He must

label: l>Line
line: meet that truth with his own true stuff—with his own inborn strength.

label: l>Line
line: Principles won’t do. Acquisitions, clothes, pretty rags—rags that would fly off

label: l>Line
line: at the first good shake. No; you want a deliberate belief. An appeal to me in

label: l>Line
line: this fiendish row—is there? Very well; I hear; I admit, but I have a voice, too,

label: l>Line
line: and for good or evil mine is the speech that cannot be silenced. Of course, a

label: l>Line
line: fool, what with sheer fright and fine sentiments, is always safe. Who’s that

label: l>Line
line: grunting? You wonder I didn’t go ashore for a howl and a dance? Well, no—I

label: l>Line
line: didn’t. Fine sentiments, you say? Fine sentiments, be hanged! I had no time. I

label: l>Line
line: had to mess about with white-lead and strips of woolen blanket helping to put

label: l>Line
line: bandages on those leaky steam-pipes—I tell you. I had to watch the steering, and

label: l>Line
line: circumvent those snags, and get the tin-pot along by hook or by crook. There was

label: l>Line
line: surface-truth enough in these things to save a wiser man. And between whiles I

label: l>Line
line: had to look after the savage who was fireman. He was an improved specimen; he

label: l>Line
line: could fire up a vertical boiler. He was there below me, and, upon my word, to

label: l>Line
line: look at him was as edifying as seeing a dog in a parody of breeches and a

label: l>Line
line: feather hat, walking on his hind-legs. A few months of training had done for

label: l>Line
line: that really fine chap. He squinted at the steam-gauge and at the water-gauge

label: l>Line
line: with an evident effort of intrepidity—and he had filed teeth, too, the poor

label: l>Line
line: devil, and the wool of his pate shaved into queer patterns, and three ornamental

label: l>Line
line: scars on each of his cheeks. He ought to have been clapping his hands and

label: l>Line
line: stamping his feet on the bank, instead of which he was hard at work, a thrall to

label: l>Line
line: strange witchcraft, full of improving knowledge. He was useful because he had

label: l>Line
line: been instructed; and what he knew was this—that should the water in that

label: l>Line
line: transparent thing disappear, the evil spirit inside the boiler would get angry

label: l>Line
line: through the greatness of his thirst, and take a terrible vengeance. So he

label: l>Line
line: sweated and fired up and watched the glass fearfully (with an impromptu charm,

label: l>Line
line: made of rags, tied to his arm, and a piece of polished bone, as big as a watch,

label: l>Line
line: stuck flatways through his lower lip), while the wooded banks slipped past us

label: l>Line
line: slowly, the short noise was left behind, the interminable miles of silence—and

label: l>Line
line: we crept on, towards Kurtz. But the snags were thick, the water was treacherous

label: l>Line
line: and shallow, the boiler seemed indeed to have a sulky devil in it, and thus

label: ll>Last Line
line: neither that fireman nor I had any time to peer into our creepy thoughts.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Some fifty miles below the Inner Station we came upon a hut of reeds, an

label: l>Line
line: inclined and melancholy pole, with the unrecognizable tatters of what had been a

label: l>Line
line: flag of some sort flying from it, and a neatly stacked wood-pile.  This was

label: l>Line
line: unexpected. We came to the bank, and on the stack of firewood found a flat piece

label: l>Line
line: of board with some faded pencil-writing on it. When deciphered it said: ‘Wood

label: l>Line
line: for you. Hurry up. Approach cautiously.’ There was a signature, but it was

label: l>Line
line: illegible—not Kurtz—a much longer word. ‘Hurry up.’ Where? Up the river?

label: l>Line
line: ‘Approach cautiously.’ We had not done so. But the warning could not have been

label: l>Line
line: meant for the place where it could be only found after approach. Something was

label: l>Line
line: wrong above. But what—and how much?  That was the question. We commented

label: l>Line
line: adversely upon the imbecility of that telegraphic style. The bush around said

label: l>Line
line: nothing, and would not let us look very far, either. A torn curtain of red twill

label: l>Line
line: hung in the doorway of the hut, and flapped sadly in our faces. The dwelling was

label: l>Line
line: dismantled; but we could see a white man had lived there not very long ago.

label: l>Line
line: There remained a rude table—a plank on two posts; a heap of rubbish reposed in a

label: l>Line
line: dark corner, and by the door I picked up a book. It had lost its covers, and the

label: l>Line
line: pages had been thumbed into a state of extremely dirty softness; but the back

label: l>Line
line: had been lovingly stitched afresh with white cotton thread, which looked clean

label: l>Line
line: yet. It was an extraordinary find. Its title was, _An Inquiry into some Points

label: l>Line
line: of Seamanship_, by a man Towser, Towson—some such name—Master in his Majesty’s

label: l>Line
line: Navy. The matter looked dreary reading enough, with illustrative diagrams and

label: l>Line
line: repulsive tables of figures, and the copy was sixty years old. I handled this

label: l>Line
line: amazing antiquity with the greatest possible tenderness, lest it should dissolve

label: l>Line
line: in my hands. Within, Towson or Towser was inquiring earnestly into the breaking

label: l>Line
line: strain of ships’ chains and tackle, and other such matters. Not a very

label: l>Line
line: enthralling book; but at the first glance you could see there a singleness of

label: l>Line
line: intention, an honest concern for the right way of going to work, which made

label: l>Line
line: these humble pages, thought out so many years ago, luminous with another than a

label: l>Line
line: professional light. The simple old sailor, with his talk of chains and

label: l>Line
line: purchases, made me forget the jungle and the pilgrims in a delicious sensation

label: l>Line
line: of having come upon something unmistakably real. Such a book being there was

label: l>Line
line: wonderful enough; but still more astounding were the notes pencilled in the

label: l>Line
line: margin, and plainly referring to the text. I couldn’t believe my eyes! They were

label: l>Line
line: in cipher! Yes, it looked like cipher. Fancy a man lugging with him a book of

label: l>Line
line: that description into this nowhere and studying it—and making notes—in cipher at

label: ll>Last Line
line: that! It was an extravagant mystery.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had been dimly aware for some time of a worrying noise, and when I lifted my

label: l>Line
line: eyes I saw the wood-pile was gone, and the manager, aided by all the pilgrims,

label: l>Line
line: was shouting at me from the riverside. I slipped the book into my pocket. I

label: l>Line
line: assure you to leave off reading was like tearing myself away from the shelter of

label: ll>Last Line
line: an old and solid friendship.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I started the lame engine ahead. ‘It must be this miserable trader—this

label: l>Line
line: intruder,’ exclaimed the manager, looking back malevolently at the place we had

label: l>Line
line: left. ‘He must be English,’ I said. ‘It will not save him from getting into

label: l>Line
line: trouble if he is not careful,’ muttered the manager darkly.  I observed with

label: ll>Last Line
line: assumed innocence that no man was safe from trouble in this world.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The current was more rapid now, the steamer seemed at her last gasp, the

label: l>Line
line: stern-wheel flopped languidly, and I caught myself listening on tiptoe for the

label: l>Line
line: next beat of the boat, for in sober truth I expected the wretched thing to give

label: l>Line
line: up every moment. It was like watching the last flickers of a life.  But still we

label: l>Line
line: crawled. Sometimes I would pick out a tree a little way ahead to measure our

label: l>Line
line: progress towards Kurtz by, but I lost it invariably before we got abreast. To

label: l>Line
line: keep the eyes so long on one thing was too much for human patience. The manager

label: l>Line
line: displayed a beautiful resignation. I fretted and fumed and took to arguing with

label: l>Line
line: myself whether or no I would talk openly with Kurtz; but before I could come to

label: l>Line
line: any conclusion it occurred to me that my speech or my silence, indeed any action

label: l>Line
line: of mine, would be a mere futility. What did it matter what any one knew or

label: l>Line
line: ignored? What did it matter who was manager? One gets sometimes such a flash of

label: l>Line
line: insight. The essentials of this affair lay deep under the surface, beyond my

label: ll>Last Line
line: reach, and beyond my power of meddling.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Towards the evening of the second day we judged ourselves about eight miles

label: l>Line
line: from Kurtz’s station. I wanted to push on; but the manager looked grave, and

label: l>Line
line: told me the navigation up there was so dangerous that it would be advisable, the

label: l>Line
line: sun being very low already, to wait where we were till next morning. Moreover,

label: l>Line
line: he pointed out that if the warning to approach cautiously were to be followed,

label: l>Line
line: we must approach in daylight—not at dusk or in the dark. This was sensible

label: l>Line
line: enough. Eight miles meant nearly three hours’ steaming for us, and I could also

label: l>Line
line: see suspicious ripples at the upper end of the reach. Nevertheless, I was

label: l>Line
line: annoyed beyond expression at the delay, and most unreasonably, too, since one

label: l>Line
line: night more could not matter much after so many months. As we had plenty of wood,

label: l>Line
line: and caution was the word, I brought up in the middle of the stream. The reach

label: l>Line
line: was narrow, straight, with high sides like a railway cutting. The dusk came

label: l>Line
line: gliding into it long before the sun had set. The current ran smooth and swift,

label: l>Line
line: but a dumb immobility sat on the banks. The living trees, lashed together by the

label: l>Line
line: creepers and every living bush of the undergrowth, might have been changed into

label: l>Line
line: stone, even to the slenderest twig, to the lightest leaf. It was not sleep—it

label: l>Line
line: seemed unnatural, like a state of trance. Not the faintest sound of any kind

label: l>Line
line: could be heard. You looked on amazed, and began to suspect yourself of being

label: l>Line
line: deaf—then the night came suddenly, and struck you blind as well. About three in

label: l>Line
line: the morning some large fish leaped, and the loud splash made me jump as though a

label: l>Line
line: gun had been fired. When the sun rose there was a white fog, very warm and

label: l>Line
line: clammy, and more blinding than the night. It did not shift or drive; it was just

label: l>Line
line: there, standing all round you like something solid. At eight or nine, perhaps,

label: l>Line
line: it lifted as a shutter lifts. We had a glimpse of the towering multitude of

label: l>Line
line: trees, of the immense matted jungle, with the blazing little ball of the sun

label: l>Line
line: hanging over it—all perfectly still—and then the white shutter came down again,

label: l>Line
line: smoothly, as if sliding in greased grooves. I ordered the chain, which we had

label: l>Line
line: begun to heave in, to be paid out again. Before it stopped running with a

label: l>Line
line: muffled rattle, a cry, a very loud cry, as of infinite desolation, soared slowly

label: l>Line
line: in the opaque air. It ceased. A complaining clamour, modulated in savage

label: l>Line
line: discords, filled our ears. The sheer unexpectedness of it made my hair stir

label: l>Line
line: under my cap. I don’t know how it struck the others: to me it seemed as though

label: l>Line
line: the mist itself had screamed, so suddenly, and apparently from all sides at

label: l>Line
line: once, did this tumultuous and mournful uproar arise. It culminated in a hurried

label: l>Line
line: outbreak of almost intolerably excessive shrieking, which stopped short, leaving

label: l>Line
line: us stiffened in a variety of silly attitudes, and obstinately listening to the

label: l>Line
line: nearly as appalling and excessive silence.  ‘Good God! What is the meaning—’

label: l>Line
line: stammered at my elbow one of the pilgrims—a little fat man, with sandy hair and

label: l>Line
line: red whiskers, who wore sidespring boots, and pink pyjamas tucked into his socks.

label: l>Line
line: Two others remained open-mouthed a while minute, then dashed into the little

label: l>Line
line: cabin, to rush out incontinently and stand darting scared glances, with

label: l>Line
line: Winchesters at ’ready’ in their hands. What we could see was just the steamer we

label: l>Line
line: were on, her outlines blurred as though she had been on the point of dissolving,

label: l>Line
line: and a misty strip of water, perhaps two feet broad, around her—and that was all.

label: l>Line
line: The rest of the world was nowhere, as far as our eyes and ears were concerned.

label: l>Line
line: Just nowhere. Gone, disappeared; swept off without leaving a whisper or a shadow

label: ll>Last Line
line: behind.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I went forward, and ordered the chain to be hauled in short, so as to be ready

label: l>Line
line: to trip the anchor and move the steamboat at once if necessary.  ’Will they

label: l>Line
line: attack?’ whispered an awed voice. ‘We will be all butchered in this fog,’

label: l>Line
line: murmured another. The faces twitched with the strain, the hands trembled

label: l>Line
line: slightly, the eyes forgot to wink. It was very curious to see the contrast of

label: l>Line
line: expressions of the white men and of the black fellows of our crew, who were as

label: l>Line
line: much strangers to that part of the river as we, though their homes were only

label: l>Line
line: eight hundred miles away. The whites, of course greatly discomposed, had besides

label: l>Line
line: a curious look of being painfully shocked by such an outrageous row. The others

label: l>Line
line: had an alert, naturally interested expression; but their faces were essentially

label: l>Line
line: quiet, even those of the one or two who grinned as they hauled at the chain.

label: l>Line
line: Several exchanged short, grunting phrases, which seemed to settle the matter to

label: l>Line
line: their satisfaction.  Their headman, a young, broad-chested black, severely

label: l>Line
line: draped in dark-blue fringed cloths, with fierce nostrils and his hair all done

label: l>Line
line: up artfully in oily ringlets, stood near me. ’Aha!’ I said, just for good

label: l>Line
line: fellowship’s sake. ‘Catch ‘im,’ he snapped, with a bloodshot widening of his

label: l>Line
line: eyes and a flash of sharp teeth—‘catch ’im. Give ‘im to us.’ ‘To you, eh?’ I

label: l>Line
line: asked; ‘what would you do with them?’ ‘Eat ‘im!’ he said curtly, and, leaning

label: l>Line
line: his elbow on the rail, looked out into the fog in a dignified and profoundly

label: l>Line
line: pensive attitude. I would no doubt have been properly horrified, had it not

label: l>Line
line: occurred to me that he and his chaps must be very hungry: that they must have

label: l>Line
line: been growing increasingly hungry for at least this month past.  They had been

label: l>Line
line: engaged for six months (I don’t think a single one of them had any clear idea of

label: l>Line
line: time, as we at the end of countless ages have. They still belonged to the

label: l>Line
line: beginnings of time—had no inherited experience to teach them as it were), and of

label: l>Line
line: course, as long as there was a piece of paper written over in accordance with

label: l>Line
line: some farcical law or other made down the river, it didn’t enter anybody’s head

label: l>Line
line: to trouble how they would live.  Certainly they had brought with them some

label: l>Line
line: rotten hippo-meat, which couldn’t have lasted very long, anyway, even if the

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims hadn’t, in the midst of a shocking hullabaloo, thrown a considerable

label: l>Line
line: quantity of it overboard. It looked like a high-handed proceeding; but it was

label: l>Line
line: really a case of legitimate self-defence. You can’t breathe dead hippo waking,

label: l>Line
line: sleeping, and eating, and at the same time keep your precarious grip on

label: l>Line
line: existence.  Besides that, they had given them every week three pieces of brass

label: l>Line
line: wire, each about nine inches long; and the theory was they were to buy their

label: l>Line
line: provisions with that currency in riverside villages. You can see how _that_

label: l>Line
line: worked. There were either no villages, or the people were hostile, or the

label: l>Line
line: director, who like the rest of us fed out of tins, with an occasional old

label: l>Line
line: he-goat thrown in, didn’t want to stop the steamer for some more or less

label: l>Line
line: recondite reason. So, unless they swallowed the wire itself, or made loops of it

label: l>Line
line: to snare the fishes with, I don’t see what good their extravagant salary could

label: l>Line
line: be to them. I must say it was paid with a regularity worthy of a large and

label: l>Line
line: honourable trading company. For the rest, the only thing to eat—though it didn’t

label: l>Line
line: look eatable in the least—I saw in their possession was a few lumps of some

label: l>Line
line: stuff like half-cooked dough, of a dirty lavender colour, they kept wrapped in

label: l>Line
line: leaves, and now and then swallowed a piece of, but so small that it seemed done

label: l>Line
line: more for the looks of the thing than for any serious purpose of sustenance. Why

label: l>Line
line: in the name of all the gnawing devils of hunger they didn’t go for us—they were

label: l>Line
line: thirty to five—and have a good tuck-in for once, amazes me now when I think of

label: l>Line
line: it. They were big powerful men, with not much capacity to weigh the

label: l>Line
line: consequences, with courage, with strength, even yet, though their skins were no

label: l>Line
line: longer glossy and their muscles no longer hard. And I saw that something

label: l>Line
line: restraining, one of those human secrets that baffle probability, had come into

label: l>Line
line: play there.  I looked at them with a swift quickening of interest—not because it

label: l>Line
line: occurred to me I might be eaten by them before very long, though I own to you

label: l>Line
line: that just then I perceived—in a new light, as it were—how unwholesome the

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims looked, and I hoped, yes, I positively hoped, that my aspect was not

label: l>Line
line: so—what shall I say?—so—unappetizing: a touch of fantastic vanity which fitted

label: l>Line
line: well with the dream-sensation that pervaded all my days at that time. Perhaps I

label: l>Line
line: had a little fever, too. One can’t live with one’s finger everlastingly on one’s

label: l>Line
line: pulse. I had often ‘a little fever,’ or a little touch of other things—the

label: l>Line
line: playful paw-strokes of the wilderness, the preliminary trifling before the more

label: l>Line
line: serious onslaught which came in due course. Yes; I looked at them as you would

label: l>Line
line: on any human being, with a curiosity of their impulses, motives, capacities,

label: l>Line
line: weaknesses, when brought to the test of an inexorable physical necessity.

label: l>Line
line: Restraint! What possible restraint? Was it superstition, disgust, patience,

label: l>Line
line: fear—or some kind of primitive honour? No fear can stand up to hunger, no

label: l>Line
line: patience can wear it out, disgust simply does not exist where hunger is; and as

label: l>Line
line: to superstition, beliefs, and what you may call principles, they are less than

label: l>Line
line: chaff in a breeze. Don’t you know the devilry of lingering starvation, its

label: l>Line
line: exasperating torment, its black thoughts, its sombre and brooding ferocity?

label: l>Line
line: Well, I do. It takes a man all his inborn strength to fight hunger properly.

label: l>Line
line: It’s really easier to face bereavement, dishonour, and the perdition of one’s

label: l>Line
line: soul—than this kind of prolonged hunger. Sad, but true.  And these chaps, too,

label: l>Line
line: had no earthly reason for any kind of scruple.  Restraint! I would just as soon

label: l>Line
line: have expected restraint from a hyena prowling amongst the corpses of a

label: l>Line
line: battlefield. But there was the fact facing me—the fact dazzling, to be seen,

label: l>Line
line: like the foam on the depths of the sea, like a ripple on an unfathomable enigma,

label: l>Line
line: a mystery greater—when I thought of it—than the curious, inexplicable note of

label: l>Line
line: desperate grief in this savage clamour that had swept by us on the river-bank,

label: ll>Last Line
line: behind the blind whiteness of the fog.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Two pilgrims were quarrelling in hurried whispers as to which bank.  ’Left.’

label: l>Line
line: ‘no, no; how can you? Right, right, of course.’ ‘It is very serious,’ said the

label: l>Line
line: manager’s voice behind me; ‘I would be desolated if anything should happen to

label: l>Line
line: Mr. Kurtz before we came up.’ I looked at him, and had not the slightest doubt

label: l>Line
line: he was sincere. He was just the kind of man who would wish to preserve

label: l>Line
line: appearances. That was his restraint. But when he muttered something about going

label: l>Line
line: on at once, I did not even take the trouble to answer him. I knew, and he knew,

label: l>Line
line: that it was impossible. Were we to let go our hold of the bottom, we would be

label: l>Line
line: absolutely in the air—in space. We wouldn’t be able to tell where we were going

label: l>Line
line: to—whether up or down stream, or across—till we fetched against one bank or the

label: l>Line
line: other—and then we wouldn’t know at first which it was. Of course I made no move.

label: l>Line
line: I had no mind for a smash-up. You couldn’t imagine a more deadly place for a

label: l>Line
line: shipwreck. Whether we drowned at once or not, we were sure to perish speedily in

label: l>Line
line: one way or another. ‘I authorize you to take all the risks,’ he said, after a

label: l>Line
line: short silence. ’I refuse to take any,’ I said shortly; which was just the answer

label: l>Line
line: he expected, though its tone might have surprised him.  ‘Well, I must defer to

label: l>Line
line: your judgment. You are captain,’ he said with marked civility. I turned my

label: l>Line
line: shoulder to him in sign of my appreciation, and looked into the fog. How long

label: l>Line
line: would it last? It was the most hopeless lookout. The approach to this Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: grubbing for ivory in the wretched bush was beset by as many dangers as though

label: l>Line
line: he had been an enchanted princess sleeping in a fabulous castle. ‘Will they

label: ll>Last Line
line: attack, do you think?’ asked the manager, in a confidential tone.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I did not think they would attack, for several obvious reasons. The thick fog

label: l>Line
line: was one. If they left the bank in their canoes they would get lost in it, as we

label: l>Line
line: would be if we attempted to move. Still, I had also judged the jungle of both

label: l>Line
line: banks quite impenetrable—and yet eyes were in it, eyes that had seen us. The

label: l>Line
line: riverside bushes were certainly very thick; but the undergrowth behind was

label: l>Line
line: evidently penetrable. However, during the short lift I had seen no canoes

label: l>Line
line: anywhere in the reach—certainly not abreast of the steamer. But what made the

label: l>Line
line: idea of attack inconceivable to me was the nature of the noise—of the cries we

label: l>Line
line: had heard. They had not the fierce character boding immediate hostile intention.

label: l>Line
line: Unexpected, wild, and violent as they had been, they had given me an

label: l>Line
line: irresistible impression of sorrow.  The glimpse of the steamboat had for some

label: l>Line
line: reason filled those savages with unrestrained grief. The danger, if any, I

label: l>Line
line: expounded, was from our proximity to a great human passion let loose. Even

label: l>Line
line: extreme grief may ultimately vent itself in violence—but more generally takes

label: ll>Last Line
line: the form of apathy....

label: fl>First Line
line: “You should have seen the pilgrims stare! They had no heart to grin, or even to

label: l>Line
line: revile me: but I believe they thought me gone mad—with fright, maybe. I

label: l>Line
line: delivered a regular lecture. My dear boys, it was no good bothering. Keep a

label: l>Line
line: lookout? Well, you may guess I watched the fog for the signs of lifting as a cat

label: l>Line
line: watches a mouse; but for anything else our eyes were of no more use to us than

label: l>Line
line: if we had been buried miles deep in a heap of cotton-wool. It felt like it,

label: l>Line
line: too—choking, warm, stifling. Besides, all I said, though it sounded extravagant,

label: l>Line
line: was absolutely true to fact. What we afterwards alluded to as an attack was

label: l>Line
line: really an attempt at repulse. The action was very far from being aggressive—it

label: l>Line
line: was not even defensive, in the usual sense: it was undertaken under the stress

label: ll>Last Line
line: of desperation, and in its essence was purely protective.

label: fl>First Line
line: “It developed itself, I should say, two hours after the fog lifted, and its

label: l>Line
line: commencement was at a spot, roughly speaking, about a mile and a half below

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz’s station. We had just floundered and flopped round a bend, when I saw an

label: l>Line
line: islet, a mere grassy hummock of bright green, in the middle of the stream. It

label: l>Line
line: was the only thing of the kind; but as we opened the reach more, I perceived it

label: l>Line
line: was the head of a long sand-bank, or rather of a chain of shallow patches

label: l>Line
line: stretching down the middle of the river. They were discoloured, just awash, and

label: l>Line
line: the whole lot was seen just under the water, exactly as a man’s backbone is seen

label: l>Line
line: running down the middle of his back under the skin. Now, as far as I did see, I

label: l>Line
line: could go to the right or to the left of this. I didn’t know either channel, of

label: l>Line
line: course. The banks looked pretty well alike, the depth appeared the same; but as

label: l>Line
line: I had been informed the station was on the west side, I naturally headed for the

label: ll>Last Line
line: western passage.

label: fl>First Line
line: “No sooner had we fairly entered it than I became aware it was much narrower

label: l>Line
line: than I had supposed. To the left of us there was the long uninterrupted shoal,

label: l>Line
line: and to the right a high, steep bank heavily overgrown with bushes. Above the

label: l>Line
line: bush the trees stood in serried ranks. The twigs overhung the current thickly,

label: l>Line
line: and from distance to distance a large limb of some tree projected rigidly over

label: l>Line
line: the stream. It was then well on in the afternoon, the face of the forest was

label: l>Line
line: gloomy, and a broad strip of shadow had already fallen on the water. In this

label: l>Line
line: shadow we steamed up—very slowly, as you may imagine. I sheered her well

label: ll>Last Line
line: inshore—the water being deepest near the bank, as the sounding-pole informed me.

label: fl>First Line
line: “One of my hungry and forbearing friends was sounding in the bows just below me.

label: l>Line
line: This steamboat was exactly like a decked scow. On the deck, there were two

label: l>Line
line: little teakwood houses, with doors and windows. The boiler was in the fore-end,

label: l>Line
line: and the machinery right astern. Over the whole there was a light roof, supported

label: l>Line
line: on stanchions. The funnel projected through that roof, and in front of the

label: l>Line
line: funnel a small cabin built of light planks served for a pilot-house. It

label: l>Line
line: contained a couch, two camp-stools, a loaded Martini-Henry leaning in one

label: l>Line
line: corner, a tiny table, and the steering-wheel.  It had a wide door in front and a

label: l>Line
line: broad shutter at each side. All these were always thrown open, of course. I

label: l>Line
line: spent my days perched up there on the extreme fore-end of that roof, before the

label: l>Line
line: door. At night I slept, or tried to, on the couch. An athletic black belonging

label: l>Line
line: to some coast tribe and educated by my poor predecessor, was the helmsman. He

label: l>Line
line: sported a pair of brass earrings, wore a blue cloth wrapper from the waist to

label: l>Line
line: the ankles, and thought all the world of himself. He was the most unstable kind

label: l>Line
line: of fool I had ever seen. He steered with no end of a swagger while you were by;

label: l>Line
line: but if he lost sight of you, he became instantly the prey of an abject funk, and

label: ll>Last Line
line: would let that cripple of a steamboat get the upper hand of him in a minute.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I was looking down at the sounding-pole, and feeling much annoyed to see at

label: l>Line
line: each try a little more of it stick out of that river, when I saw my poleman give

label: l>Line
line: up on the business suddenly, and stretch himself flat on the deck, without even

label: l>Line
line: taking the trouble to haul his pole in. He kept hold on it though, and it

label: l>Line
line: trailed in the water. At the same time the fireman, whom I could also see below

label: l>Line
line: me, sat down abruptly before his furnace and ducked his head. I was amazed. Then

label: l>Line
line: I had to look at the river mighty quick, because there was a snag in the

label: l>Line
line: fairway. Sticks, little sticks, were flying about—thick: they were whizzing

label: l>Line
line: before my nose, dropping below me, striking behind me against my pilot-house.

label: l>Line
line: All this time the river, the shore, the woods, were very quiet—perfectly quiet.

label: l>Line
line: I could only hear the heavy splashing thump of the stern-wheel and the patter of

label: l>Line
line: these things. We cleared the snag clumsily. Arrows, by Jove! We were being shot

label: l>Line
line: at!  I stepped in quickly to close the shutter on the landside. That

label: l>Line
line: fool-helmsman, his hands on the spokes, was lifting his knees high, stamping his

label: l>Line
line: feet, champing his mouth, like a reined-in horse. Confound him! And we were

label: l>Line
line: staggering within ten feet of the bank. I had to lean right out to swing the

label: l>Line
line: heavy shutter, and I saw a face amongst the leaves on the level with my own,

label: l>Line
line: looking at me very fierce and steady; and then suddenly, as though a veil had

label: l>Line
line: been removed from my eyes, I made out, deep in the tangled gloom, naked breasts,

label: l>Line
line: arms, legs, glaring eyes—the bush was swarming with human limbs in movement,

label: l>Line
line: glistening of bronze colour. The twigs shook, swayed, and rustled, the arrows

label: l>Line
line: flew out of them, and then the shutter came to. ’Steer her straight,’ I said to

label: l>Line
line: the helmsman. He held his head rigid, face forward; but his eyes rolled, he kept

label: l>Line
line: on lifting and setting down his feet gently, his mouth foamed a little. ‘Keep

label: l>Line
line: quiet!’ I said in a fury. I might just as well have ordered a tree not to sway

label: l>Line
line: in the wind. I darted out. Below me there was a great scuffle of feet on the

label: l>Line
line: iron deck; confused exclamations; a voice screamed, ‘Can you turn back?’ I

label: l>Line
line: caught sight of a V-shaped ripple on the water ahead. What? Another snag!  A

label: l>Line
line: fusillade burst out under my feet. The pilgrims had opened with their

label: l>Line
line: Winchesters, and were simply squirting lead into that bush. A deuce of a lot of

label: l>Line
line: smoke came up and drove slowly forward. I swore at it. Now I couldn’t see the

label: l>Line
line: ripple or the snag either. I stood in the doorway, peering, and the arrows came

label: l>Line
line: in swarms. They might have been poisoned, but they looked as though they

label: l>Line
line: wouldn’t kill a cat. The bush began to howl. Our wood-cutters raised a warlike

label: l>Line
line: whoop; the report of a rifle just at my back deafened me. I glanced over my

label: l>Line
line: shoulder, and the pilot-house was yet full of noise and smoke when I made a dash

label: l>Line
line: at the wheel. The fool-nigger had dropped everything, to throw the shutter open

label: l>Line
line: and let off that Martini-Henry. He stood before the wide opening, glaring, and I

label: l>Line
line: yelled at him to come back, while I straightened the sudden twist out of that

label: l>Line
line: steamboat. There was no room to turn even if I had wanted to, the snag was

label: l>Line
line: somewhere very near ahead in that confounded smoke, there was no time to lose,

label: l>Line
line: so I just crowded her into the bank—right into the bank, where I knew the water

label: ll>Last Line
line: was deep.

label: fl>First Line
line: “We tore slowly along the overhanging bushes in a whirl of broken twigs and

label: l>Line
line: flying leaves. The fusillade below stopped short, as I had foreseen it would

label: l>Line
line: when the squirts got empty. I threw my head back to a glinting whizz that

label: l>Line
line: traversed the pilot-house, in at one shutter-hole and out at the other. Looking

label: l>Line
line: past that mad helmsman, who was shaking the empty rifle and yelling at the

label: l>Line
line: shore, I saw vague forms of men running bent double, leaping, gliding, distinct,

label: l>Line
line: incomplete, evanescent. Something big appeared in the air before the shutter,

label: l>Line
line: the rifle went overboard, and the man stepped back swiftly, looked at me over

label: l>Line
line: his shoulder in an extraordinary, profound, familiar manner, and fell upon my

label: l>Line
line: feet. The side of his head hit the wheel twice, and the end of what appeared a

label: l>Line
line: long cane clattered round and knocked over a little camp-stool. It looked as

label: l>Line
line: though after wrenching that thing from somebody ashore he had lost his balance

label: l>Line
line: in the effort. The thin smoke had blown away, we were clear of the snag, and

label: l>Line
line: looking ahead I could see that in another hundred yards or so I would be free to

label: l>Line
line: sheer off, away from the bank; but my feet felt so very warm and wet that I had

label: l>Line
line: to look down. The man had rolled on his back and stared straight up at me; both

label: l>Line
line: his hands clutched that cane. It was the shaft of a spear that, either thrown or

label: l>Line
line: lunged through the opening, had caught him in the side, just below the ribs; the

label: l>Line
line: blade had gone in out of sight, after making a frightful gash; my shoes were

label: l>Line
line: full; a pool of blood lay very still, gleaming dark-red under the wheel; his

label: l>Line
line: eyes shone with an amazing lustre.  The fusillade burst out again. He looked at

label: l>Line
line: me anxiously, gripping the spear like something precious, with an air of being

label: l>Line
line: afraid I would try to take it away from him. I had to make an effort to free my

label: l>Line
line: eyes from his gaze and attend to the steering. With one hand I felt above my

label: l>Line
line: head for the line of the steam whistle, and jerked out screech after screech

label: l>Line
line: hurriedly.  The tumult of angry and warlike yells was checked instantly, and

label: l>Line
line: then from the depths of the woods went out such a tremulous and prolonged wail

label: l>Line
line: of mournful fear and utter despair as may be imagined to follow the flight of

label: l>Line
line: the last hope from the earth. There was a great commotion in the bush; the

label: l>Line
line: shower of arrows stopped, a few dropping shots rang out sharply—then silence, in

label: l>Line
line: which the languid beat of the stern-wheel came plainly to my ears. I put the

label: l>Line
line: helm hard a-starboard at the moment when the pilgrim in pink pyjamas, very hot

label: l>Line
line: and agitated, appeared in the doorway. ‘The manager sends me—’ he began in an

label: l>Line
line: official tone, and stopped short. ‘Good God!’ he said, glaring at the wounded

label: ll>Last Line
line: man.

label: fl>First Line
line: “We two whites stood over him, and his lustrous and inquiring glance enveloped

label: l>Line
line: us both. I declare it looked as though he would presently put to us some

label: l>Line
line: questions in an understandable language; but he died without uttering a sound,

label: l>Line
line: without moving a limb, without twitching a muscle. Only in the very last moment,

label: l>Line
line: as though in response to some sign we could not see, to some whisper we could

label: l>Line
line: not hear, he frowned heavily, and that frown gave to his black death-mask an

label: l>Line
line: inconceivably sombre, brooding, and menacing expression. The lustre of inquiring

label: l>Line
line: glance faded swiftly into vacant glassiness. ‘Can you steer?’ I asked the agent

label: l>Line
line: eagerly. He looked very dubious; but I made a grab at his arm, and he understood

label: l>Line
line: at once I meant him to steer whether or no. To tell you the truth, I was

label: l>Line
line: morbidly anxious to change my shoes and socks. ‘He is dead,’ murmured the

label: l>Line
line: fellow, immensely impressed. ‘No doubt about it,’ said I, tugging like mad at

label: l>Line
line: the shoe-laces. ‘And by the way, I suppose Mr. Kurtz is dead as well by this

label: ll>Last Line
line: time.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “For the moment that was the dominant thought. There was a sense of extreme

label: l>Line
line: disappointment, as though I had found out I had been striving after something

label: l>Line
line: altogether without a substance. I couldn’t have been more disgusted if I had

label: l>Line
line: travelled all this way for the sole purpose of talking with Mr. Kurtz. Talking

label: l>Line
line: with... I flung one shoe overboard, and became aware that that was exactly what

label: l>Line
line: I had been looking forward to—a talk with Kurtz. I made the strange discovery

label: l>Line
