line: that I had never imagined him as doing, you know, but as discoursing. I didn’t

label: l>Line
line: say to myself, ‘Now I will never see him,’ or ‘Now I will never shake him by the

label: l>Line
line: hand,’ but, ‘Now I will never hear him.’ The man presented himself as a voice.

label: l>Line
line: Not of course that I did not connect him with some sort of action. Hadn’t I been

label: l>Line
line: told in all the tones of jealousy and admiration that he had collected,

label: l>Line
line: bartered, swindled, or stolen more ivory than all the other agents together?

label: l>Line
line: That was not the point. The point was in his being a gifted creature, and that

label: l>Line
line: of all his gifts the one that stood out preeminently, that carried with it a

label: l>Line
line: sense of real presence, was his ability to talk, his words—the gift of

label: l>Line
line: expression, the bewildering, the illuminating, the most exalted and the most

label: l>Line
line: contemptible, the pulsating stream of light, or the deceitful flow from the

label: ll>Last Line
line: heart of an impenetrable darkness.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The other shoe went flying unto the devil-god of that river. I thought, ’By

label: l>Line
line: Jove! it’s all over. We are too late; he has vanished—the gift has vanished, by

label: l>Line
line: means of some spear, arrow, or club. I will never hear that chap speak after

label: l>Line
line: all’—and my sorrow had a startling extravagance of emotion, even such as I had

label: l>Line
line: noticed in the howling sorrow of these savages in the bush. I couldn’t have felt

label: l>Line
line: more of lonely desolation somehow, had I been robbed of a belief or had missed

label: l>Line
line: my destiny in life.... Why do you sigh in this beastly way, somebody? Absurd?

label: ll>Last Line
line: Well, absurd. Good Lord!  mustn’t a man ever—Here, give me some tobacco.”...

label: fl>First Line
line: There was a pause of profound stillness, then a match flared, and Marlow’s lean

label: l>Line
line: face appeared, worn, hollow, with downward folds and dropped eyelids, with an

label: l>Line
line: aspect of concentrated attention; and as he took vigorous draws at his pipe, it

label: l>Line
line: seemed to retreat and advance out of the night in the regular flicker of tiny

label: ll>Last Line
line: flame. The match went out.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Absurd!” he cried. “This is the worst of trying to tell.... Here you all are,

label: l>Line
line: each moored with two good addresses, like a hulk with two anchors, a butcher

label: l>Line
line: round one corner, a policeman round another, excellent appetites, and

label: l>Line
line: temperature normal—you hear—normal from year’s end to year’s end. And you say,

label: l>Line
line: Absurd! Absurd be—exploded! Absurd! My dear boys, what can you expect from a man

label: l>Line
line: who out of sheer nervousness had just flung overboard a pair of new shoes! Now I

label: l>Line
line: think of it, it is amazing I did not shed tears.  I am, upon the whole, proud of

label: l>Line
line: my fortitude. I was cut to the quick at the idea of having lost the inestimable

label: l>Line
line: privilege of listening to the gifted Kurtz. Of course I was wrong. The privilege

label: l>Line
line: was waiting for me. Oh, yes, I heard more than enough. And I was right, too. A

label: l>Line
line: voice. He was very little more than a voice. And I heard—him—it—this voice—other

label: l>Line
line: voices—all of them were so little more than voices—and the memory of that time

label: l>Line
line: itself lingers around me, impalpable, like a dying vibration of one immense

label: l>Line
line: jabber, silly, atrocious, sordid, savage, or simply mean, without any kind of

label: ll>Last Line
line: sense.  Voices, voices—even the girl herself—now—”

label: sl>Single Line
line: He was silent for a long time.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I laid the ghost of his gifts at last with a lie,” he began, suddenly.  “Girl!

label: l>Line
line: What? Did I mention a girl? Oh, she is out of it—completely.  They—the women, I

label: l>Line
line: mean—are out of it—should be out of it. We must help them to stay in that

label: l>Line
line: beautiful world of their own, lest ours gets worse. Oh, she had to be out of it.

label: l>Line
line: You should have heard the disinterred body of Mr.  Kurtz saying, ‘My Intended.’

label: l>Line
line: You would have perceived directly then how completely she was out of it. And the

label: l>Line
line: lofty frontal bone of Mr. Kurtz! They say the hair goes on growing sometimes,

label: l>Line
line: but this—ah—specimen, was impressively bald. The wilderness had patted him on

label: l>Line
line: the head, and, behold, it was like a ball—an ivory ball; it had caressed him,

label: l>Line
line: and—lo!—he had withered; it had taken him, loved him, embraced him, got into his

label: l>Line
line: veins, consumed his flesh, and sealed his soul to its own by the inconceivable

label: l>Line
line: ceremonies of some devilish initiation. He was its spoiled and pampered

label: l>Line
line: favourite. Ivory? I should think so. Heaps of it, stacks of it. The old mud

label: l>Line
line: shanty was bursting with it. You would think there was not a single tusk left

label: l>Line
line: either above or below the ground in the whole country. ‘Mostly fossil,’ the

label: l>Line
line: manager had remarked, disparagingly. It was no more fossil than I am; but they

label: l>Line
line: call it fossil when it is dug up. It appears these niggers do bury the tusks

label: l>Line
line: sometimes—but evidently they couldn’t bury this parcel deep enough to save the

label: l>Line
line: gifted Mr. Kurtz from his fate. We filled the steamboat with it, and had to pile

label: l>Line
line: a lot on the deck. Thus he could see and enjoy as long as he could see, because

label: l>Line
line: the appreciation of this favour had remained with him to the last. You should

label: l>Line
line: have heard him say, ’My ivory.’ Oh, yes, I heard him. ‘My Intended, my ivory, my

label: l>Line
line: station, my river, my—’ everything belonged to him. It made me hold my breath in

label: l>Line
line: expectation of hearing the wilderness burst into a prodigious peal of laughter

label: l>Line
line: that would shake the fixed stars in their places. Everything belonged to him—but

label: l>Line
line: that was a trifle. The thing was to know what he belonged to, how many powers of

label: l>Line
line: darkness claimed him for their own. That was the reflection that made you creepy

label: l>Line
line: all over. It was impossible—it was not good for one either—trying to imagine. He

label: l>Line
line: had taken a high seat amongst the devils of the land—I mean literally. You can’t

label: l>Line
line: understand. How could you?—with solid pavement under your feet, surrounded by

label: l>Line
line: kind neighbours ready to cheer you or to fall on you, stepping delicately

label: l>Line
line: between the butcher and the policeman, in the holy terror of scandal and gallows

label: l>Line
line: and lunatic asylums—how can you imagine what particular region of the first ages

label: l>Line
line: a man’s untrammelled feet may take him into by the way of solitude—utter

label: l>Line
line: solitude without a policeman—by the way of silence—utter silence, where no

label: l>Line
line: warning voice of a kind neighbour can be heard whispering of public opinion?

label: l>Line
line: These little things make all the great difference. When they are gone you must

label: l>Line
line: fall back upon your own innate strength, upon your own capacity for

label: l>Line
line: faithfulness. Of course you may be too much of a fool to go wrong—too dull even

label: l>Line
line: to know you are being assaulted by the powers of darkness. I take it, no fool

label: l>Line
line: ever made a bargain for his soul with the devil; the fool is too much of a fool,

label: l>Line
line: or the devil too much of a devil—I don’t know which. Or you may be such a

label: l>Line
line: thunderingly exalted creature as to be altogether deaf and blind to anything but

label: l>Line
line: heavenly sights and sounds.  Then the earth for you is only a standing place—and

label: l>Line
line: whether to be like this is your loss or your gain I won’t pretend to say. But

label: l>Line
line: most of us are neither one nor the other. The earth for us is a place to live

label: l>Line
line: in, where we must put up with sights, with sounds, with smells, too, by

label: l>Line
line: Jove!—breathe dead hippo, so to speak, and not be contaminated. And there, don’t

label: l>Line
line: you see?  Your strength comes in, the faith in your ability for the digging of

label: l>Line
line: unostentatious holes to bury the stuff in—your power of devotion, not to

label: l>Line
line: yourself, but to an obscure, back-breaking business. And that’s difficult

label: l>Line
line: enough. Mind, I am not trying to excuse or even explain—I am trying to account

label: l>Line
line: to myself for—for—Mr. Kurtz—for the shade of Mr. Kurtz. This initiated wraith

label: l>Line
line: from the back of Nowhere honoured me with its amazing confidence before it

label: l>Line
line: vanished altogether. This was because it could speak English to me. The original

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz had been educated partly in England, and—as he was good enough to say

label: l>Line
line: himself—his sympathies were in the right place. His mother was half-English, his

label: l>Line
line: father was half-French. All Europe contributed to the making of Kurtz; and by

label: l>Line
line: and by I learned that, most appropriately, the International Society for the

label: l>Line
line: Suppression of Savage Customs had intrusted him with the making of a report, for

label: l>Line
line: its future guidance. And he had written it, too. I’ve seen it. I’ve read it. It

label: l>Line
line: was eloquent, vibrating with eloquence, but too high-strung, I think. Seventeen

label: l>Line
line: pages of close writing he had found time for! But this must have been before

label: l>Line
line: his—let us say—nerves, went wrong, and caused him to preside at certain midnight

label: l>Line
line: dances ending with unspeakable rites, which—as far as I reluctantly gathered

label: l>Line
line: from what I heard at various times—were offered up to him—do you understand?—to

label: l>Line
line: Mr. Kurtz himself. But it was a beautiful piece of writing. The opening

label: l>Line
line: paragraph, however, in the light of later information, strikes me now as

label: l>Line
line: ominous. He began with the argument that we whites, from the point of

label: l>Line
line: development we had arrived at, ‘must necessarily appear to them [savages] in the

label: l>Line
line: nature of supernatural beings—we approach them with the might of a deity,’ and

label: l>Line
line: so on, and so on. ‘By the simple exercise of our will we can exert a power for

label: l>Line
line: good practically unbounded,’ etc., etc. From that point he soared and took me

label: l>Line
line: with him. The peroration was magnificent, though difficult to remember, you

label: l>Line
line: know. It gave me the notion of an exotic Immensity ruled by an august

label: l>Line
line: Benevolence. It made me tingle with enthusiasm. This was the unbounded power of

label: l>Line
line: eloquence—of words—of burning noble words. There were no practical hints to

label: l>Line
line: interrupt the magic current of phrases, unless a kind of note at the foot of the

label: l>Line
line: last page, scrawled evidently much later, in an unsteady hand, may be regarded

label: l>Line
line: as the exposition of a method. It was very simple, and at the end of that moving

label: l>Line
line: appeal to every altruistic sentiment it blazed at you, luminous and terrifying,

label: l>Line
line: like a flash of lightning in a serene sky: ‘Exterminate all the brutes!’ The

label: l>Line
line: curious part was that he had apparently forgotten all about that valuable

label: l>Line
line: postscriptum, because, later on, when he in a sense came to himself, he

label: l>Line
line: repeatedly entreated me to take good care of ‘my pamphlet’ (he called it), as it

label: l>Line
line: was sure to have in the future a good influence upon his career. I had full

label: l>Line
line: information about all these things, and, besides, as it turned out, I was to

label: l>Line
line: have the care of his memory. I’ve done enough for it to give me the indisputable

label: l>Line
line: right to lay it, if I choose, for an everlasting rest in the dust-bin of

label: l>Line
line: progress, amongst all the sweepings and, figuratively speaking, all the dead

label: l>Line
line: cats of civilization. But then, you see, I can’t choose. He won’t be forgotten.

label: l>Line
line: Whatever he was, he was not common. He had the power to charm or frighten

label: l>Line
line: rudimentary souls into an aggravated witch-dance in his honour; he could also

label: l>Line
line: fill the small souls of the pilgrims with bitter misgivings: he had one devoted

label: l>Line
line: friend at least, and he had conquered one soul in the world that was neither

label: l>Line
line: rudimentary nor tainted with self-seeking. No; I can’t forget him, though I am

label: l>Line
line: not prepared to affirm the fellow was exactly worth the life we lost in getting

label: l>Line
line: to him.  I missed my late helmsman awfully—I missed him even while his body was

label: l>Line
line: still lying in the pilot-house. Perhaps you will think it passing strange this

label: l>Line
line: regret for a savage who was no more account than a grain of sand in a black

label: l>Line
line: Sahara. Well, don’t you see, he had done something, he had steered; for months I

label: l>Line
line: had him at my back—a help—an instrument. It was a kind of partnership. He

label: l>Line
line: steered for me—I had to look after him, I worried about his deficiencies, and

label: l>Line
line: thus a subtle bond had been created, of which I only became aware when it was

label: l>Line
line: suddenly broken. And the intimate profundity of that look he gave me when he

label: l>Line
line: received his hurt remains to this day in my memory—like a claim of distant

label: ll>Last Line
line: kinship affirmed in a supreme moment.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Poor fool! If he had only left that shutter alone. He had no restraint, no

label: l>Line
line: restraint—just like Kurtz—a tree swayed by the wind. As soon as I had put on a

label: l>Line
line: dry pair of slippers, I dragged him out, after first jerking the spear out of

label: l>Line
line: his side, which operation I confess I performed with my eyes shut tight. His

label: l>Line
line: heels leaped together over the little doorstep; his shoulders were pressed to my

label: l>Line
line: breast; I hugged him from behind desperately. Oh! he was heavy, heavy; heavier

label: l>Line
line: than any man on earth, I should imagine. Then without more ado I tipped him

label: l>Line
line: overboard. The current snatched him as though he had been a wisp of grass, and I

label: l>Line
line: saw the body roll over twice before I lost sight of it for ever. All the

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims and the manager were then congregated on the awning-deck about the

label: l>Line
line: pilot-house, chattering at each other like a flock of excited magpies, and there

label: l>Line
line: was a scandalized murmur at my heartless promptitude. What they wanted to keep

label: l>Line
line: that body hanging about for I can’t guess. Embalm it, maybe. But I had also

label: l>Line
line: heard another, and a very ominous, murmur on the deck below. My friends the

label: l>Line
line: wood-cutters were likewise scandalized, and with a better show of reason—though

label: l>Line
line: I admit that the reason itself was quite inadmissible. Oh, quite! I had made up

label: l>Line
line: my mind that if my late helmsman was to be eaten, the fishes alone should have

label: l>Line
line: him. He had been a very second-rate helmsman while alive, but now he was dead he

label: l>Line
line: might have become a first-class temptation, and possibly cause some startling

label: l>Line
line: trouble. Besides, I was anxious to take the wheel, the man in pink pyjamas

label: ll>Last Line
line: showing himself a hopeless duffer at the business.

label: fl>First Line
line: “This I did directly the simple funeral was over. We were going half-speed,

label: l>Line
line: keeping right in the middle of the stream, and I listened to the talk about me.

label: l>Line
line: They had given up Kurtz, they had given up the station; Kurtz was dead, and the

label: l>Line
line: station had been burnt—and so on—and so on. The red-haired pilgrim was beside

label: l>Line
line: himself with the thought that at least this poor Kurtz had been properly

label: l>Line
line: avenged. ‘Say! We must have made a glorious slaughter of them in the bush. Eh?

label: l>Line
line: What do you think? Say?’ He positively danced, the bloodthirsty little gingery

label: l>Line
line: beggar. And he had nearly fainted when he saw the wounded man! I could not help

label: l>Line
line: saying, ‘You made a glorious lot of smoke, anyhow.’ I had seen, from the way the

label: l>Line
line: tops of the bushes rustled and flew, that almost all the shots had gone too

label: l>Line
line: high. You can’t hit anything unless you take aim and fire from the shoulder; but

label: l>Line
line: these chaps fired from the hip with their eyes shut. The retreat, I

label: l>Line
line: maintained—and I was right—was caused by the screeching of the steam whistle.

label: ll>Last Line
line: Upon this they forgot Kurtz, and began to howl at me with indignant protests.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The manager stood by the wheel murmuring confidentially about the necessity of

label: l>Line
line: getting well away down the river before dark at all events, when I saw in the

label: l>Line
line: distance a clearing on the riverside and the outlines of some sort of building.

label: l>Line
line: ‘What’s this?’ I asked. He clapped his hands in wonder. ‘The station!’ he cried.

label: ll>Last Line
line: I edged in at once, still going half-speed.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Through my glasses I saw the slope of a hill interspersed with rare trees and

label: l>Line
line: perfectly free from undergrowth. A long decaying building on the summit was half

label: l>Line
line: buried in the high grass; the large holes in the peaked roof gaped black from

label: l>Line
line: afar; the jungle and the woods made a background. There was no enclosure or

label: l>Line
line: fence of any kind; but there had been one apparently, for near the house

label: l>Line
line: half-a-dozen slim posts remained in a row, roughly trimmed, and with their upper

label: l>Line
line: ends ornamented with round carved balls. The rails, or whatever there had been

label: l>Line
line: between, had disappeared. Of course the forest surrounded all that. The

label: l>Line
line: river-bank was clear, and on the waterside I saw a white man under a hat like a

label: l>Line
line: cart-wheel beckoning persistently with his whole arm. Examining the edge of the

label: l>Line
line: forest above and below, I was almost certain I could see movements—human forms

label: l>Line
line: gliding here and there. I steamed past prudently, then stopped the engines and

label: l>Line
line: let her drift down. The man on the shore began to shout, urging us to land. ‘We

label: l>Line
line: have been attacked,’ screamed the manager. ‘I know—I know. It’s all right,’

label: l>Line
line: yelled back the other, as cheerful as you please. ‘Come along. It’s all right. I

label: ll>Last Line
line: am glad.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “His aspect reminded me of something I had seen—something funny I had seen

label: l>Line
line: somewhere. As I manoeuvred to get alongside, I was asking myself, ’What does

label: l>Line
line: this fellow look like?’ Suddenly I got it. He looked like a harlequin.  His

label: l>Line
line: clothes had been made of some stuff that was brown holland probably, but it was

label: l>Line
line: covered with patches all over, with bright patches, blue, red, and

label: l>Line
line: yellow—patches on the back, patches on the front, patches on elbows, on knees;

label: l>Line
line: coloured binding around his jacket, scarlet edging at the bottom of his

label: l>Line
line: trousers; and the sunshine made him look extremely gay and wonderfully neat

label: l>Line
line: withal, because you could see how beautifully all this patching had been done. A

label: l>Line
line: beardless, boyish face, very fair, no features to speak of, nose peeling, little

label: l>Line
line: blue eyes, smiles and frowns chasing each other over that open countenance like

label: l>Line
line: sunshine and shadow on a wind-swept plain. ‘Look out, captain!’ he cried;

label: l>Line
line: ‘there’s a snag lodged in here last night.’ What!  Another snag? I confess I

label: l>Line
line: swore shamefully. I had nearly holed my cripple, to finish off that charming

label: l>Line
line: trip. The harlequin on the bank turned his little pug-nose up to me. ‘You

label: l>Line
line: English?’ he asked, all smiles. ‘Are you?’ I shouted from the wheel. The smiles

label: l>Line
line: vanished, and he shook his head as if sorry for my disappointment. Then he

label: l>Line
line: brightened up. ‘Never mind!’ he cried encouragingly. ‘Are we in time?’ I asked.

label: l>Line
line: ‘He is up there,’ he replied, with a toss of the head up the hill, and becoming

label: l>Line
line: gloomy all of a sudden.  His face was like the autumn sky, overcast one moment

label: ll>Last Line
line: and bright the next.

label: fl>First Line
line: “When the manager, escorted by the pilgrims, all of them armed to the teeth, had

label: l>Line
line: gone to the house this chap came on board. ‘I say, I don’t like this. These

label: l>Line
line: natives are in the bush,’ I said. He assured me earnestly it was all right.

label: l>Line
line: ‘They are simple people,’ he added; ‘well, I am glad you came. It took me all my

label: l>Line
line: time to keep them off.’ ‘But you said it was all right,’ I cried. ‘Oh, they

label: l>Line
line: meant no harm,’ he said; and as I stared he corrected himself, ‘Not exactly.’

label: l>Line
line: Then vivaciously, ‘My faith, your pilot-house wants a clean-up!’ In the next

label: l>Line
line: breath he advised me to keep enough steam on the boiler to blow the whistle in

label: l>Line
line: case of any trouble. ‘One good screech will do more for you than all your

label: l>Line
line: rifles. They are simple people,’ he repeated. He rattled away at such a rate he

label: l>Line
line: quite overwhelmed me. He seemed to be trying to make up for lots of silence, and

label: l>Line
line: actually hinted, laughing, that such was the case. ‘Don’t you talk with Mr.

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz?’ I said. ‘You don’t talk with that man—you listen to him,’ he exclaimed

label: l>Line
line: with severe exaltation. ‘But now—’ He waved his arm, and in the twinkling of an

label: l>Line
line: eye was in the uttermost depths of despondency. In a moment he came up again

label: l>Line
line: with a jump, possessed himself of both my hands, shook them continuously, while

label: l>Line
line: he gabbled: ‘Brother sailor... honour... pleasure...  delight... introduce

label: l>Line
line: myself... Russian... son of an arch-priest...  Government of Tambov... What?

label: l>Line
line: Tobacco! English tobacco; the excellent English tobacco! Now, that’s brotherly.

label: ll>Last Line
line: Smoke? Where’s a sailor that does not smoke?”

label: fl>First Line
line: “The pipe soothed him, and gradually I made out he had run away from school, had

label: l>Line
line: gone to sea in a Russian ship; ran away again; served some time in English

label: l>Line
line: ships; was now reconciled with the arch-priest. He made a point of that. ‘But

label: l>Line
line: when one is young one must see things, gather experience, ideas; enlarge the

label: l>Line
line: mind.’ ‘Here!’ I interrupted. ‘You can never tell! Here I met Mr. Kurtz,’ he

label: l>Line
line: said, youthfully solemn and reproachful. I held my tongue after that. It appears

label: l>Line
line: he had persuaded a Dutch trading-house on the coast to fit him out with stores

label: l>Line
line: and goods, and had started for the interior with a light heart and no more idea

label: l>Line
line: of what would happen to him than a baby. He had been wandering about that river

label: l>Line
line: for nearly two years alone, cut off from everybody and everything. ’I am not so

label: l>Line
line: young as I look. I am twenty-five,’ he said. ‘At first old Van Shuyten would

label: l>Line
line: tell me to go to the devil,’ he narrated with keen enjoyment; ‘but I stuck to

label: l>Line
line: him, and talked and talked, till at last he got afraid I would talk the hind-leg

label: l>Line
line: off his favourite dog, so he gave me some cheap things and a few guns, and told

label: l>Line
line: me he hoped he would never see my face again. Good old Dutchman, Van Shuyten.

label: l>Line
line: I’ve sent him one small lot of ivory a year ago, so that he can’t call me a

label: l>Line
line: little thief when I get back. I hope he got it. And for the rest I don’t care. I

label: ll>Last Line
line: had some wood stacked for you. That was my old house. Did you see?’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I gave him Towson’s book. He made as though he would kiss me, but restrained

label: l>Line
line: himself. ‘The only book I had left, and I thought I had lost it,’ he said,

label: l>Line
line: looking at it ecstatically. ‘So many accidents happen to a man going about

label: l>Line
line: alone, you know. Canoes get upset sometimes—and sometimes you’ve got to clear

label: l>Line
line: out so quick when the people get angry.’ He thumbed the pages. ‘You made notes

label: l>Line
line: in Russian?’ I asked. He nodded. ’I thought they were written in cipher,’ I

label: l>Line
line: said. He laughed, then became serious. ‘I had lots of trouble to keep these

label: l>Line
line: people off,’ he said. ’Did they want to kill you?’ I asked. ‘Oh, no!’ he cried,

label: l>Line
line: and checked himself. ‘Why did they attack us?’ I pursued. He hesitated, then

label: l>Line
line: said shamefacedly, ‘They don’t want him to go.’ ‘Don’t they?’ I said curiously.

label: l>Line
line: He nodded a nod full of mystery and wisdom. ‘I tell you,’ he cried, ‘this man

label: l>Line
line: has enlarged my mind.’ He opened his arms wide, staring at me with his little

label: ll>Last Line
line: blue eyes that were perfectly round.”

label: lvl1>Chapter
line: III

label: fl>First Line
line: “I looked at him, lost in astonishment. There he was before me, in motley, as

label: l>Line
line: though he had absconded from a troupe of mimes, enthusiastic, fabulous.  His

label: l>Line
line: very existence was improbable, inexplicable, and altogether bewildering. He was

label: l>Line
line: an insoluble problem. It was inconceivable how he had existed, how he had

label: l>Line
line: succeeded in getting so far, how he had managed to remain—why he did not

label: l>Line
line: instantly disappear. ’I went a little farther,’ he said, ‘then still a little

label: l>Line
line: farther—till I had gone so far that I don’t know how I’ll ever get back. Never

label: l>Line
line: mind. Plenty time. I can manage. You take Kurtz away quick—quick—I tell you.’

label: l>Line
line: The glamour of youth enveloped his parti-coloured rags, his destitution, his

label: l>Line
line: loneliness, the essential desolation of his futile wanderings. For months—for

label: l>Line
line: years—his life hadn’t been worth a day’s purchase; and there he was gallantly,

label: l>Line
line: thoughtlessly alive, to all appearances indestructible solely by the virtue of

label: l>Line
line: his few years and of his unreflecting audacity. I was seduced into something

label: l>Line
line: like admiration—like envy. Glamour urged him on, glamour kept him unscathed. He

label: l>Line
line: surely wanted nothing from the wilderness but space to breathe in and to push on

label: l>Line
line: through. His need was to exist, and to move onwards at the greatest possible

label: l>Line
line: risk, and with a maximum of privation. If the absolutely pure, uncalculating,

label: l>Line
line: unpractical spirit of adventure had ever ruled a human being, it ruled this

label: l>Line
line: bepatched youth. I almost envied him the possession of this modest and clear

label: l>Line
line: flame. It seemed to have consumed all thought of self so completely, that even

label: l>Line
line: while he was talking to you, you forgot that it was he—the man before your

label: l>Line
line: eyes—who had gone through these things. I did not envy him his devotion to

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz, though. He had not meditated over it.  It came to him, and he accepted it

label: l>Line
line: with a sort of eager fatalism. I must say that to me it appeared about the most

label: ll>Last Line
line: dangerous thing in every way he had come upon so far.

label: fl>First Line
line: “They had come together unavoidably, like two ships becalmed near each other,

label: l>Line
line: and lay rubbing sides at last. I suppose Kurtz wanted an audience, because on a

label: l>Line
line: certain occasion, when encamped in the forest, they had talked all night, or

label: l>Line
line: more probably Kurtz had talked. ‘We talked of everything,’ he said, quite

label: l>Line
line: transported at the recollection. ‘I forgot there was such a thing as sleep. The

label: l>Line
line: night did not seem to last an hour. Everything!  Everything!... Of love, too.’

label: l>Line
line: ‘Ah, he talked to you of love!’ I said, much amused. ‘It isn’t what you think,’

label: l>Line
line: he cried, almost passionately. ‘It was in general. He made me see

label: ll>Last Line
line: things—things.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “He threw his arms up. We were on deck at the time, and the headman of my

label: l>Line
line: wood-cutters, lounging near by, turned upon him his heavy and glittering eyes. I

label: l>Line
line: looked around, and I don’t know why, but I assure you that never, never before,

label: l>Line
line: did this land, this river, this jungle, the very arch of this blazing sky,

label: l>Line
line: appear to me so hopeless and so dark, so impenetrable to human thought, so

label: l>Line
line: pitiless to human weakness. ‘And, ever since, you have been with him, of

label: ll>Last Line
line: course?’ I said.

label: fl>First Line
line: “On the contrary. It appears their intercourse had been very much broken by

label: l>Line
line: various causes. He had, as he informed me proudly, managed to nurse Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: through two illnesses (he alluded to it as you would to some risky feat), but as

label: l>Line
line: a rule Kurtz wandered alone, far in the depths of the forest. ‘Very often coming

label: l>Line
line: to this station, I had to wait days and days before he would turn up,’ he said.

label: l>Line
line: ‘Ah, it was worth waiting for!—sometimes.’ ‘What was he doing? exploring or

label: l>Line
line: what?’ I asked. ‘Oh, yes, of course’; he had discovered lots of villages, a

label: l>Line
line: lake, too—he did not know exactly in what direction; it was dangerous to inquire

label: l>Line
line: too much—but mostly his expeditions had been for ivory. ‘But he had no goods to

label: l>Line
line: trade with by that time,’ I objected.  ‘There’s a good lot of cartridges left

label: l>Line
line: even yet,’ he answered, looking away. ‘To speak plainly, he raided the country,’

label: l>Line
line: I said. He nodded. ‘Not alone, surely!’ He muttered something about the villages

label: l>Line
line: round that lake.  ‘Kurtz got the tribe to follow him, did he?’ I suggested. He

label: l>Line
line: fidgeted a little. ‘They adored him,’ he said. The tone of these words was so

label: l>Line
line: extraordinary that I looked at him searchingly. It was curious to see his

label: l>Line
line: mingled eagerness and reluctance to speak of Kurtz. The man filled his life,

label: l>Line
line: occupied his thoughts, swayed his emotions. ‘What can you expect?’ he burst out;

label: l>Line
line: ‘he came to them with thunder and lightning, you know—and they had never seen

label: l>Line
line: anything like it—and very terrible. He could be very terrible. You can’t judge

label: l>Line
line: Mr. Kurtz as you would an ordinary man. No, no, no! Now—just to give you an

label: l>Line
line: idea—I don’t mind telling you, he wanted to shoot me, too, one day—but I don’t

label: l>Line
line: judge him.’ ‘Shoot you!’ I cried ’What for?’ ‘Well, I had a small lot of ivory

label: l>Line
line: the chief of that village near my house gave me. You see I used to shoot game

label: l>Line
line: for them. Well, he wanted it, and wouldn’t hear reason. He declared he would

label: l>Line
line: shoot me unless I gave him the ivory and then cleared out of the country,

label: l>Line
line: because he could do so, and had a fancy for it, and there was nothing on earth

label: l>Line
line: to prevent him killing whom he jolly well pleased. And it was true, too. I gave

label: l>Line
line: him the ivory.  What did I care! But I didn’t clear out. No, no. I couldn’t

label: l>Line
line: leave him.  I had to be careful, of course, till we got friendly again for a

label: l>Line
line: time. He had his second illness then. Afterwards I had to keep out of the way;

label: l>Line
line: but I didn’t mind. He was living for the most part in those villages on the

label: l>Line
line: lake. When he came down to the river, sometimes he would take to me, and

label: l>Line
line: sometimes it was better for me to be careful. This man suffered too much.  He

label: l>Line
line: hated all this, and somehow he couldn’t get away. When I had a chance I begged

label: l>Line
line: him to try and leave while there was time; I offered to go back with him. And he

label: l>Line
line: would say yes, and then he would remain; go off on another ivory hunt; disappear

label: l>Line
line: for weeks; forget himself amongst these people—forget himself—you know.’ ‘Why!

label: l>Line
line: he’s mad,’ I said. He protested indignantly. Mr.  Kurtz couldn’t be mad. If I

label: l>Line
line: had heard him talk, only two days ago, I wouldn’t dare hint at such a thing....

label: l>Line
line: I had taken up my binoculars while we talked, and was looking at the shore,

label: l>Line
line: sweeping the limit of the forest at each side and at the back of the house. The

label: l>Line
line: consciousness of there being people in that bush, so silent, so quiet—as silent

label: l>Line
line: and quiet as the ruined house on the hill—made me uneasy. There was no sign on

label: l>Line
line: the face of nature of this amazing tale that was not so much told as suggested

label: l>Line
line: to me in desolate exclamations, completed by shrugs, in interrupted phrases, in

label: l>Line
line: hints ending in deep sighs. The woods were unmoved, like a mask—heavy, like the

label: l>Line
line: closed door of a prison—they looked with their air of hidden knowledge, of

label: l>Line
line: patient expectation, of unapproachable silence. The Russian was explaining to me

label: l>Line
line: that it was only lately that Mr. Kurtz had come down to the river, bringing

label: l>Line
line: along with him all the fighting men of that lake tribe.  He had been absent for

label: l>Line
line: several months—getting himself adored, I suppose—and had come down unexpectedly,

label: l>Line
line: with the intention to all appearance of making a raid either across the river or

label: l>Line
line: down stream. Evidently the appetite for more ivory had got the better of

label: l>Line
line: the—what shall I say?—less material aspirations. However he had got much worse

label: l>Line
line: suddenly. ‘I heard he was lying helpless, and so I came up—took my chance,’ said

label: l>Line
line: the Russian. ‘Oh, he is bad, very bad.’ I directed my glass to the house. There

label: l>Line
line: were no signs of life, but there was the ruined roof, the long mud wall peeping

label: l>Line
line: above the grass, with three little square window-holes, no two of the same size;

label: l>Line
line: all this brought within reach of my hand, as it were. And then I made a brusque

label: l>Line
line: movement, and one of the remaining posts of that vanished fence leaped up in the

label: l>Line
line: field of my glass. You remember I told you I had been struck at the distance by

label: l>Line
line: certain attempts at ornamentation, rather remarkable in the ruinous aspect of

label: l>Line
line: the place. Now I had suddenly a nearer view, and its first result was to make me

label: l>Line
line: throw my head back as if before a blow. Then I went carefully from post to post

label: l>Line
line: with my glass, and I saw my mistake.  These round knobs were not ornamental but

label: l>Line
line: symbolic; they were expressive and puzzling, striking and disturbing—food for

label: l>Line
line: thought and also for vultures if there had been any looking down from the sky;

label: l>Line
line: but at all events for such ants as were industrious enough to ascend the pole.

label: l>Line
line: They would have been even more impressive, those heads on the stakes, if their

label: l>Line
line: faces had not been turned to the house. Only one, the first I had made out, was

label: l>Line
line: facing my way. I was not so shocked as you may think. The start back I had given

label: l>Line
line: was really nothing but a movement of surprise. I had expected to see a knob of

label: l>Line
line: wood there, you know. I returned deliberately to the first I had seen—and there

label: l>Line
line: it was, black, dried, sunken, with closed eyelids—a head that seemed to sleep at

label: l>Line
line: the top of that pole, and, with the shrunken dry lips showing a narrow white

label: l>Line
line: line of the teeth, was smiling, too, smiling continuously at some endless and

label: ll>Last Line
line: jocose dream of that eternal slumber.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I am not disclosing any trade secrets. In fact, the manager said afterwards

label: l>Line
line: that Mr. Kurtz’s methods had ruined the district. I have no opinion on that

label: l>Line
line: point, but I want you clearly to understand that there was nothing exactly

label: l>Line
line: profitable in these heads being there. They only showed that Mr. Kurtz lacked

label: l>Line
line: restraint in the gratification of his various lusts, that there was something

label: l>Line
line: wanting in him—some small matter which, when the pressing need arose, could not

label: l>Line
line: be found under his magnificent eloquence.  Whether he knew of this deficiency

label: l>Line
line: himself I can’t say. I think the knowledge came to him at last—only at the very

label: l>Line
line: last. But the wilderness had found him out early, and had taken on him a

label: l>Line
line: terrible vengeance for the fantastic invasion. I think it had whispered to him

label: l>Line
line: things about himself which he did not know, things of which he had no conception

label: l>Line
line: till he took counsel with this great solitude—and the whisper had proved

label: l>Line
line: irresistibly fascinating. It echoed loudly within him because he was hollow at

label: l>Line
line: the core.... I put down the glass, and the head that had appeared near enough to

label: l>Line
line: be spoken to seemed at once to have leaped away from me into inaccessible

label: ll>Last Line
line: distance.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The admirer of Mr. Kurtz was a bit crestfallen. In a hurried, indistinct voice

label: l>Line
line: he began to assure me he had not dared to take these—say, symbols—down. He was

label: l>Line
line: not afraid of the natives; they would not stir till Mr. Kurtz gave the word. His

label: l>Line
line: ascendancy was extraordinary. The camps of these people surrounded the place,

label: l>Line
line: and the chiefs came every day to see him. They would crawl.... ‘I don’t want to

label: l>Line
line: know anything of the ceremonies used when approaching Mr. Kurtz,’ I shouted.

label: l>Line
line: Curious, this feeling that came over me that such details would be more

label: l>Line
line: intolerable than those heads drying on the stakes under Mr. Kurtz’s windows.

label: l>Line
line: After all, that was only a savage sight, while I seemed at one bound to have

label: l>Line
line: been transported into some lightless region of subtle horrors, where pure,

label: l>Line
line: uncomplicated savagery was a positive relief, being something that had a right

label: l>Line
line: to exist—obviously—in the sunshine. The young man looked at me with surprise.  I

label: l>Line
line: suppose it did not occur to him that Mr. Kurtz was no idol of mine. He forgot I

label: l>Line
line: hadn’t heard any of these splendid monologues on, what was it? on love, justice,

label: l>Line
line: conduct of life—or what not. If it had come to crawling before Mr. Kurtz, he

label: l>Line
line: crawled as much as the veriest savage of them all.  I had no idea of the

label: l>Line
line: conditions, he said: these heads were the heads of rebels. I shocked him

label: l>Line
line: excessively by laughing. Rebels! What would be the next definition I was to

label: l>Line
line: hear? There had been enemies, criminals, workers—and these were rebels. Those

label: l>Line
line: rebellious heads looked very subdued to me on their sticks. ‘You don’t know how

label: l>Line
line: such a life tries a man like Kurtz,’ cried Kurtz’s last disciple. ‘Well, and

label: l>Line
line: you?’ I said. ‘I! I! I am a simple man. I have no great thoughts. I want nothing

label: l>Line
line: from anybody. How can you compare me to...?’ His feelings were too much for

label: l>Line
line: speech, and suddenly he broke down. ‘I don’t understand,’ he groaned. ‘I’ve been

label: l>Line
line: doing my best to keep him alive, and that’s enough. I had no hand in all this.

label: l>Line
line: I have no abilities. There hasn’t been a drop of medicine or a mouthful of

label: l>Line
line: invalid food for months here. He was shamefully abandoned. A man like this, with

label: l>Line
line: such ideas. Shamefully! Shamefully! I—I—haven’t slept for the last ten

label: ll>Last Line
line: nights...’

label: fl>First Line
line: “His voice lost itself in the calm of the evening. The long shadows of the

label: l>Line
line: forest had slipped downhill while we talked, had gone far beyond the ruined

label: l>Line
line: hovel, beyond the symbolic row of stakes. All this was in the gloom, while we

label: l>Line
line: down there were yet in the sunshine, and the stretch of the river abreast of the

label: l>Line
line: clearing glittered in a still and dazzling splendour, with a murky and

label: l>Line
line: overshadowed bend above and below. Not a living soul was seen on the shore. The

label: ll>Last Line
line: bushes did not rustle.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Suddenly round the corner of the house a group of men appeared, as though they

label: l>Line
line: had come up from the ground. They waded waist-deep in the grass, in a compact

label: l>Line
line: body, bearing an improvised stretcher in their midst. Instantly, in the

label: l>Line
line: emptiness of the landscape, a cry arose whose shrillness pierced the still air

label: l>Line
line: like a sharp arrow flying straight to the very heart of the land; and, as if by

label: l>Line
line: enchantment, streams of human beings—of naked human beings—with spears in their

label: l>Line
line: hands, with bows, with shields, with wild glances and savage movements, were

label: l>Line
line: poured into the clearing by the dark-faced and pensive forest. The bushes shook,

label: l>Line
line: the grass swayed for a time, and then everything stood still in attentive

label: ll>Last Line
line: immobility.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Now, if he does not say the right thing to them we are all done for,’ said the

label: l>Line
line: Russian at my elbow. The knot of men with the stretcher had stopped, too,

label: l>Line
line: halfway to the steamer, as if petrified. I saw the man on the stretcher sit up,

label: l>Line
line: lank and with an uplifted arm, above the shoulders of the bearers. ‘Let us hope

label: l>Line
line: that the man who can talk so well of love in general will find some particular

label: l>Line
line: reason to spare us this time,’ I said. I resented bitterly the absurd danger of

label: l>Line
line: our situation, as if to be at the mercy of that atrocious phantom had been a

label: l>Line
line: dishonouring necessity. I could not hear a sound, but through my glasses I saw

label: l>Line
line: the thin arm extended commandingly, the lower jaw moving, the eyes of that

label: l>Line
line: apparition shining darkly far in its bony head that nodded with grotesque jerks.

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz—Kurtz—that means short in German—don’t it? Well, the name was as true as

label: l>Line
line: everything else in his life—and death. He looked at least seven feet long. His

label: l>Line
line: covering had fallen off, and his body emerged from it pitiful and appalling as

label: l>Line
line: from a winding-sheet. I could see the cage of his ribs all astir, the bones of

label: l>Line
line: his arm waving. It was as though an animated image of death carved out of old

label: l>Line
line: ivory had been shaking its hand with menaces at a motionless crowd of men made

label: l>Line
line: of dark and glittering bronze. I saw him open his mouth wide—it gave him a

label: l>Line
line: weirdly voracious aspect, as though he had wanted to swallow all the air, all

label: l>Line
line: the earth, all the men before him. A deep voice reached me faintly. He must have

label: l>Line
line: been shouting. He fell back suddenly. The stretcher shook as the bearers

label: l>Line
line: staggered forward again, and almost at the same time I noticed that the crowd of

label: l>Line
line: savages was vanishing without any perceptible movement of retreat, as if the

label: l>Line
line: forest that had ejected these beings so suddenly had drawn them in again as the

label: ll>Last Line
line: breath is drawn in a long aspiration.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Some of the pilgrims behind the stretcher carried his arms—two shot-guns, a

label: l>Line
line: heavy rifle, and a light revolver-carbine—the thunderbolts of that pitiful

label: l>Line
line: Jupiter. The manager bent over him murmuring as he walked beside his head. They

label: l>Line
line: laid him down in one of the little cabins—just a room for a bed place and a

label: l>Line
line: camp-stool or two, you know. We had brought his belated correspondence, and a

label: l>Line
line: lot of torn envelopes and open letters littered his bed. His hand roamed feebly

label: l>Line
line: amongst these papers. I was struck by the fire of his eyes and the composed

label: l>Line
line: languor of his expression. It was not so much the exhaustion of disease. He did

label: l>Line
line: not seem in pain. This shadow looked satiated and calm, as though for the moment

label: ll>Last Line
line: it had had its fill of all the emotions.

label: fl>First Line
line: “He rustled one of the letters, and looking straight in my face said, ’I am

label: l>Line
line: glad.’ Somebody had been writing to him about me. These special recommendations

label: l>Line
line: were turning up again. The volume of tone he emitted without effort, almost

label: l>Line
line: without the trouble of moving his lips, amazed me.  A voice! a voice! It was

label: l>Line
line: grave, profound, vibrating, while the man did not seem capable of a whisper.

label: l>Line
line: However, he had enough strength in him—factitious no doubt—to very nearly make

label: ll>Last Line
line: an end of us, as you shall hear directly.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The manager appeared silently in the doorway; I stepped out at once and he drew

label: l>Line
line: the curtain after me. The Russian, eyed curiously by the pilgrims, was staring

label: ll>Last Line
line: at the shore. I followed the direction of his glance.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Dark human shapes could be made out in the distance, flitting indistinctly

label: l>Line
line: against the gloomy border of the forest, and near the river two bronze figures,

label: l>Line
line: leaning on tall spears, stood in the sunlight under fantastic head-dresses of

label: l>Line
line: spotted skins, warlike and still in statuesque repose. And from right to left

label: ll>Last Line
line: along the lighted shore moved a wild and gorgeous apparition of a woman.

label: fl>First Line
line: “She walked with measured steps, draped in striped and fringed cloths, treading

label: l>Line
line: the earth proudly, with a slight jingle and flash of barbarous ornaments. She

label: l>Line
line: carried her head high; her hair was done in the shape of a helmet; she had brass

label: l>Line
line: leggings to the knee, brass wire gauntlets to the elbow, a crimson spot on her

label: l>Line
line: tawny cheek, innumerable necklaces of glass beads on her neck; bizarre things,

label: l>Line
line: charms, gifts of witch-men, that hung about her, glittered and trembled at every

label: l>Line
line: step. She must have had the value of several elephant tusks upon her. She was

label: l>Line
line: savage and superb, wild-eyed and magnificent; there was something ominous and

label: l>Line
line: stately in her deliberate progress. And in the hush that had fallen suddenly

label: l>Line
line: upon the whole sorrowful land, the immense wilderness, the colossal body of the

label: l>Line
line: fecund and mysterious life seemed to look at her, pensive, as though it had been

label: ll>Last Line
line: looking at the image of its own tenebrous and passionate soul.

label: fl>First Line
line: “She came abreast of the steamer, stood still, and faced us. Her long shadow

label: l>Line
line: fell to the water’s edge. Her face had a tragic and fierce aspect of wild sorrow

label: l>Line
line: and of dumb pain mingled with the fear of some struggling, half-shaped resolve.

label: l>Line
line: She stood looking at us without a stir, and like the wilderness itself, with an

label: l>Line
line: air of brooding over an inscrutable purpose.  A whole minute passed, and then

label: l>Line
line: she made a step forward. There was a low jingle, a glint of yellow metal, a sway

label: l>Line
line: of fringed draperies, and she stopped as if her heart had failed her. The young

label: l>Line
line: fellow by my side growled. The pilgrims murmured at my back. She looked at us

label: l>Line
line: all as if her life had depended upon the unswerving steadiness of her glance.

label: l>Line
line: Suddenly she opened her bared arms and threw them up rigid above her head, as

label: l>Line
line: though in an uncontrollable desire to touch the sky, and at the same time the

label: l>Line
line: swift shadows darted out on the earth, swept around on the river, gathering the

label: ll>Last Line
line: steamer into a shadowy embrace. A formidable silence hung over the scene.

label: fl>First Line
line: “She turned away slowly, walked on, following the bank, and passed into the

label: l>Line
line: bushes to the left. Once only her eyes gleamed back at us in the dusk of the

label: ll>Last Line
line: thickets before she disappeared.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘If she had offered to come aboard I really think I would have tried to shoot

label: l>Line
line: her,’ said the man of patches, nervously. ‘I have been risking my life every day

label: l>Line
line: for the last fortnight to keep her out of the house. She got in one day and

label: l>Line
line: kicked up a row about those miserable rags I picked up in the storeroom to mend

label: l>Line
line: my clothes with. I wasn’t decent. At least it must have been that, for she

label: l>Line
line: talked like a fury to Kurtz for an hour, pointing at me now and then. I don’t

label: l>Line
line: understand the dialect of this tribe. Luckily for me, I fancy Kurtz felt too ill

label: l>Line
line: that day to care, or there would have been mischief. I don’t understand....

label: ll>Last Line
line: No—it’s too much for me. Ah, well, it’s all over now.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “At this moment I heard Kurtz’s deep voice behind the curtain: ‘Save me!—save

label: l>Line
line: the ivory, you mean. Don’t tell me. Save _me!_ Why, I’ve had to save you. You

label: l>Line
line: are interrupting my plans now. Sick! Sick! Not so sick as you would like to

label: l>Line
line: believe. Never mind. I’ll carry my ideas out yet—I will return. I’ll show you

label: l>Line
line: what can be done. You with your little peddling notions—you are interfering with

label: ll>Last Line
line: me. I will return. I....’

label: fl>First Line
line: “The manager came out. He did me the honour to take me under the arm and lead me

label: l>Line
line: aside. ‘He is very low, very low,’ he said. He considered it necessary to sigh,

label: l>Line
line: but neglected to be consistently sorrowful. ‘We have done all we could for

label: l>Line
line: him—haven’t we? But there is no disguising the fact, Mr. Kurtz has done more

label: l>Line
line: harm than good to the Company. He did not see the time was not ripe for vigorous

label: l>Line
line: action. Cautiously, cautiously—that’s my principle. We must be cautious yet. The

label: l>Line
line: district is closed to us for a time. Deplorable! Upon the whole, the trade will

label: l>Line
line: suffer. I don’t deny there is a remarkable quantity of ivory—mostly fossil. We

label: l>Line
line: must save it, at all events—but look how precarious the position is—and why?

label: l>Line
line: Because the method is unsound.’ ‘Do you,’ said I, looking at the shore, ‘call it

label: l>Line
line: ”unsound method?“’ ‘Without doubt,’ he exclaimed hotly. ‘Don’t you?’... ‘No

label: l>Line
line: method at all,’ I murmured after a while. ‘Exactly,’ he exulted. ‘I anticipated

label: l>Line
line: this. Shows a complete want of judgment. It is my duty to point it out in the

label: l>Line
line: proper quarter.’ ’Oh,’ said I, ‘that fellow—what’s his name?—the brickmaker,

label: l>Line
line: will make a readable report for you.’ He appeared confounded for a moment. It

label: l>Line
line: seemed to me I had never breathed an atmosphere so vile, and I turned mentally

label: l>Line
line: to Kurtz for relief—positively for relief.  ‘Nevertheless I think Mr. Kurtz is a

label: l>Line
line: remarkable man,’ I said with emphasis.  He started, dropped on me a heavy

label: l>Line
line: glance, said very quietly, ‘he _was_,’ and turned his back on me. My hour of

label: l>Line
line: favour was over; I found myself lumped along with Kurtz as a partisan of methods

label: l>Line
line: for which the time was not ripe: I was unsound! Ah! but it was something to have

label: ll>Last Line
line: at least a choice of nightmares.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I had turned to the wilderness really, not to Mr. Kurtz, who, I was ready to

label: l>Line
line: admit, was as good as buried. And for a moment it seemed to me as if I also were

label: l>Line
line: buried in a vast grave full of unspeakable secrets. I felt an intolerable weight

label: l>Line
line: oppressing my breast, the smell of the damp earth, the unseen presence of

label: l>Line
line: victorious corruption, the darkness of an impenetrable night.... The Russian

label: l>Line
line: tapped me on the shoulder. I heard him mumbling and stammering something about

label: l>Line
line: ‘brother seaman—couldn’t conceal—knowledge of matters that would affect Mr.

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz’s reputation.’ I waited. For him evidently Mr. Kurtz was not in his grave;

label: l>Line
line: I suspect that for him Mr. Kurtz was one of the immortals. ‘Well!’ said I at

label: ll>Last Line
line: last, ‘speak out. As it happens, I am Mr. Kurtz’s friend—in a way.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “He stated with a good deal of formality that had we not been ‘of the same

label: l>Line
line: profession,’ he would have kept the matter to himself without regard to

label: l>Line
line: consequences. ‘He suspected there was an active ill-will towards him on the part

label: l>Line
line: of these white men that—’ ‘You are right,’ I said, remembering a certain

label: l>Line
line: conversation I had overheard. ‘The manager thinks you ought to be hanged.’ He

label: l>Line
line: showed a concern at this intelligence which amused me at first.  ‘I had better

label: l>Line
line: get out of the way quietly,’ he said earnestly. ‘I can do no more for Kurtz now,

label: l>Line
line: and they would soon find some excuse. What’s to stop them? There’s a military

label: l>Line
line: post three hundred miles from here.’ ‘Well, upon my word,’ said I, ‘perhaps you

label: l>Line
line: had better go if you have any friends amongst the savages near by.’ ’Plenty,’ he

label: l>Line
line: said. ‘They are simple people—and I want nothing, you know.’ He stood biting his

label: l>Line
line: lip, then: ‘I don’t want any harm to happen to these whites here, but of course

label: l>Line
line: I was thinking of Mr. Kurtz’s reputation—but you are a brother seaman and—’ ‘All

label: l>Line
line: right,’ said I, after a time. ‘Mr. Kurtz’s reputation is safe with me.’ I did

label: ll>Last Line
line: not know how truly I spoke.

label: fl>First Line
line: “He informed me, lowering his voice, that it was Kurtz who had ordered the

label: l>Line
line: attack to be made on the steamer. ‘He hated sometimes the idea of being taken

label: l>Line
line: away—and then again.... But I don’t understand these matters. I am a simple man.

label: l>Line
line: He thought it would scare you away—that you would give it up, thinking him dead.

label: l>Line
line: I could not stop him. Oh, I had an awful time of it this last month.’ ‘Very

label: l>Line
line: well,’ I said. ‘He is all right now.’ ‘Ye-e-es,’ he muttered, not very convinced

label: l>Line
line: apparently. ‘Thanks,’ said I; ‘I shall keep my eyes open.’ ‘But quiet-eh?’ he

label: l>Line
line: urged anxiously. ’It would be awful for his reputation if anybody here—’ I

label: l>Line
line: promised a complete discretion with great gravity. ‘I have a canoe and three

label: l>Line
line: black fellows waiting not very far. I am off. Could you give me a few

label: l>Line
line: Martini-Henry cartridges?’ I could, and did, with proper secrecy. He helped

label: l>Line
line: himself, with a wink at me, to a handful of my tobacco. ‘Between sailors—you

label: l>Line
line: know—good English tobacco.’ At the door of the pilot-house he turned round—‘I

label: l>Line
line: say, haven’t you a pair of shoes you could spare?’ He raised one leg. ‘Look.’

label: l>Line
line: The soles were tied with knotted strings sandalwise under his bare feet. I

label: l>Line
line: rooted out an old pair, at which he looked with admiration before tucking it

label: l>Line
line: under his left arm. One of his pockets (bright red) was bulging with cartridges,

label: l>Line
line: from the other (dark blue) peeped ‘Towson’s Inquiry,’ etc., etc. He seemed to

label: l>Line
line: think himself excellently well equipped for a renewed encounter with the

label: l>Line
line: wilderness.  ’Ah! I’ll never, never meet such a man again. You ought to have

label: l>Line
line: heard him recite poetry—his own, too, it was, he told me. Poetry!’ He rolled his

label: l>Line
line: eyes at the recollection of these delights. ‘Oh, he enlarged my mind!’

label: l>Line
line: ‘Good-bye,’ said I. He shook hands and vanished in the night. Sometimes I ask

label: l>Line
line: myself whether I had ever really seen him—whether it was possible to meet such a

label: ll>Last Line
line: phenomenon!...

label: fl>First Line
line: “When I woke up shortly after midnight his warning came to my mind with its hint

label: l>Line
line: of danger that seemed, in the starred darkness, real enough to make me get up

label: l>Line
line: for the purpose of having a look round. On the hill a big fire burned,

label: l>Line
line: illuminating fitfully a crooked corner of the station-house. One of the agents

label: l>Line
line: with a picket of a few of our blacks, armed for the purpose, was keeping guard

label: l>Line
line: over the ivory; but deep within the forest, red gleams that wavered, that seemed

label: l>Line
line: to sink and rise from the ground amongst confused columnar shapes of intense

label: l>Line
line: blackness, showed the exact position of the camp where Mr. Kurtz’s adorers were

label: l>Line
line: keeping their uneasy vigil. The monotonous beating of a big drum filled the air

label: l>Line
line: with muffled shocks and a lingering vibration. A steady droning sound of many

label: l>Line
line: men chanting each to himself some weird incantation came out from the black,

label: l>Line
line: flat wall of the woods as the humming of bees comes out of a hive, and had a

label: l>Line
line: strange narcotic effect upon my half-awake senses. I believe I dozed off leaning

label: l>Line
line: over the rail, till an abrupt burst of yells, an overwhelming outbreak of a

label: l>Line
line: pent-up and mysterious frenzy, woke me up in a bewildered wonder. It was cut

label: l>Line
line: short all at once, and the low droning went on with an effect of audible and

label: l>Line
line: soothing silence.  I glanced casually into the little cabin. A light was burning

label: ll>Last Line
line: within, but Mr. Kurtz was not there.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I think I would have raised an outcry if I had believed my eyes. But I didn’t

label: l>Line
line: believe them at first—the thing seemed so impossible. The fact is I was

label: l>Line
line: completely unnerved by a sheer blank fright, pure abstract terror, unconnected

label: l>Line
line: with any distinct shape of physical danger. What made this emotion so

label: l>Line
line: overpowering was—how shall I define it?—the moral shock I received, as if

label: l>Line
line: something altogether monstrous, intolerable to thought and odious to the soul,

label: l>Line
line: had been thrust upon me unexpectedly. This lasted of course the merest fraction

label: l>Line
line: of a second, and then the usual sense of commonplace, deadly danger, the

label: l>Line
line: possibility of a sudden onslaught and massacre, or something of the kind, which

label: l>Line
line: I saw impending, was positively welcome and composing. It pacified me, in fact,

label: ll>Last Line
line: so much that I did not raise an alarm.

label: fl>First Line
line: “There was an agent buttoned up inside an ulster and sleeping on a chair on deck

label: l>Line
line: within three feet of me. The yells had not awakened him; he snored very

label: l>Line
line: slightly; I left him to his slumbers and leaped ashore. I did not betray Mr.

label: l>Line
line: Kurtz—it was ordered I should never betray him—it was written I should be loyal

label: l>Line
line: to the nightmare of my choice. I was anxious to deal with this shadow by myself

label: l>Line
line: alone—and to this day I don’t know why I was so jealous of sharing with any one

label: ll>Last Line
line: the peculiar blackness of that experience.

label: fl>First Line
line: “As soon as I got on the bank I saw a trail—a broad trail through the grass. I

label: l>Line
line: remember the exultation with which I said to myself, ‘He can’t walk—he is

label: l>Line
line: crawling on all-fours—I’ve got him.’ The grass was wet with dew.  I strode

label: l>Line
line: rapidly with clenched fists. I fancy I had some vague notion of falling upon him

label: l>Line
line: and giving him a drubbing. I don’t know. I had some imbecile thoughts. The

label: l>Line
line: knitting old woman with the cat obtruded herself upon my memory as a most

label: l>Line
line: improper person to be sitting at the other end of such an affair. I saw a row of

label: l>Line
line: pilgrims squirting lead in the air out of Winchesters held to the hip. I thought

label: l>Line
line: I would never get back to the steamer, and imagined myself living alone and

label: l>Line
line: unarmed in the woods to an advanced age. Such silly things—you know. And I

label: l>Line
line: remember I confounded the beat of the drum with the beating of my heart, and was

label: ll>Last Line
line: pleased at its calm regularity.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I kept to the track though—then stopped to listen. The night was very clear; a

label: l>Line
line: dark blue space, sparkling with dew and starlight, in which black things stood

label: l>Line
line: very still. I thought I could see a kind of motion ahead of me. I was strangely

label: l>Line
line: cocksure of everything that night. I actually left the track and ran in a wide

label: l>Line
line: semicircle (I verily believe chuckling to myself) so as to get in front of that

label: l>Line
line: stir, of that motion I had seen—if indeed I had seen anything. I was

label: ll>Last Line
line: circumventing Kurtz as though it had been a boyish game.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I came upon him, and, if he had not heard me coming, I would have fallen over

label: l>Line
line: him, too, but he got up in time. He rose, unsteady, long, pale, indistinct, like

label: l>Line
line: a vapour exhaled by the earth, and swayed slightly, misty and silent before me;

label: l>Line
line: while at my back the fires loomed between the trees, and the murmur of many

label: l>Line
line: voices issued from the forest. I had cut him off cleverly; but when actually

label: l>Line
line: confronting him I seemed to come to my senses, I saw the danger in its right

label: l>Line
line: proportion. It was by no means over yet.  Suppose he began to shout? Though he

label: l>Line
line: could hardly stand, there was still plenty of vigour in his voice. ‘Go away—hide

label: l>Line
line: yourself,’ he said, in that profound tone. It was very awful. I glanced back. We

label: l>Line
line: were within thirty yards from the nearest fire. A black figure stood up, strode

label: l>Line
line: on long black legs, waving long black arms, across the glow. It had

label: l>Line
line: horns—antelope horns, I think—on its head. Some sorcerer, some witch-man, no

label: l>Line
line: doubt: it looked fiendlike enough. ‘Do you know what you are doing?’ I

label: l>Line
line: whispered.  ‘Perfectly,’ he answered, raising his voice for that single word: it

label: l>Line
line: sounded to me far off and yet loud, like a hail through a speaking-trumpet.  ‘If

label: l>Line
line: he makes a row we are lost,’ I thought to myself. This clearly was not a case

label: l>Line
line: for fisticuffs, even apart from the very natural aversion I had to beat that

label: l>Line
line: Shadow—this wandering and tormented thing. ‘You will be lost,’ I said—‘utterly

label: l>Line
line: lost.’ One gets sometimes such a flash of inspiration, you know. I did say the

label: l>Line
line: right thing, though indeed he could not have been more irretrievably lost than

label: l>Line
line: he was at this very moment, when the foundations of our intimacy were being

label: ll>Last Line
line: laid—to endure—to endure—even to the end—even beyond.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘I had immense plans,’ he muttered irresolutely. ‘Yes,’ said I; ‘but if you try

label: l>Line
line: to shout I’ll smash your head with—’ There was not a stick or a stone near. ‘I

label: l>Line
line: will throttle you for good,’ I corrected myself. ‘I was on the threshold of

label: l>Line
line: great things,’ he pleaded, in a voice of longing, with a wistfulness of tone

label: l>Line
line: that made my blood run cold. ‘And now for this stupid scoundrel—’ ‘Your success

label: l>Line
line: in Europe is assured in any case,’ I affirmed steadily. I did not want to have

label: l>Line
line: the throttling of him, you understand—and indeed it would have been very little

label: l>Line
line: use for any practical purpose.  I tried to break the spell—the heavy, mute spell

label: l>Line
line: of the wilderness—that seemed to draw him to its pitiless breast by the

label: l>Line
line: awakening of forgotten and brutal instincts, by the memory of gratified and

label: l>Line
line: monstrous passions. This alone, I was convinced, had driven him out to the edge

label: l>Line
line: of the forest, to the bush, towards the gleam of fires, the throb of drums, the

label: l>Line
line: drone of weird incantations; this alone had beguiled his unlawful soul beyond

label: l>Line
line: the bounds of permitted aspirations. And, don’t you see, the terror of the

label: l>Line
line: position was not in being knocked on the head—though I had a very lively sense

label: l>Line
line: of that danger, too—but in this, that I had to deal with a being to whom I could

label: l>Line
line: not appeal in the name of anything high or low. I had, even like the niggers, to

label: l>Line
line: invoke him—himself—his own exalted and incredible degradation. There was nothing

label: l>Line
line: either above or below him, and I knew it. He had kicked himself loose of the

label: l>Line
line: earth. Confound the man! he had kicked the very earth to pieces. He was alone,

label: l>Line
line: and I before him did not know whether I stood on the ground or floated in the

label: l>Line
line: air. I’ve been telling you what we said—repeating the phrases we pronounced—but

label: l>Line
line: what’s the good? They were common everyday words—the familiar, vague sounds

label: l>Line
line: exchanged on every waking day of life. But what of that? They had behind them,

label: l>Line
line: to my mind, the terrific suggestiveness of words heard in dreams, of phrases

label: l>Line
line: spoken in nightmares. Soul! If anybody ever struggled with a soul, I am the man.

label: l>Line
line: And I wasn’t arguing with a lunatic either. Believe me or not, his intelligence

label: l>Line
line: was perfectly clear—concentrated, it is true, upon himself with horrible

label: l>Line
line: intensity, yet clear; and therein was my only chance—barring, of course, the

label: l>Line
line: killing him there and then, which wasn’t so good, on account of unavoidable

label: l>Line
line: noise. But his soul was mad. Being alone in the wilderness, it had looked within

label: l>Line
line: itself, and, by heavens! I tell you, it had gone mad.  I had—for my sins, I

label: l>Line
line: suppose—to go through the ordeal of looking into it myself. No eloquence could

label: l>Line
line: have been so withering to one’s belief in mankind as his final burst of

label: l>Line
line: sincerity. He struggled with himself, too.  I saw it—I heard it. I saw the

label: l>Line
line: inconceivable mystery of a soul that knew no restraint, no faith, and no fear,

label: l>Line
line: yet struggling blindly with itself.  I kept my head pretty well; but when I had

label: l>Line
line: him at last stretched on the couch, I wiped my forehead, while my legs shook

label: l>Line
line: under me as though I had carried half a ton on my back down that hill. And yet I

label: l>Line
line: had only supported him, his bony arm clasped round my neck—and he was not much

label: ll>Last Line
line: heavier than a child.

label: fl>First Line
line: “When next day we left at noon, the crowd, of whose presence behind the curtain

label: l>Line
line: of trees I had been acutely conscious all the time, flowed out of the woods

label: l>Line
line: again, filled the clearing, covered the slope with a mass of naked, breathing,

label: l>Line
line: quivering, bronze bodies. I steamed up a bit, then swung down stream, and two

label: l>Line
line: thousand eyes followed the evolutions of the splashing, thumping, fierce

label: l>Line
line: river-demon beating the water with its terrible tail and breathing black smoke

label: l>Line
line: into the air. In front of the first rank, along the river, three men, plastered

label: l>Line
line: with bright red earth from head to foot, strutted to and fro restlessly. When we

label: l>Line
line: came abreast again, they faced the river, stamped their feet, nodded their

label: l>Line
line: horned heads, swayed their scarlet bodies; they shook towards the fierce

label: l>Line
line: river-demon a bunch of black feathers, a mangy skin with a pendent

label: l>Line
line: tail—something that looked a dried gourd; they shouted periodically together

label: l>Line
line: strings of amazing words that resembled no sounds of human language; and the

label: l>Line
line: deep murmurs of the crowd, interrupted suddenly, were like the responses of some

label: ll>Last Line
line: satanic litany.

label: fl>First Line
line: “We had carried Kurtz into the pilot-house: there was more air there.  Lying on

label: l>Line
line: the couch, he stared through the open shutter. There was an eddy in the mass of

label: l>Line
line: human bodies, and the woman with helmeted head and tawny cheeks rushed out to

label: l>Line
line: the very brink of the stream. She put out her hands, shouted something, and all

label: l>Line
line: that wild mob took up the shout in a roaring chorus of articulated, rapid,

label: ll>Last Line
line: breathless utterance.

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘Do you understand this?’ I asked.

label: fl>First Line
line: “He kept on looking out past me with fiery, longing eyes, with a mingled

label: l>Line
line: expression of wistfulness and hate. He made no answer, but I saw a smile, a

label: l>Line
line: smile of indefinable meaning, appear on his colourless lips that a moment after

label: l>Line
line: twitched convulsively. ‘Do I not?’ he said slowly, gasping, as if the words had

label: ll>Last Line
line: been torn out of him by a supernatural power.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I pulled the string of the whistle, and I did this because I saw the pilgrims

label: l>Line
line: on deck getting out their rifles with an air of anticipating a jolly lark. At

label: l>Line
line: the sudden screech there was a movement of abject terror through that wedged

label: l>Line
line: mass of bodies. ‘Don’t! don’t you frighten them away,’ cried some one on deck

label: l>Line
line: disconsolately. I pulled the string time after time.  They broke and ran, they

label: l>Line
line: leaped, they crouched, they swerved, they dodged the flying terror of the sound.

label: l>Line
line: The three red chaps had fallen flat, face down on the shore, as though they had

label: l>Line
line: been shot dead. Only the barbarous and superb woman did not so much as flinch,

label: l>Line
line: and stretched tragically her bare arms after us over the sombre and glittering

label: ll>Last Line
line: river.

label: fl>First Line
line: “And then that imbecile crowd down on the deck started their little fun, and I

label: ll>Last Line
line: could see nothing more for smoke.

label: fl>First Line
line: “The brown current ran swiftly out of the heart of darkness, bearing us down

label: l>Line
line: towards the sea with twice the speed of our upward progress; and Kurtz’s life

label: l>Line
line: was running swiftly, too, ebbing, ebbing out of his heart into the sea of

label: l>Line
line: inexorable time. The manager was very placid, he had no vital anxieties now, he

label: l>Line
line: took us both in with a comprehensive and satisfied glance: the ‘affair’ had come

label: l>Line
line: off as well as could be wished. I saw the time approaching when I would be left

label: l>Line
line: alone of the party of ’unsound method.’ The pilgrims looked upon me with

label: l>Line
line: disfavour. I was, so to speak, numbered with the dead. It is strange how I

label: l>Line
line: accepted this unforeseen partnership, this choice of nightmares forced upon me

label: ll>Last Line
line: in the tenebrous land invaded by these mean and greedy phantoms.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Kurtz discoursed. A voice! a voice! It rang deep to the very last. It survived

label: l>Line
line: his strength to hide in the magnificent folds of eloquence the barren darkness

label: l>Line
line: of his heart. Oh, he struggled! he struggled! The wastes of his weary brain were

label: l>Line
line: haunted by shadowy images now—images of wealth and fame revolving obsequiously

label: l>Line
line: round his unextinguishable gift of noble and lofty expression. My Intended, my

label: l>Line
line: station, my career, my ideas—these were the subjects for the occasional

label: l>Line
line: utterances of elevated sentiments. The shade of the original Kurtz frequented

label: l>Line
line: the bedside of the hollow sham, whose fate it was to be buried presently in the

label: l>Line
line: mould of primeval earth.  But both the diabolic love and the unearthly hate of

label: l>Line
line: the mysteries it had penetrated fought for the possession of that soul satiated

label: l>Line
line: with primitive emotions, avid of lying fame, of sham distinction, of all the

label: ll>Last Line
line: appearances of success and power.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Sometimes he was contemptibly childish. He desired to have kings meet him at

label: l>Line
line: railway-stations on his return from some ghastly Nowhere, where he intended to

label: l>Line
line: accomplish great things. ‘You show them you have in you something that is really

label: l>Line
line: profitable, and then there will be no limits to the recognition of your

label: l>Line
line: ability,’ he would say. ‘Of course you must take care of the motives—right

label: l>Line
line: motives—always.’ The long reaches that were like one and the same reach,

label: l>Line
line: monotonous bends that were exactly alike, slipped past the steamer with their

label: l>Line
line: multitude of secular trees looking patiently after this grimy fragment of

label: l>Line
line: another world, the forerunner of change, of conquest, of trade, of massacres, of

label: l>Line
line: blessings. I looked ahead—piloting.  ‘Close the shutter,’ said Kurtz suddenly

label: l>Line
line: one day; ‘I can’t bear to look at this.’ I did so. There was a silence. ‘Oh, but

label: ll>Last Line
line: I will wring your heart yet!’ he cried at the invisible wilderness.

label: fl>First Line
line: “We broke down—as I had expected—and had to lie up for repairs at the head of an

label: l>Line
line: island. This delay was the first thing that shook Kurtz’s confidence.  One

label: l>Line
line: morning he gave me a packet of papers and a photograph—the lot tied together

label: l>Line
line: with a shoe-string. ‘Keep this for me,’ he said. ‘This noxious fool’ (meaning

label: l>Line
line: the manager) ‘is capable of prying into my boxes when I am not looking.’ In the

label: l>Line
line: afternoon I saw him. He was lying on his back with closed eyes, and I withdrew

label: l>Line
line: quietly, but I heard him mutter, ‘Live rightly, die, die...’ I listened. There

label: l>Line
line: was nothing more. Was he rehearsing some speech in his sleep, or was it a

label: l>Line
line: fragment of a phrase from some newspaper article? He had been writing for the

label: ll>Last Line
line: papers and meant to do so again, ‘for the furthering of my ideas. It’s a duty.’
