label: fl>First Line
line: “His was an impenetrable darkness. I looked at him as you peer down at a man who

label: l>Line
line: is lying at the bottom of a precipice where the sun never shines.  But I had not

label: l>Line
line: much time to give him, because I was helping the engine-driver to take to pieces

label: l>Line
line: the leaky cylinders, to straighten a bent connecting-rod, and in other such

label: l>Line
line: matters. I lived in an infernal mess of rust, filings, nuts, bolts, spanners,

label: l>Line
line: hammers, ratchet-drills—things I abominate, because I don’t get on with them. I

label: l>Line
line: tended the little forge we fortunately had aboard; I toiled wearily in a

label: ll>Last Line
line: wretched scrap-heap—unless I had the shakes too bad to stand.

label: fl>First Line
line: “One evening coming in with a candle I was startled to hear him say a little

label: l>Line
line: tremulously, ‘I am lying here in the dark waiting for death.’ The light was

label: l>Line
line: within a foot of his eyes. I forced myself to murmur, ‘Oh, nonsense!’ and stood

label: ll>Last Line
line: over him as if transfixed.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Anything approaching the change that came over his features I have never seen

label: l>Line
line: before, and hope never to see again. Oh, I wasn’t touched. I was fascinated. It

label: l>Line
line: was as though a veil had been rent. I saw on that ivory face the expression of

label: l>Line
line: sombre pride, of ruthless power, of craven terror—of an intense and hopeless

label: l>Line
line: despair. Did he live his life again in every detail of desire, temptation, and

label: l>Line
line: surrender during that supreme moment of complete knowledge? He cried in a

label: l>Line
line: whisper at some image, at some vision—he cried out twice, a cry that was no more

label: ll>Last Line
line: than a breath:

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘The horror! The horror!’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I blew the candle out and left the cabin. The pilgrims were dining in the

label: l>Line
line: mess-room, and I took my place opposite the manager, who lifted his eyes to give

label: l>Line
line: me a questioning glance, which I successfully ignored. He leaned back, serene,

label: l>Line
line: with that peculiar smile of his sealing the unexpressed depths of his meanness.

label: l>Line
line: A continuous shower of small flies streamed upon the lamp, upon the cloth, upon

label: l>Line
line: our hands and faces. Suddenly the manager’s boy put his insolent black head in

label: ll>Last Line
line: the doorway, and said in a tone of scathing contempt:

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘Mistah Kurtz—he dead.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “All the pilgrims rushed out to see. I remained, and went on with my dinner. I

label: l>Line
line: believe I was considered brutally callous. However, I did not eat much. There

label: l>Line
line: was a lamp in there—light, don’t you know—and outside it was so beastly, beastly

label: l>Line
line: dark. I went no more near the remarkable man who had pronounced a judgment upon

label: l>Line
line: the adventures of his soul on this earth. The voice was gone. What else had been

label: l>Line
line: there? But I am of course aware that next day the pilgrims buried something in a

label: ll>Last Line
line: muddy hole.

label: sl>Single Line
line: “And then they very nearly buried me.

label: fl>First Line
line: “However, as you see, I did not go to join Kurtz there and then. I did not.  I

label: l>Line
line: remained to dream the nightmare out to the end, and to show my loyalty to Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: once more. Destiny. My destiny! Droll thing life is—that mysterious arrangement

label: l>Line
line: of merciless logic for a futile purpose. The most you can hope from it is some

label: l>Line
line: knowledge of yourself—that comes too late—a crop of unextinguishable regrets. I

label: l>Line
line: have wrestled with death. It is the most unexciting contest you can imagine. It

label: l>Line
line: takes place in an impalpable greyness, with nothing underfoot, with nothing

label: l>Line
line: around, without spectators, without clamour, without glory, without the great

label: l>Line
line: desire of victory, without the great fear of defeat, in a sickly atmosphere of

label: l>Line
line: tepid scepticism, without much belief in your own right, and still less in that

label: l>Line
line: of your adversary. If such is the form of ultimate wisdom, then life is a

label: l>Line
line: greater riddle than some of us think it to be. I was within a hair’s breadth of

label: l>Line
line: the last opportunity for pronouncement, and I found with humiliation that

label: l>Line
line: probably I would have nothing to say. This is the reason why I affirm that Kurtz

label: l>Line
line: was a remarkable man. He had something to say. He said it. Since I had peeped

label: l>Line
line: over the edge myself, I understand better the meaning of his stare, that could

label: l>Line
line: not see the flame of the candle, but was wide enough to embrace the whole

label: l>Line
line: universe, piercing enough to penetrate all the hearts that beat in the darkness.

label: l>Line
line: He had summed up—he had judged. ‘The horror!’ He was a remarkable man. After

label: l>Line
line: all, this was the expression of some sort of belief; it had candour, it had

label: l>Line
line: conviction, it had a vibrating note of revolt in its whisper, it had the

label: l>Line
line: appalling face of a glimpsed truth—the strange commingling of desire and hate.

label: l>Line
line: And it is not my own extremity I remember best—a vision of greyness without form

label: l>Line
line: filled with physical pain, and a careless contempt for the evanescence of all

label: l>Line
line: things—even of this pain itself. No! It is his extremity that I seem to have

label: l>Line
line: lived through. True, he had made that last stride, he had stepped over the edge,

label: l>Line
line: while I had been permitted to draw back my hesitating foot. And perhaps in this

label: l>Line
line: is the whole difference; perhaps all the wisdom, and all truth, and all

label: l>Line
line: sincerity, are just compressed into that inappreciable moment of time in which

label: l>Line
line: we step over the threshold of the invisible.  Perhaps! I like to think my

label: l>Line
line: summing-up would not have been a word of careless contempt. Better his cry—much

label: l>Line
line: better. It was an affirmation, a moral victory paid for by innumerable defeats,

label: l>Line
line: by abominable terrors, by abominable satisfactions. But it was a victory! That

label: l>Line
line: is why I have remained loyal to Kurtz to the last, and even beyond, when a long

label: l>Line
line: time after I heard once more, not his own voice, but the echo of his magnificent

label: ll>Last Line
line: eloquence thrown to me from a soul as translucently pure as a cliff of crystal.

label: fl>First Line
line: “No, they did not bury me, though there is a period of time which I remember

label: l>Line
line: mistily, with a shuddering wonder, like a passage through some inconceivable

label: l>Line
line: world that had no hope in it and no desire. I found myself back in the

label: l>Line
line: sepulchral city resenting the sight of people hurrying through the streets to

label: l>Line
line: filch a little money from each other, to devour their infamous cookery, to gulp

label: l>Line
line: their unwholesome beer, to dream their insignificant and silly dreams. They

label: l>Line
line: trespassed upon my thoughts. They were intruders whose knowledge of life was to

label: l>Line
line: me an irritating pretence, because I felt so sure they could not possibly know

label: l>Line
line: the things I knew. Their bearing, which was simply the bearing of commonplace

label: l>Line
line: individuals going about their business in the assurance of perfect safety, was

label: l>Line
line: offensive to me like the outrageous flauntings of folly in the face of a danger

label: l>Line
line: it is unable to comprehend. I had no particular desire to enlighten them, but I

label: l>Line
line: had some difficulty in restraining myself from laughing in their faces so full

label: l>Line
line: of stupid importance. I daresay I was not very well at that time.  I tottered

label: l>Line
line: about the streets—there were various affairs to settle—grinning bitterly at

label: l>Line
line: perfectly respectable persons. I admit my behaviour was inexcusable, but then my

label: l>Line
line: temperature was seldom normal in these days. My dear aunt’s endeavours to ‘nurse

label: l>Line
line: up my strength’ seemed altogether beside the mark. It was not my strength that

label: l>Line
line: wanted nursing, it was my imagination that wanted soothing. I kept the bundle of

label: l>Line
line: papers given me by Kurtz, not knowing exactly what to do with it. His mother had

label: l>Line
line: died lately, watched over, as I was told, by his Intended. A clean-shaved man,

label: l>Line
line: with an official manner and wearing gold-rimmed spectacles, called on me one day

label: l>Line
line: and made inquiries, at first circuitous, afterwards suavely pressing, about what

label: l>Line
line: he was pleased to denominate certain ‘documents.’ I was not surprised, because I

label: l>Line
line: had had two rows with the manager on the subject out there. I had refused to

label: l>Line
line: give up the smallest scrap out of that package, and I took the same attitude

label: l>Line
line: with the spectacled man. He became darkly menacing at last, and with much heat

label: l>Line
line: argued that the Company had the right to every bit of information about its

label: l>Line
line: ‘territories.’ And said he, ‘Mr. Kurtz’s knowledge of unexplored regions must

label: l>Line
line: have been necessarily extensive and peculiar—owing to his great abilities and to

label: l>Line
line: the deplorable circumstances in which he had been placed: therefore—’ I assured

label: l>Line
line: him Mr. Kurtz’s knowledge, however extensive, did not bear upon the problems of

label: l>Line
line: commerce or administration. He invoked then the name of science. ‘It would be an

label: l>Line
line: incalculable loss if,’ etc., etc. I offered him the report on the ‘Suppression

label: l>Line
line: of Savage Customs,’ with the postscriptum torn off. He took it up eagerly, but

label: l>Line
line: ended by sniffing at it with an air of contempt. ‘This is not what we had a

label: l>Line
line: right to expect,’ he remarked. ’Expect nothing else,’ I said. ‘There are only

label: l>Line
line: private letters.’ He withdrew upon some threat of legal proceedings, and I saw

label: l>Line
line: him no more; but another fellow, calling himself Kurtz’s cousin, appeared two

label: l>Line
line: days later, and was anxious to hear all the details about his dear relative’s

label: l>Line
line: last moments. Incidentally he gave me to understand that Kurtz had been

label: l>Line
line: essentially a great musician. ‘There was the making of an immense success,’ said

label: l>Line
line: the man, who was an organist, I believe, with lank grey hair flowing over a

label: l>Line
line: greasy coat-collar. I had no reason to doubt his statement; and to this day I am

label: l>Line
line: unable to say what was Kurtz’s profession, whether he ever had any—which was the

label: l>Line
line: greatest of his talents. I had taken him for a painter who wrote for the papers,

label: l>Line
line: or else for a journalist who could paint—but even the cousin (who took snuff

label: l>Line
line: during the interview) could not tell me what he had been—exactly. He was a

label: l>Line
line: universal genius—on that point I agreed with the old chap, who thereupon blew

label: l>Line
line: his nose noisily into a large cotton handkerchief and withdrew in senile

label: l>Line
line: agitation, bearing off some family letters and memoranda without importance.

label: l>Line
line: Ultimately a journalist anxious to know something of the fate of his ‘dear

label: l>Line
line: colleague’ turned up. This visitor informed me Kurtz’s proper sphere ought to

label: l>Line
line: have been politics ‘on the popular side.’ He had furry straight eyebrows,

label: l>Line
line: bristly hair cropped short, an eyeglass on a broad ribbon, and, becoming

label: l>Line
line: expansive, confessed his opinion that Kurtz really couldn’t write a bit—‘but

label: l>Line
line: heavens! how that man could talk. He electrified large meetings.  He had

label: l>Line
line: faith—don’t you see?—he had the faith. He could get himself to believe

label: l>Line
line: anything—anything. He would have been a splendid leader of an extreme party.’

label: l>Line
line: ‘What party?’ I asked. ‘Any party,’ answered the other. ‘He was

label: l>Line
line: an—an—extremist.’ Did I not think so? I assented. Did I know, he asked, with a

label: l>Line
line: sudden flash of curiosity, ‘what it was that had induced him to go out there?’

label: l>Line
line: ‘Yes,’ said I, and forthwith handed him the famous Report for publication, if he

label: l>Line
line: thought fit. He glanced through it hurriedly, mumbling all the time, judged ‘it

label: ll>Last Line
line: would do,’ and took himself off with this plunder.

label: fl>First Line
line: “Thus I was left at last with a slim packet of letters and the girl’s portrait.

label: l>Line
line: She struck me as beautiful—I mean she had a beautiful expression.  I know that

label: l>Line
line: the sunlight can be made to lie, too, yet one felt that no manipulation of light

label: l>Line
line: and pose could have conveyed the delicate shade of truthfulness upon those

label: l>Line
line: features. She seemed ready to listen without mental reservation, without

label: l>Line
line: suspicion, without a thought for herself. I concluded I would go and give her

label: l>Line
line: back her portrait and those letters myself.  Curiosity? Yes; and also some other

label: l>Line
line: feeling perhaps. All that had been Kurtz’s had passed out of my hands: his soul,

label: l>Line
line: his body, his station, his plans, his ivory, his career. There remained only his

label: l>Line
line: memory and his Intended—and I wanted to give that up, too, to the past, in a

label: l>Line
line: way—to surrender personally all that remained of him with me to that oblivion

label: l>Line
line: which is the last word of our common fate. I don’t defend myself. I had no clear

label: l>Line
line: perception of what it was I really wanted. Perhaps it was an impulse of

label: l>Line
line: unconscious loyalty, or the fulfilment of one of those ironic necessities that

label: ll>Last Line
line: lurk in the facts of human existence. I don’t know.  I can’t tell. But I went.

label: fl>First Line
line: “I thought his memory was like the other memories of the dead that accumulate in

label: l>Line
line: every man’s life—a vague impress on the brain of shadows that had fallen on it

label: l>Line
line: in their swift and final passage; but before the high and ponderous door,

label: l>Line
line: between the tall houses of a street as still and decorous as a well-kept alley

label: l>Line
line: in a cemetery, I had a vision of him on the stretcher, opening his mouth

label: l>Line
line: voraciously, as if to devour all the earth with all its mankind. He lived then

label: l>Line
line: before me; he lived as much as he had ever lived—a shadow insatiable of splendid

label: l>Line
line: appearances, of frightful realities; a shadow darker than the shadow of the

label: l>Line
line: night, and draped nobly in the folds of a gorgeous eloquence. The vision seemed

label: l>Line
line: to enter the house with me—the stretcher, the phantom-bearers, the wild crowd of

label: l>Line
line: obedient worshippers, the gloom of the forests, the glitter of the reach between

label: l>Line
line: the murky bends, the beat of the drum, regular and muffled like the beating of a

label: l>Line
line: heart—the heart of a conquering darkness. It was a moment of triumph for the

label: l>Line
line: wilderness, an invading and vengeful rush which, it seemed to me, I would have

label: l>Line
line: to keep back alone for the salvation of another soul. And the memory of what I

label: l>Line
line: had heard him say afar there, with the horned shapes stirring at my back, in the

label: l>Line
line: glow of fires, within the patient woods, those broken phrases came back to me,

label: l>Line
line: were heard again in their ominous and terrifying simplicity.  I remembered his

label: l>Line
line: abject pleading, his abject threats, the colossal scale of his vile desires, the

label: l>Line
line: meanness, the torment, the tempestuous anguish of his soul. And later on I

label: l>Line
line: seemed to see his collected languid manner, when he said one day, ‘This lot of

label: l>Line
line: ivory now is really mine. The Company did not pay for it. I collected it myself

label: l>Line
line: at a very great personal risk. I am afraid they will try to claim it as theirs

label: l>Line
line: though. H’m. It is a difficult case. What do you think I ought to do—resist? Eh?

label: l>Line
line: I want no more than justice.’... He wanted no more than justice—no more than

label: l>Line
line: justice. I rang the bell before a mahogany door on the first floor, and while I

label: l>Line
line: waited he seemed to stare at me out of the glassy panel—stare with that wide and

label: l>Line
line: immense stare embracing, condemning, loathing all the universe. I seemed to hear

label: ll>Last Line
line: the whispered cry, ‘The horror! The horror!’

label: fl>First Line
line: “The dusk was falling. I had to wait in a lofty drawing-room with three long

label: l>Line
line: windows from floor to ceiling that were like three luminous and bedraped

label: l>Line
line: columns. The bent gilt legs and backs of the furniture shone in indistinct

label: l>Line
line: curves. The tall marble fireplace had a cold and monumental whiteness. A grand

label: l>Line
line: piano stood massively in a corner; with dark gleams on the flat surfaces like a

label: ll>Last Line
line: sombre and polished sarcophagus. A high door opened—closed. I rose.

label: fl>First Line
line: “She came forward, all in black, with a pale head, floating towards me in the

label: l>Line
line: dusk. She was in mourning. It was more than a year since his death, more than a

label: l>Line
line: year since the news came; she seemed as though she would remember and mourn

label: l>Line
line: forever. She took both my hands in hers and murmured, ‘I had heard you were

label: l>Line
line: coming.’ I noticed she was not very young—I mean not girlish. She had a mature

label: l>Line
line: capacity for fidelity, for belief, for suffering.  The room seemed to have grown

label: l>Line
line: darker, as if all the sad light of the cloudy evening had taken refuge on her

label: l>Line
line: forehead. This fair hair, this pale visage, this pure brow, seemed surrounded by

label: l>Line
line: an ashy halo from which the dark eyes looked out at me. Their glance was

label: l>Line
line: guileless, profound, confident, and trustful. She carried her sorrowful head as

label: l>Line
line: though she were proud of that sorrow, as though she would say, ’I—I alone know

label: l>Line
line: how to mourn for him as he deserves.’ But while we were still shaking hands,

label: l>Line
line: such a look of awful desolation came upon her face that I perceived she was one

label: l>Line
line: of those creatures that are not the playthings of Time. For her he had died only

label: l>Line
line: yesterday. And, by Jove! the impression was so powerful that for me, too, he

label: l>Line
line: seemed to have died only yesterday—nay, this very minute. I saw her and him in

label: l>Line
line: the same instant of time—his death and her sorrow—I saw her sorrow in the very

label: l>Line
line: moment of his death. Do you understand? I saw them together—I heard them

label: l>Line
line: together. She had said, with a deep catch of the breath, ‘I have survived’ while

label: l>Line
line: my strained ears seemed to hear distinctly, mingled with her tone of despairing

label: l>Line
line: regret, the summing up whisper of his eternal condemnation. I asked myself what

label: l>Line
line: I was doing there, with a sensation of panic in my heart as though I had

label: l>Line
line: blundered into a place of cruel and absurd mysteries not fit for a human being

label: l>Line
line: to behold. She motioned me to a chair. We sat down. I laid the packet gently on

label: l>Line
line: the little table, and she put her hand over it.... ‘You knew him well,’ she

label: ll>Last Line
line: murmured, after a moment of mourning silence.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Intimacy grows quickly out there,’ I said. ‘I knew him as well as it is

label: ll>Last Line
line: possible for one man to know another.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘And you admired him,’ she said. ‘It was impossible to know him and not to

label: ll>Last Line
line: admire him. Was it?’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘He was a remarkable man,’ I said, unsteadily. Then before the appealing fixity

label: l>Line
line: of her gaze, that seemed to watch for more words on my lips, I went on, ‘It was

label: ll>Last Line
line: impossible not to—’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Love him,’ she finished eagerly, silencing me into an appalled dumbness.  ‘How

label: l>Line
line: true! how true! But when you think that no one knew him so well as I!  I had all

label: ll>Last Line
line: his noble confidence. I knew him best.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘You knew him best,’ I repeated. And perhaps she did. But with every word

label: l>Line
line: spoken the room was growing darker, and only her forehead, smooth and white,

label: ll>Last Line
line: remained illumined by the inextinguishable light of belief and love.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘You were his friend,’ she went on. ‘His friend,’ she repeated, a little

label: l>Line
line: louder. ‘You must have been, if he had given you this, and sent you to me.  I

label: l>Line
line: feel I can speak to you—and oh! I must speak. I want you—you who have heard his

label: l>Line
line: last words—to know I have been worthy of him.... It is not pride.... Yes! I am

label: l>Line
line: proud to know I understood him better than any one on earth—he told me so

label: ll>Last Line
line: himself. And since his mother died I have had no one—no one—to—to—’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I listened. The darkness deepened. I was not even sure whether he had given me

label: l>Line
line: the right bundle. I rather suspect he wanted me to take care of another batch of

label: l>Line
line: his papers which, after his death, I saw the manager examining under the lamp.

label: l>Line
line: And the girl talked, easing her pain in the certitude of my sympathy; she talked

label: l>Line
line: as thirsty men drink. I had heard that her engagement with Kurtz had been

label: l>Line
line: disapproved by her people. He wasn’t rich enough or something. And indeed I

label: l>Line
line: don’t know whether he had not been a pauper all his life. He had given me some

label: l>Line
line: reason to infer that it was his impatience of comparative poverty that drove him

label: ll>Last Line
line: out there.

label: fl>First Line
line: “’... Who was not his friend who had heard him speak once?’ she was saying.  ‘He

label: l>Line
line: drew men towards him by what was best in them.’ She looked at me with intensity.

label: l>Line
line: ‘It is the gift of the great,’ she went on, and the sound of her low voice

label: l>Line
line: seemed to have the accompaniment of all the other sounds, full of mystery,

label: l>Line
line: desolation, and sorrow, I had ever heard—the ripple of the river, the soughing

label: l>Line
line: of the trees swayed by the wind, the murmurs of the crowds, the faint ring of

label: l>Line
line: incomprehensible words cried from afar, the whisper of a voice speaking from

label: l>Line
line: beyond the threshold of an eternal darkness. ‘But you have heard him! You know!’

label: ll>Last Line
line: she cried.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Yes, I know,’ I said with something like despair in my heart, but bowing my

label: l>Line
line: head before the faith that was in her, before that great and saving illusion

label: l>Line
line: that shone with an unearthly glow in the darkness, in the triumphant darkness

label: l>Line
line: from which I could not have defended her—from which I could not even defend

label: ll>Last Line
line: myself.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘What a loss to me—to us!‘—she corrected herself with beautiful generosity;

label: l>Line
line: then added in a murmur, ‘To the world.’ By the last gleams of twilight I could

label: ll>Last Line
line: see the glitter of her eyes, full of tears—of tears that would not fall.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘I have been very happy—very fortunate—very proud,’ she went on. ‘Too

label: ll>Last Line
line: fortunate. Too happy for a little while. And now I am unhappy for—for life.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “She stood up; her fair hair seemed to catch all the remaining light in a

label: ll>Last Line
line: glimmer of gold. I rose, too.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘And of all this,’ she went on mournfully, ‘of all his promise, and of all his

label: l>Line
line: greatness, of his generous mind, of his noble heart, nothing remains—nothing but

label: ll>Last Line
line: a memory. You and I—’

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘We shall always remember him,’ I said hastily.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘No!’ she cried. ‘It is impossible that all this should be lost—that such a

label: l>Line
line: life should be sacrificed to leave nothing—but sorrow. You know what vast plans

label: l>Line
line: he had. I knew of them, too—I could not perhaps understand—but others knew of

label: ll>Last Line
line: them. Something must remain. His words, at least, have not died.’

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘His words will remain,’ I said.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘And his example,’ she whispered to herself. ‘Men looked up to him—his goodness

label: ll>Last Line
line: shone in every act. His example—’

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘True,’ I said; ‘his example, too. Yes, his example. I forgot that.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘But I do not. I cannot—I cannot believe—not yet. I cannot believe that I shall

label: ll>Last Line
line: never see him again, that nobody will see him again, never, never, never.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “She put out her arms as if after a retreating figure, stretching them back and

label: l>Line
line: with clasped pale hands across the fading and narrow sheen of the window. Never

label: l>Line
line: see him! I saw him clearly enough then. I shall see this eloquent phantom as

label: l>Line
line: long as I live, and I shall see her, too, a tragic and familiar Shade,

label: l>Line
line: resembling in this gesture another one, tragic also, and bedecked with powerless

label: l>Line
line: charms, stretching bare brown arms over the glitter of the infernal stream, the

label: ll>Last Line
line: stream of darkness. She said suddenly very low, ‘He died as he lived.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘His end,’ said I, with dull anger stirring in me, ‘was in every way worthy of

label: ll>Last Line
line: his life.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘And I was not with him,’ she murmured. My anger subsided before a feeling of

label: ll>Last Line
line: infinite pity.

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘Everything that could be done—’ I mumbled.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Ah, but I believed in him more than any one on earth—more than his own mother,

label: l>Line
line: more than—himself. He needed me! Me! I would have treasured every sigh, every

label: ll>Last Line
line: word, every sign, every glance.’

label: sl>Single Line
line: “I felt like a chill grip on my chest. ‘Don’t,’ I said, in a muffled voice.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Forgive me. I—I have mourned so long in silence—in silence.... You were with

label: l>Line
line: him—to the last? I think of his loneliness. Nobody near to understand him as I

label: ll>Last Line
line: would have understood. Perhaps no one to hear....’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘To the very end,’ I said, shakily. ‘I heard his very last words....’ I stopped

label: ll>Last Line
line: in a fright.

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘Repeat them,’ she murmured in a heart-broken tone. ‘I want—I

label: ll>Last Line
line: want—something—something—to—to live with.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I was on the point of crying at her, ‘Don’t you hear them?’ The dusk was

label: l>Line
line: repeating them in a persistent whisper all around us, in a whisper that seemed

label: l>Line
line: to swell menacingly like the first whisper of a rising wind. ’The horror! The

label: ll>Last Line
line: horror!’

label: fl>First Line
line: “‘His last word—to live with,’ she insisted. ‘Don’t you understand I loved him—I

label: ll>Last Line
line: loved him—I loved him!’

label: sl>Single Line
line: “I pulled myself together and spoke slowly.

label: sl>Single Line
line: “‘The last word he pronounced was—your name.’

label: fl>First Line
line: “I heard a light sigh and then my heart stood still, stopped dead short by an

label: l>Line
line: exulting and terrible cry, by the cry of inconceivable triumph and of

label: l>Line
line: unspeakable pain. ‘I knew it—I was sure!’... She knew. She was sure.  I heard

label: l>Line
line: her weeping; she had hidden her face in her hands. It seemed to me that the

label: l>Line
line: house would collapse before I could escape, that the heavens would fall upon my

label: l>Line
line: head. But nothing happened. The heavens do not fall for such a trifle. Would

label: l>Line
line: they have fallen, I wonder, if I had rendered Kurtz that justice which was his

label: l>Line
line: due? Hadn’t he said he wanted only justice? But I couldn’t. I could not tell

label: ll>Last Line
line: her. It would have been too dark—too dark altogether....”

label: fl>First Line
line: Marlow ceased, and sat apart, indistinct and silent, in the pose of a meditating

label: l>Line
line: Buddha. Nobody moved for a time. “We have lost the first of the ebb,” said the

label: l>Line
line: Director suddenly. I raised my head. The offing was barred by a black bank of

label: l>Line
line: clouds, and the tranquil waterway leading to the uttermost ends of the earth

label: l>Line
line: flowed sombre under an overcast sky—seemed to lead into the heart of an immense

label: ll>Last Line
line: darkness.
